questions.text: Which of the following drugs come under Schedule H of the Drugs and Cosmetics Act, 1945?

choices.text: Biologicals and special products like insulin, toxin and antitoxins
Drugs  purchased with the prescription of a qualified doctor
Drugs with a warning label  “Caution: it is dangerous to take this preparation except under medical supervision”

questions.solution:
Schedule H includes drugs purchased over the counter with the prescription of a qualified doctor.

The Drugs and Cosmetics Rules, classify drugs under different schedules based on their potential for abuse, their therapeutic value, and other factors. The rules provide guidelines for the storage, sale, display, and prescription of each schedule.

Other options:

Option A- Biological and special products like insulin, toxin, and antitoxins are included under Schedule C.

Option B- Bacterial vaccines are included under Schedule F I.

Option D- Drugs that should be labelled with the words “Caution: it is dangerous to take this preparation except under medical supervision” are included under Schedule G.

Related Pearl: Drug regulatory schedules 1940: (2016 update)

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false about the conditions given below?

choices.text: It is more common in girls than boys
Haab striae is seen in late stages
Prognosis is worse if glaucoma is present since birth.

questions.solution:
Congenital glaucoma occurs more often in boys than in girls and is commonly seen bilaterally.

The first sign may be an edema of the cornea with watering of the eyes and marked photo­ phobia. At a later stage, rupture of Descemet's membrane causes more discrete corneal opacities (Haab’s striae.)

The Prognosis is

  • Worst – if glaucoma is present since birth.
  • Best – if present from 2 months to 1 year.  

Related Pearl: Causes of congenital opacities of the cornea

Causes of congenital opacities of the cornea (STUMPED)

S - Sclerocornea

T - Tears in the Descemet membrane secondary to birth trauma or congenital glaucoma

U - Ulcer

M - Mucopolysaccharidosis

P - Peters anomaly

E - Congenital hereditary endothelial dystrophy

D - Dermoid

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents with foul-smelling vaginal discharge due to a bacterial infection. When subjecting a fresh sample of the vaginal discharge to 10% KOH, a characteristic fishy odour is seen. Which of the following is not responsible for the formation of fishy odour in the above case?
questions.solution:
The given clinical findings of foul-smelling vaginal discharge and the presence of the characteristic fishy odour on subjecting the vaginal discharge to 10% KOH (whiff test) are suggestive of bacterial vaginosis. It is associated with the marked decrease in the hydrogen peroxide–producing lactobacillus species that constitute most of the normal vaginal microbiota.

Bacterial vaginosis is a polymicrobial infection caused by Mobiluncus curtisii, Gardnerella vaginalis, Mycoplasma hominis, and Haemophilus vaginalis. This change in vaginal microbiota from Lactobacillus species is associated with an increase in pH. Many females are asymptomatic carriers but the majority complain of malodorous vaginal discharge without itching.  

Amsel's Criteria is helpful in diagnosing bacterial vaginosis when 3 of the following 4 are present :

  • Thin, grayish-white homogenous vaginal discharge
  • A pH of vaginal fluid >4.5.
  • Fishy odor of discharge accentuated by adding 10% KOH-(Whiff test). 
  • Presence of clue cells which are vaginal epithelial cells covered with coccobacilli 

The whiff test is performed by mixing vaginal fluid with a drop of KOH on a microscope slide. Because of its alkaline qualities, KOH causes the vaginal fluid to release volatile amines like trimethylamine, which gives the vaginal fluid its distinctive fishy odour. The amines are products of anaerobic bacterial metabolism. 

Treatment is oral metronidazole 500mg BD for 7 days or oral tinidazole 2g for 3 days. Alternatively, oral clindamycin 300mg BID for 7 days can also be given.

The given images show clue cells on microscopy.

questions.text: A 20-year-old male patient is diagnosed with acute myeloid leukemia. The peripheral blood smear picture is given in the image. The cell indicated by the arrow is best described as:
questions.solution:
The given cell shows multiple Auer rods clustered together within a single cell resembling a bundle of sticks. Such cells have been termed as faggot cells (faggot in French means bundle of sticks).  

Since the question specifically asks about the cell, the best answer is faggot cell (not Auer rods).

Option A: Auer rods are distinctive needle-like azurophilic granules present in many cases but particularly numerous in AML with the t(15;17) aberration (acute promyelocytic leukemia).  

Option B: The term flaming promyelocyte refers to cells that appear to be breaking apart, taking on a vibrant reddish-purple hue with the apparent liberation of granules into the surrounding cellular matrix. 

Option C: Promyelocytes containing fine granules appear dusky or hazy and are referred to as dusky promyelocytes.

questions.text: In which of the following patients would you expect to find an increased anion gap?
questions.solution:
The anion gap is increased in ketoacidosis. The ketone bodies act as unmeasured anions and increase the anion gap.

The anion gap is calculated as:

AG = (Na+) – [(Cl-) + (HCO3-)]

The normal anion gap is 6 - 12 mEq/L (optimally <10 mEq/L).

O2 saturation > 95%

questions.text: Which of the following changes can be seen in the quadruple screening for Down syndrome?

choices.text: Elevated β-hCG, PAPP-A and lower estriol, AFP
Elevated β-hCG, Inhibin and lower estriol, AFP
Lower β-hCG, PAPP-A and elevated estriol, AFP
Lower  β-hCG, Inhibin and elevated estriol, AFP

questions.solution:
Quadruple screening is a second-trimester multiple marker screening test used for the detection of chromosomal anomalies like Down syndrome. It is performed between 15-21 weeks.

Pregnancies with Down syndrome are characterized by elevated β-hCG, elevated Inhibin A, reduced estriol and reduced AFP levels.

  Trisomy 21 Trisomy 18 Neural tube defect or abdominal wall defect
MSAFP Low Low High
β hCG High Low Normal
Unconjugated estriol Low Low Normal
Inhibin A High Low Normal

First-trimester aneuploidy screening combines two maternal serum analytes (Dual screening test) with a sonographic measurement. It is performed between 11-14 weeks.

Dual test Down’s syndrome Trisomy 18 & Trisomy 13
PAPP-A (pregnancy associated plasma protein A) ↓ ↓
β-HCG ↑  ↓

An increased nuchal translucency indicates an increased possibility of Down's syndrome.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false about Wedl cells?

choices.text: They are also called bladder cells
These cells are seen in posterior subcapsular cataract

questions.solution:
Wedl cells are swollen migratory epithelial lens cells associated with cataract especially posterior subcapsular cataract.

On slit lamp microscopy they appear vacuolated.

They are also termed as bladder cells.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman underwent an emergency LSCS under general anesthesia to deliver a term, healthy infant. Two hours later, she developed sudden tachypnea, cyanosis, and massive pulmonary edema and died despite resuscitative measures. The histopathological picture of her lung is shown below.  What is the likely cause of death?
questions.solution:
The given scenario and image showing massive neutrophilic infiltration are suggestive of Mendelson’s syndrome or aspiration pneumonitis.

Mendelson's syndrome is a chemical pneumonitis caused by the aspiration of sterile gastric contents during general anesthesia, especially during pregnancy. The most common cause of maternal mortality associated with general anesthesia is either due to a pulmonary aspiration or a failed endotracheal intubation. 

The risk factors for Mendelson's syndrome include:

  • Gastric volume > 25 mL (0.4 mL/kg)
  • Gastric pH < 2.5

Incidence of aspiration can be reduced by administration of:

  • Non-particulate antacids like sodium citrate 30-45 minutes prior to intubation
  • H2 receptor antagonists like intravenous ranitidine 
  • Metoclopramide 1-2 hours prior to induction

Option B: Cryptogenic organizing pneumonia is a type of ILD associated with Masson bodies and plugs of loose connective tissue on histology.

Option C: CMV pneumonia is associated with the owl's eye appearance on histology.

Option D: PCP pneumonia is associated with black-walled cysts on silver staining.

questions.text: The identification of Salmonella and Shigella in stool cultures using eosin–methylene blue (EMB) medium is dependent on which of the following properties?

choices.text: Salmonella and Shigella produce a blue colony in the presence of methylene blue.
Salmonella and Shigella produce a colorless colony.
Salmonella and Shigella produce a dark blue black colony with green sheen.
Salmonella and Shigella produce a yellow colony.

questions.solution:
Salmonella and Shigella produce a colorless colony in the eosin methylene blue agar because they do not ferment lactose.  

EMB agar: Eosin methylene blue (EMB) agar is a selective, differential medium.

It is selective because it allows the growth of gram-negative rods and inhibits the growth of gram-positive organisms.

Its differential property is based on the fact that Salmonella and Shigella do not ferment lactose while other enteric gram-negative rods do.  

On EMB agar, Escherichia coli appear as dark blue-black colonies with green metallic sheen because they are lactose fermenters.

Since both Salmonella and Shigella appear colorless, triple-sugar iron agar is used to differentiate Salmonella from Shigella.

This medium contains

  • 0.1% glucose
  • 1% sucrose
  • 1% lactose
  • Ferrous sulfate (for detection of H2S production)
  • Tissue extracts (protein growth substrate)
  • A pH indicator (phenol red)

It is poured into a test tube to produce a slant with a deep butt and is inoculated by stabbing bacterial growth into the butt.  

If only glucose is fermented, the slant and the butt initially turn yellow from the small amount of acid produced; as the fermentation products are subsequently oxidized to CO2 and H2O and released from the slant and as oxidative decarboxylation of proteins continues with formation of amines, the slant turns alkaline (red).  

  • If lactose or sucrose is fermented, so much acid is produced that the slant and butt remain yellow (acid). Salmonella and Shigella typically yield an alkaline slant and an acid butt. 
  • If gas is produced, bubbles and cracks can be seen in the medium. 
  • If H2S is produced, the black color of ferrous sulfide can be seen.
Name of the organism Slant Butt Gas H2S
E. coli, Klebsiella, Enterobacter Acid Acid Positive Negative
Shigella, Serratia Alkaline Acid Negative Negative
Salmonella, Proteus Alkaline Acid Positive Positive
Pseudomonas Alkaline Alkaline Negative Negative

questions.text: A 14 year old male is brought with the complaints of multiple hyperpigmented papules over the face and other sun exposed areas with persistent erythema. He had history of similar episodes since childhood. Which of the following mechanisms is likely to be defective in this condition?

choices.text: Removal of mismatched base during DNA replication
Removal of oligonucleotides containing damaged bases by endonuclease
Removal of the altered base by base specific glycosylase

questions.solution:
The above given clinical findings is suggestive of xeroderma pigmentosum. Defect in the removal of oligonucleotides containing the damaged bases by endonucleases is seen in xeroderma pigmentosum.

Xeroderma Pigmentosum (XP) is a rare autosomal recessive genetic disorder characterized by defective DNA repair which leads to clinical and cellular hypersensitivity to ultraviolet radiation and other carcinogenic agents.  

Important clinical features are:

Intense cutaneous photosensitivity, xerosis, poikiloderma, actinic keratosis, acute burning under minimal sun exposure, erythemas, hyperpigmented lentiginous macules, and malignant lesions in sun-exposed areas, including basocellular carcinoma, squamous cell carcinoma, and melanoma.  

The final diagnosis of XP can be confirmed by special laboratory tests by examining the DNA damage repair in cells from cultures exposed to ultraviolet radiation. The most common tests are skin biopsy and culture of skin fibroblasts.  

There is no cure for XP. Treatment consists of minimizing exposure to sunlight and regular dermatological care, as well as surgery for recurrent tumors excision. Patients should be followed up every 3 months. Genetic counseling is important in a family that has an affected child and is considering having more children.

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding parenteral administration of alteplase?

choices.text: It increases the formation of plasminogen
It is indicated in hemorrhagic stroke
It can cause bleeding, which can be counteracted by aminocaproic acid
Alteplase has the advantage of activating free plasminogen

questions.solution:
All thrombolytics can cause bleeding, which may be counteracted by the administration of antifibrinolytics, such as aminocaproic acid and tranexamic acid.  

Alteplase is a recombinant tissue plasminogen activator and activates plasminogen bound to fibrin, and catalyses the conversion of plasminogen to plasmin, resulting in increased formation of plasmin(Option A). This results in fibrinolysis of formed thrombus(thrombolysis). It is indicated in pulmonary embolism with hemodynamic instability, severe deep vein thrombosis, ascending thrombophlebitis, acute ischemic stroke and acute myocardial infarction.  

Alteplase has the advantage of only activating plasminogen bound to fibrin (clot specific) but not free plasminogen (option D). 

Contraindications of alteplase:

  • Risk of bleeding(including intracranial hemorrhage (Option B), subarachnoid hemorrhage, and those with active internal bleeding)
  • Recent intracranial, intraspinal surgery or head trauma in previous 3 months
  • Intracranial neoplasm, arteriovenous malformation, or aneurysm
  • Bleeding diathesis
  • Severe uncontrolled hypertension

Related Pearl: Plasminogen activators (classification of fibrinolytics)

Fibrin non-specific plasminogen activators

  • Streptokinase - least fibrin specific and has the lowest incidence of intracranial hemorrhage
  • Anistreplase
  • Urokinase

Fibrin specific plasminogen activators

  • Alteplase - has the shortest half-life
  • Tenecteplase - most fibrin specific and given as a single bolus dose
  • Reteplase

questions.text: A 20-year-old male from West Bengal, presents with complaints of recurrent fever with chills for the past 3 months with progressive weakness and abdominal discomfort. On examination he has hepatosplenomegaly. Bone marrow aspiration finding is given in the image. Which of the following can be given for the treatment?
questions.solution:
The given scenario of recurrent fever with chills, progressive weakness, and hepatosplenomegaly along with the presence of intracellular organisms within the macrophages is suggestive of visceral leishmaniasis. It can be treated with sodium stibogluconate. 

Drugs used in the treatment of visceral leishmaniasis are sodium stibogluconate, miltefosine, and amphotericin. Liposomal amphotericin single dose 10 mg/Kg IV is the first line of treatment in India. For most regions of the endemic regions of the world, pentavalent antimony compounds like sodium stibogluconate are the drug of choice. In India, antimony resistance has been noted and thus Amphotericin B is the drug of choice. Miltefosine is an oral drug that is also approved for treatment of this condition

Kala-azar or visceral leishmaniasis is a protozoal infection mainly affecting the reticuloendothelial system. It is caused by the Leishmania donovani complex which includes L. donovani and L. infantum. These organisms are transmitted by sandflies. When the infected sandfly bites a person, infectious promastigotes are released into the host dermis along with the sandfly's saliva, which potentiates parasite infectivity.

L. donovani exists in 2 forms:

  • Amastigote form- in humans and other mammals
  • Promastigote form- in the sandfly and artificial culture

The amastigote form (as shown in the image below) is also known as the Leishman-Donovan (LD) body. It is an intracellular form found inside macrophages, monocytes, and reticuloendothelial cells. It contains a kinetoplast which consists of a parabasal body and a blepharoplast. Flagellum is absent.

Promastigote form (as shown in the below image) is present in the midgut of the female sandfly. The kinetoplast lies transversely near the anterior end. A single flagellum is seen. It is the infective form of Leishmania donovani for humans.

In India, it is endemic to Bihar, West Bengal, Jharkhand, and Uttar Pradesh. Patients present with high fever, hepatosplenomegaly, weight loss, and emaciation. The skin becomes dry, rough, and darkly pigmented. There is anemia, leukopenia, and thrombocytopenia.

Diagnosis:

  • Rapid diagnostic test: rK39 Rapid diagnostic test and Kala azar dipstick test strip.
  • Parasitological diagnosis: Demonstration of LD bodies in buffy coat smear - confirmatory.
  • Aldehyde test of Napier: Widely used for surveillance.
  • Serological tests for diagnosis: Rapid dipstick test, Direct agglutination test, ELISA, Indirect Fluorescent Antibody Test.
  • Leishmania (Montenegro) test: Induration of 5 mm or more is considered positive, usually positive 4-6 weeks after onset in cutaneous leishmaniasis, valuable for distinguishing immune from non-immune subjects and endemicity.

Drugs used in the treatment of visceral leishmaniasis are sodium stibogluconate, miltefosine, and amphotericin. Liposomal amphotericin single dose 10 mg/Kg IV is the first line of treatment in India.  

Other options:  

Option A: Benznidazole is used in the treatment of Chagas disease caused by protozoa Trypanosoma cruzi. 

Option C: Suramin is used in the treatment of African sleeping sickness caused by Trypanosoma brucei. 

Option D: Atovaquone can be used in the treatment of babesiosis and Pneumocystis jiroveci infection.

questions.text: A patient has a HbA2 of 3% and HbF of 97%. A peripheral blood smear is taken. Which of the following blood pictures will be seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
The presence of HbA2 3% and HbF 97% indicates that it is a case of thalassemia major. In thalassemia major, hematological findings in image 1 showing poikilocytes and image 3 showing target cells are seen. Image 2 showing Howell Jolly bodies are seen in post-splenectomy thalassemia patients and not in this case.

Hematological findings in thalassemia major include the following:

  • Anisopoikilocytosis
  • Target cells (codocytes)
  • Nucleated RBC’s
  • Dacrocytes
  • Basophilic stippling
  • Polychromatophilic cells

Related Pearl: Thalassemia syndromes

Normally each individual carries 4 functional alpha chain genes and 2 functional beta chain genes. Alpha and beta-thalassemia are inherited disorders in which there is reduced production of alpha-globin or beta-globin chains, respectively.

  • Alpha thalassemia: Gene deletion is the most common cause of reduced α-chain synthesis.
  • Beta +- thalassemia: The most common cause is splicing mutation.
  • Beta 0- thalassemia: Chain terminator mutations are the most common cause.

questions.text: A 22-year-old medical student was scuba diving while vacationing in Malaysia. During her last dive, her regulator malfunctioned, requiring her to ascend from 20 meters to the surface rapidly. Upon returning to the boat she was initially well but developed blurred vision, slurred speech, nausea and muscles aches requiring recompression and hyperbaric oxygen therapy for decompression sickness. Which of the following is considered a contraindication of hyperbaric oxygen therapy?
questions.solution:
History of prior bleomycin therapy is a common contraindication of hyperbaric oxygen therapy.

Bleomycin therapy is associated with a dose-dependent risk of pneumonitis and the risk may be enhanced with hyperbaric oxygen exposure.

Other contraindications of hyperbaric therapy include, untreated pneumothorax (risk of rapidly expanding and causing tension upon decompression) and patients with extensive bullae.

questions.text: Ketamine is the common anesthetic agent to cause dissociative sedation. Dissociative sedation is a type of_____:
questions.solution:
Ketamine produces dissociative anaesthesia which is considered to be a type of moderate sedation. 

It produces a trance like state with sedation, not without sedation. 

Dissociation is a state in which cortical centers are prevented from receiving sensory stimuli, but cardiopulmonary activity and responses are preserved.

Moderate sedation (conscious sedation) is characterized by a depressed level of consciousness and a slower but purposeful motor response to simple verbal or tactile stimuli. Used for procedures where patient cooperation is not required. Procedures performed under moderate sedation include reduction of dislocated joints, thoracostomy tube insertion, and synchronized cardioversion.

Other options:  

  • Minimal sedation is characterized by anxiolysis but with normal, although sometimes slowed, response to verbal stimuli. Used for procedures where patient cooperation is required. Minimal sedation procedures might include abscess incision and drainage, lumbar puncture, simple fracture reductions, and laceration repair.
  • Deep sedation is characterized by a profoundly depressed level of consciousness, with a purposeful motor response elicited only after repeated or painful stimuli. Used where muscle relaxation and a minimal patient reaction is required. The risk of losing airway patency or developing hypoxia or hypoventilation is greater with deep sedation than with moderate or minimal sedation.  Deep sedation is often required for reducing fracture dislocations, open fracture reductions, and burn wound care.

questions.text: A 28-year-old male patient was brought to the trauma center following a bike accident. He was stuporous, speaking incoherent words in response to painful stimuli and bleeding from a deep penetrating wound in his right thigh. On examination, his pulse was weak and 110/min. His BP was 90/66 mmHg. His respiration rate was 22/min. The skin on his extremities was cold and clammy. What is the best method of restoring adequate cardiac output and tissue oxygenation in this patient?
questions.solution:
The above clinical picture points towards a diagnosis of hemorrhagic shock.

Nearly 70% of the body’s total blood volume is estimated to be located in the venous circuit. Compliance of the venous system involves a relationship between venous volume and venous pressure. This pressure gradient drives venous flow and therefore the volume of venous return to the heart. Blood loss depletes this component of venous volume and reduces the pressure gradient; consequently, venous return is reduced.

In a case of hemorrhagic shock, the most effective method of restoring adequate cardiac output, end-organ perfusion, and tissue oxygenation is to restore venous return to normal by locating and stopping the source of bleeding.

Other options:

  • Volume repletion will allow recovery from the shock state only when the bleeding has stopped and the first line is crystalloids, not blood products.
  • Since the patient already has cutaneous vasoconstriction, vasopressors are not administered without prior adequate fluid resuscitation to avoid further vasoconstriction and gangrene formation.

Related Pearl: Classification of hemorrhagic shock

Parameters Class I Class II Class III Class IV
Blood loss in % <15 15–30 30–40 >40
Pulse rate <100 100–120 120–140 >140
Blood pressure Normal Normal Decreased Greatly decreased
Pulse pressure Normal or increased Decreased Decreased Decreased
Respiratory rate 14–20 20–30 30–40 >35
Mental status Slightly anxious Mildly anxious Anxious, confused Confused, lethargic
Urine output (mL/hr) >30 20–30 5–15 Minimal

 

Related Pearl: Trauma Scoring Systems

Revised Trauma Score  - Total score 0-12 :

  • Glasgow coma scale
  • Respiratory rate
  • Systolic BP

Glasgow coma scale  - Total score 3-15 :

  • Eye-opening
  • Verbal response
  • Motor response

Abbreviated Injury Scale: AIS severity code – 1(minimal severity) to 6 (presumably fatal)

Injury Severity Score – Total score 1 to 75. Calculated summing the squares of the AIS severity codes for the three most severely injured body regions

Score Severity of injury
3-8 Minor
9-16 Moderate
16-24 Serious
>25 Severe/ Critical

  

Mangled Extremity Severity score: Mnemonic - ELiSA

  • Energy that caused the injury, skeletal and soft tissue injury
  • Limb ischemia
  • Shock
  • Patient’s age

TRISS (Trauma and Injury Severity Score) : Mnemonic - IRMA

  • Injury Severity Score
  • Revised Trauma Score
  • Mechanism of Injury (blunt/penetrating)
  • Age

questions.text: An asymptomatic 30-year-old man presents with a lesion on his thigh as seen in the below image. He returned a week ago from the US where he inspected farming areas during the summer. The best management for this patient would be:

choices.text: Reassurance as it is a fixed drug eruption

questions.solution:
The given image classically depicts the bull’s eye lesion (erythema chronicum migrans) and the clinical history is suggestive of the diagnosis of Lyme disease. The drug of choice for early asymptomatic Lyme disease is Doxycycline 100 mg BD.

Lyme disease is caused by the spirochete Borrelia burgdorferi and is transmitted by the hard tick, Ixodes. It usually occurs after a tick bite while strolling through the farms. Most of them do not recall the bite and the initial presentation is only a skin lesion known as erythema chronicum migrans.

It is only after dissemination, that the disease spreads to joints (arthritis), heart (AV blocks), and the nervous system (neuroborreliosis).

The treatment protocol for early Lyme disease includes:

  • Doxycycline 100 mg BD (Drug of choice) for 2-3 weeks (or)
  • Amoxicillin 500 – 1000 mg for 2-3 weeks (for children < 9 years, pregnant women)

In severe disseminated cases, Ceftriaxone 2 g IV for 2-3 weeks can be given. 

Other options:

Option A - Chloroquine and tafenoquine are used to prevent Plasmodium vivax malaria relapse. There are no clinical symptoms suggestive of Malaria. 

Option C - Antihistamines can be used to treat urticaria. Patients present with short-lived itchy weals, angioedema, or both. 

Option D - Fixed drug eruption presents as a sharply defined oval or round erythematous, edematous plaque. It becomes dusky, violaceous, and vesicular or bullous. It occurs in the lips, genitals, palms, and soles.

questions.text: Which of the following β1 selective blockers has vasodilating action by increasing nitric oxide production?
questions.solution:
Nebivolol is a β1 selective blocker that has vasodilating action by increasing nitric oxide production.

Nebivolol is a third-generation, long-acting, and highly selective β1 adrenergic receptor antagonist that stimulates NO-mediated vasodilation via β3 receptor agonism.

It is used for the treatment of hypertension and for heart failure with reduced ejection fraction. It lowers blood pressure by reducing peripheral vascular resistance and significantly increases stroke volume with preservation of cardiac output and maintains systemic flow and blood flow to
target organs. It also reduces oxidative stress.

Acebutolol is a second generation β1-selective antagonist with some intrinsic sympathomimetic
and membrane-stabilizing activity.


Third generation β receptor antagonists with additional mechanisms for vasodilation :

Nitric oxide production Β2 receptor agonism   α1 receptor antagonism   Ca2+ entry blockade K+ channel opening Antioxidant activity

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman, G2P1L1 at 33 weeks of gestation is admitted to the hospital for management of spontaneous preterm labor. What is the dose of dexamethasone administered to stimulate fetal lung maturation in her?
questions.solution:
The dose of dexamethasone administered to stimulate fetal lung maturation is 6 mg 12 hourly 4 doses IM.  

Antenatal corticosteroids are recommended in a pregnancy less than 34 weeks to allow fetal lung maturation and to reduce the incidence of respiratory distress syndrome (RDS), intraventricular hemorrhage (IVH), necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC), periventricular leukomalacia (PVL), overall neonatal mortality, and neurodevelopmental impairment. 

Betamethasone is the steroid of choice and it becomes useful if the delivery is delayed beyond 48 hours of the first dose with the effect lasting for about 18 days. The dose of Betamethasone is 12 mg IM 24 hourly 2 doses. Dexamethasone is another steroid that can be given in a dose of 6 mg 12 hourly 4 doses IM.  

Preterm labour is the onset of labour before 37 completed weeks of pregnancy (less than 259 days of gestation). It can occur in patients with a history of prior preterm birth, multiple pregnancies and genital tract infections. Evaluation of cervical anatomy is the most important step in women with a history of preterm labour to look for cervical incompetence. 

Features of preterm labour include regular uterine contractions at least once every 10 minutes, with/without pain, cervical dilatation >2 cm and effacement >80% and length of cervix <2.5 cm and funnelling of the internal os >1 cm.

The best predictors of preterm labour in a woman with a previous history of preterm birth are fetal fibronectin >50ng/ml and cervical length <2.5cm on transvaginal ultrasound.

Short-term therapy with tocolytics is given in conjunction with steroids for 1-3 days to delay labour for at least 48 hours or to transfer the patient to a tertiary centre (with NICU). The drugs include terbutaline, indomethacin, nifedipine, and atosiban. Contraindications to tocolysis include chorioamnionitis, preeclampsia/eclampsia, fetal distress, pregnancy >34 weeks, active labour, and placental abruption.

questions.text: All of the following can be seen in a patient with lead poisoning except?

choices.text: Elevated levels of porphobilinogen in blood
Elevated levels of ALA and coproporphyrinogen in urine

questions.solution:
Porphobilinogen is not elevated in blood in lead poisoning.  

Lead inhibits enzymes ALA dehydratase and ferrochelatase which are involved in the heme synthesis. ALA is converted to porphobilinogen by ALA dehydratase which is inhibited by lead. So, porphobilinogen is never elevated in lead poisoning.

Signs are

  • Elevated level of protoporphyrin in blood and elevated urinary levels of ALA and coproporphyrin. 
  • Ringed sideroblasts in bone marrow
  • Microcytic anemia with basophilic stippling in peripheral smear.
  • Cabot rings in RBCs - Cabot rings are thin, threadlike ring- or “figure eight” shaped red blood cell inclusions, likely remnants from mitotic spindles. They are rarely seen in peripheral blood, and their presence indicates a defect in erythrocyte production. Also seen in megaloblastic anemia, homozygous thalassemia, and splenectomy.

questions.text: The following findings are seen in a man who presents to the OPD. The CT scan of his neck is given below. Which of the following situations is not at the risk of being converted to an open sternotomy during surgery?

choices.text: If this is a case of revision surgery
Diameter of goiter is more than thoracic inlet
If the swelling extends into the anterior mediastinum

questions.solution:
The two images(A&B) show a positive Pemberton’s sign, which is indicative of a Superior Vena Cava Syndrome. The CT scan shows a large thyroid goiter and extension into the mediastinum (retrosternal extension).

Most of the retrosternal goiters (>95%) are removed transcervically.

Those at most risk of conversion into an open sternotomy are:

  • Malignant swellings
  • Revision surgery
  • Diameter of goiter is more than thoracic inlet
  • Swelling extends into posterior mediastinum

Pemberton's sign is positive when bilateral arm elevation causes facial plethora. It has been attributed to a "cork effect" resulting from the thyroid obstructing the thoracic inlet, thereby increasing pressure on the venous system.

questions.text: Which of these is not a pre-leukemic condition?
questions.solution:
Paroxysmal cold hemoglobinuria is not a preleukemic condition. 

It is an autoimmune hemolytic anemia due to IgG autoantibodies that bind to the P blood group antigen and cause intravascular hemolysis and hemoglobinuria. Most cases are seen in children and show recovery within a month.

Option A: Few patients with paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH) develop acute non-lymphocytic leukemia. This is thought to arise from the injured marrow as a secondary hematopoietic disorder.

Option B: Bone marrow aplasia preceding acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) is a rare condition that usually affects children. It generally follows the recovery of normal blood counts and most commonly occurs within 6 months of the onset of aplasia.

Option C: Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) occurs in 10% to 40% of individuals with myelodysplastic syndromes (MDS). It is usually accompanied by the appearance of additional cytogenetic abnormalities.

questions.text: While the genetic code has 64 codons, there are only 20 naturally occurring amino acids. Most amino acids are encoded by more than one codon. This feature of genetic code is said to be
questions.solution:
The genetic code is degenerate because most amino acids are encoded by more than one codon.  

Other features of genetic code are:

  • Unambiguous : Each codon specifies only one amino acid. 
  • Non punctuate:There is no punctuation between codons, and the message is read in a continuing sequence of nucleotide triplets until a translation stop codon is reached.
  • Non overlapping : The reading of the genetic code during the process of protein synthesis does not involve any overlap of codons. Read from a fixed starting point as a continuous sequence of bases
  • Universal : Genetic code is conserved throughout evolution.  

Exceptions : Methionine and tryptophan encode by only one codon(AUG and UGG respectively)

questions.text: The given epithelium in the histological image is not found in
questions.solution:
The above image shows transitional epithelium, identified by the variations in the cell layers: The deepest cell layer is columnar, the middle is made of polyhedral cells and lastly the surface cells are large and umbrella-shaped. Transitional epithelium lines the pre-prostatic and prostatic part of the urethra (not the membranous urethra).  

Transitional epithelium is found in the renal pelvis and calyces, the ureter, the urinary bladder, and the pre-prostatic and prostatic part of the urethra. Because of this distribution, it is also called the urothelium.  

In the urinary bladder, it is usually observed that transitional epithelium can be stretched considerably without being damaged. When stretched it appears to be thinner and the cells become flattened or rounded.  

The following are various parts of the urethra in males and their lining epithelium:

  • Pre-prostatic & Prostatic urethra: Transitional epithelium
  • Membranous urethra: Pseudostratified columnar
  • Penile/Spongy urethra: Proximally: Pseudostratified columnar, Distally: Stratified squamous

questions.text: All of the following are risk factors for PID except______.
questions.solution:
Pregnancy is not a risk factor for PID. Instead, it plays a protective role in this condition.

The risk factors for developing PID are:

  • Unprotected sexual intercourse
  • Having multiple sex partners
  • Previous history of PID
  • IUD insertion
  • Early age of sexual intercourse (<18years)

The protective factors for PID are:

  • Pregnancy 
  • Using barrier contraception like condoms, diaphragms
  • Oral contraceptive pills (OCPs)
  • Menopause

questions.text:
A microbiologist was studying a fungal cell wall polysaccharide called glucan, which has been used for the diagnosis of certain invasive fungal infections. Which of the following fungal infections can be detected by this assay?

1. Invasive aspergillosis
2. Invasive candidiasis
3. Invasive cryptococcosis
4. Pneumocystis jiroveci infection
questions.solution:
The given diagnostic assay is a 1, 3 beta D Glucan assay. Invasive aspergillosis, invasive candidiasis, and infection with Pneumocystis jiroveci are detected by this assay. But, invasive cryptococcosis is not detected by this assay. It is diagnosed by the detection of the cryptococcus capsular polysaccharide.

Fungi have an essential rigid cell wall that determines their shape and protects them from environmental stresses. Cell walls are made up of carbohydrate layers, glycoproteins, and lipids. It has components such as chitin, glucan, and mannans which are cross-linked to form a multilayered cell wall matrix. In addition, other polysaccharides may be unique to specific fungal species and therefore useful for identification.

1,3-β-d-glucan (BDG) is a cell wall polysaccharide composed of glucose polymers and is found in most fungi, more commonly: candida, aspergillus, and Pneumocystis jiroveci.  

However, it is not detectable in the fungi such as cryptococci, zygomycetes, and Blastomyces dermatitidis, which either lack the glucan entirely or produce it at minimal levels.  

This assay is a chromogenic, quantitative enzyme immunoassay (EIA) used to detect beta D Glucan by using purified, lysed horseshoe crab (Limulus polyphemus) amebocytes. These cells contain factors C and G which are components of the Limulus clotting cascade. Factor C initiates coagulation in the presence of bacterial liposaccharide and factor G initiates coagulation in the presence of Beta D Glucan. By eliminating factor C from the lysate, the manufacturers limit activation of the cascade to Beta D glucan alone.

questions.text: Which of the following is not an example of feed forward control mechanism?

choices.text: Exercise resulting in heart rate increase

questions.solution:
Exercise resulting in heart rate increase is not an example of feedforward control mechanism. However, thinking about exercise and it resulting in a heart rate increase would be an example of feedforward control mechanism.  

Feedforward control is that which makes an anticipatory or adaptive response without a specific stimulus.  

Temperature control - Thermoregulatory responses are initiated by the hypothalamus before the changes in environmental temperature changes the core body temperature. Thus, shivering in response to cold environment would be an example of feedforward control.

In the cephalic phase of gastric secretion, the thought of food itself and not food per se produces a gastric secretion.

The cerebellum has a feed-forward inhibition that limits the duration of the excitation produced by any given afferent volley.

Heart rate is accelerated by
  • Decreased activity of arterial baroreceptors
  • Increased activity of atrial stretch receptors
  • Inspiration
  • Excitement
  • Anger

  • Hypoxia
  • Exercise
  • Thyroid hormones
  • Fever

The Heart is slowed by
  • Increased activity of arterial baroreceptors
  • Expiration
  • Grief
  • Stimulation of pain fibers in trigeminal nerve
  • Increased intracranial pressure

questions.text: Which of the following nerve is involved in the action of the thumb depicted in the image given?
questions.solution:
The given image shows abduction of the thumb. It is mediated by abductor pollicis longus which is supplied by posterior interosseous nerve.  

The posterior interosseous nerve is the deep terminal branch of the radial nerve.  

It reaches the back of the forearm by passing round the lateral aspect of the radius between the two heads of supinator. It supplies supinator both before entering the muscle and as it passes through it.

As it emerges from supinator posteriorly, the nerve gives off three short branches to

  • Extensor digitorum
  • Extensor digiti minimi and
  • Extensor carpi ulnaris

and two longer branches:

  • A medial branch to extensor pollicis longus and extensor indicis, and 
  • A lateral branch that supplies abductor pollicis longus and extensor pollicis brevis.  

Articular branches supply :

Carpal, distal radio-ulnar and some intercarpal and intermetacarpal joints.

Digital branches supply :

The metacarpophalangeal and proximal interphalangeal joints.

questions.text: Which of the following forms the anterolateral wall of the true pelvis?
questions.solution:
Obturator internus with its fascia forms the anterolateral wall of the true pelvis.

Muscles forming walls of the true pelvis:

  • Anterolateral wall - obturator internus and the fascia over its upper and inner (pelvic) surface.
  • Posterolateral wall - piriformis
  • Floor - levator ani and coccygeus

questions.text: A 5 month old child was breast-fed and developing normally. Within a few weeks of weaning, the child became lethargic and yellow skinned, with vomiting and diarrhoea. A biochemical test was performed and the result is shown in the image. Also urine dipstick test was negative. Which of the following enzyme is deficient in this child?
questions.solution:
The above given clinical findings where the child became symptomatic upon weaning is suggestive of fructose intolerance.

It is an autosomal recessive disorder with deficiency of enzyme aldolase B.  

The biochemical test in the image is benedict’s test used for testing the presence of reducing sugars.  

It is characterized by profound hypoglycemia and vomiting after consumption of fructose (or sucrose, which yields fructose on digestion). Fructose-induced hypoglycemia occurs despite the presence of high glycogen reserves, because fructose-1-phosphate allosterically inhibit liver glycogen phosphorylase. The sequestration of inorganic phosphate also leads to depletion of ATP and hyperuricemia.

Diets low in fructose, sorbitol, and sucrose are beneficial. 

Other options:

  • Fructokinase enzyme defect causes essential fructosuria. It is a benign, asymptomatic condition since fructose is not trapped in the cells.
  • Galactose-1-phosphate uridyltransferase deficiency leads to classic galactosemia in which symptoms develop when infants begin feeding. Clinical features include failure to thrive, jaundice, hepatomegaly, infantile cataracts, intellectual disability. It can predispose to E coli sepsis in neonates.
  • Aldose reductase is an enzyme that reduces glucose to sorbitol and has been implicated in the formation of cataract in diabetic patients.

questions.text: A 26-year-old athlete comes for a routine examination. He has no symptoms. The ECG is as shown below. Which of the following should be done?
questions.solution:
The given ECG shows sinus bradycardia with a heart rate of 45 bpm. The patient is an athlete and heart rates are usually lower in athletes.

As the patient is asymptomatic no further therapy should be given to increase the heart rate.

Sinus bradycardia:

  • Sinus bradycardia is defined as SA nodal rhythm with a rate <60 beats/min. However, in young healthy adults and athletes, a resting heart rate of <60 beats/min is common.
  • Also, a sinus pause of upto 3 seconds on ECG is commonly seen in athletes and elderly individuals.
  • If the rate is <40 beats/min, in an awake individual in the absence of physical training, then it is considered abnormal.

Diagnosis of SA node dysfunction:

  • The presence of abnormal sinus bradycardia or sinus pause on ECG is insufficient to diagnose SA node dysfunction. Longer-term electrocardiographic recording and clinical correlation are required to establish the diagnosis.
  • On the contrary, the presence of symptoms without any sinus bradycardia or sinus pause on ECG is sufficient to rule out SA node dysfunction.

questions.text:
Match the following:
1 - Kleptomania A - Intense desire to drink alcoholic drinks
2 - Pyromania B - Intense desire to mutilate
3 - Mutilomania C - Intense desire to steal items of trivial value
4 - Dipsomania D - Intense desire to burn things
questions.solution:
The correct option is 1-C, 2-D, 3-B, 4-A

Impulse control disorders are characterized by the repeated failure to resist an impulse, drive, or urge to perform an act that is rewarding to the person, at least in the short-term, despite consequences such as long-term harm either to the individual or to others; marked distress about the behavior pattern; or significant impairment in personal, family, social, educational, occupational, or other important areas of functioning.

It includes

  1. Pyromania
  2. Kleptomania 
  3. Compulsive sexual behavior disorder
  4. Intermittent explosive disorder

Kleptomania is the repeated failure to resist impulses to steal objects that are of no value to the person. The individual can usually afford the object or does not need it, but it is the act of stealing itself that is the goal. The stolen objects are usually given away, returned, or kept hidden. The act is not planned and is carried out alone.

Pyromania is the deliberate setting of fires on more than one occasion. 

Pyromania is significantly associated with the following:

  • Substance abuse disorder (especially alcoholism).
  • Affective disorders (depression or bipolar)
  • Other impulse control disorders, such as kleptomania in female firesetters.
  • Personality disturbances, such as borderline personality disorders.
  • Attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder and learning disabilities in childhood pyromania.

Dipsomania is an irresistible impulse to drink alcohol at a periodic intervals.

Mutilomania is an irresistible impulse to mutilate animals.

questions.text: Not true about Rosai-Dorfman syndrome is

choices.text: It is not a histiocytic neoplasm
Langerhans Cell Histiocytosis is often a differential diagnosis

questions.solution:
Painless, not painful, cervical nodes are commonly seen in Rosai Dorfman Syndrome.  

Rosai-Dorfman Syndrome is otherwise called sinus histiocytosis with massive lymphadenopathy.  

Rosai Dorfman disease is not a histiocytic neoplasm. It is an idiopathic disease characterized by Painless lymphadenopathy, usually of cervical nodes. The disorder predominantly affects children, adolescents or young adults. It may present with nonspecific symptoms and management mostly involves observation rather than specific treatment.

questions.text: Uterine contractions are palpable when its intensity is more than _____.
questions.solution:
Uterine contractions are palpable when the intensity is >10 mmHg.

Uterine contractions cause cervical dilatation at 15 mmHg and are painful beyond 15 mmHg.

Stage of labour      Pressure
1st 40–50 mmHg
2nd 100–120 mmHg
3rd 100–120 mmHg

Units for measuring the intensity of uterine contractions are mmHg and Montevideo units (MV).

1 MV = intensity of uterine contractions x number of contractions in 10 min.

During labour, normal uterine contractions are between 190 and 300 MV and at the time of delivery, it is 300 MV.

questions.text: In patients with which of the following conditions would a testicular biopsy be needed for a complete diagnostic workup?
questions.solution:
A testicular biopsy may be required to check for the presence of spermatogenesis in a patient with infertility if there is doubt regarding the cause for the same even after the initial workup using semen analysis and gonadotropin levels.

The assessment of the patient should be done by semen analysis, which should be performed within 2 hours of the semen being produced. Two or three samples should be tested. An endocrine screening should be performed including serum testosterone, prolactin, follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH), and luteinizing hormone (LH).

The absence of sperm in semen is known as azoospermia. It can be due to:

  • Pre-testicular azoospermia due to a hypothalamic or pituitary abnormality (hypogonadotropic-hypogonadism)
  • Testicular failure or non-obstructive azoospermia 
  • Post-testicular obstruction implies normal spermatogenesis but failure to deliver the sperm into the ejaculate because of ductal obstruction.  

Follicle-stimulating hormone(FSH) and testosterone are important for spermatogenesis but serum FSH levels are used to differentiate obstructive and non-obstructive azoospermia, as it had the highest specificity and sensitivity.

  • A low FSH level indicates pituitary or hypothalamic failure
  • A high FSH level denotes primary gonadal failure or testicular cause
  • A normal FSH level could be due to either non-obstructive or obstructive azoospermia. A testicular biopsy is usually required in such people to provide a definitive diagnosis.

A testicular biopsy (or aspirate) can also be used to harvest spermatozoa during intracytoplasmic sperm injection (ICSI) which are then injected in vitro into ova obtained from the mother.

Option A: A biopsy is contraindicated in a patient with a painless testicular mass as it may cause the seeding of the undiagnosed tumor.

Option B: In suspected testicular torsion, doppler study to assess vascular status of the testis is preferred.

Option C: In pyocoele, an assessment with USG is preferred as a testicular biopsy would not yield relevant information.

Forward progression >2 (Scale of 0-4)

  • Thyroid dysfunction
  • Hyperprolactinemia

Psychosexual

  • Impotence
  • Erectile dysfunction

Drugs

  • Antihypertensives
  • Antipsychotics

  • 47XXY
  • Y chromosome deletions

  • Immotile cilia syndrome
  • Cryptorchidism
  • Orchitis (mumps, Tb, gonorrhoea, traumatic)
  • Toxins(Drugs,radiation)
  • Primary testicular failure
  • Sertoli cell-only syndrome
  • Oligoasthenoteratozoospermia

Obstruction of efferent duct 

Congenital

  • Youngs syndrome

  • Tuberculosis
  • Gonorrhea

  • Ejaculatory failure
  • Bladder neck surgery
  • Retrograde ejaculation

questions.text: An intern is asked to return a unit of blood which was unused during a surgical procedure to the blood bank. The blood bank staff would accept the blood under all the given conditions except

choices.text: The temperature of the blood pack is +15 °C
There is no sign of hemolysis
The blood has been returned within 30 minutes

questions.solution:
To accept the unit of blood, the temperature of the blood bag should be < +10 °C. If the blood bag temperature is > +10 °C, the blood unit should be discarded.

The criteria to discard the unit of blood when returned back are:

  • Out of refrigerator for > 30 minutes
  • Seal is broken
  • Signs of are hemolysis present
  • Any sign that pack has been opened
  • If the temperature is over > +10 °C

questions.text: The position that you would place the patient posted for surgery for Jeep Disease is
questions.solution:
Jeep Disease is another name of Pilonidal Sinus, which is operated upon in the Jackknife position.  

The jackknife position is also called the Kraske Position. The patient's abdomen lies flat upon the bed which is scissored so the hip is lifted and the legs and head are low.

The sacrococcygeal region is best exposed in the prone jackknife position with the buttocks taped apart. A paramedian longitudinal incision is made over the abscess cavity that is large enough to allow for adequate drainage and removal of all debris and hair

questions.text: A 35 year old farmer from the Himalayan belt presents with multiple nodules and a verrucous lesion in his left leg following a thorn prick a year back. Histopathology of the lesion shows sclerotic bodies. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical findings are suggestive of chromoblastomycosis.  

Chromoblastomycosis is a chronic fungal infection of the skin and subcutaneous tissue often producing a type of verrucous dermatitis.  

It occurs most commonly in humid tropical and subtropical regions  

Infection occurs following the traumatic implantation through the skin of exposed body parts. Lesions usually start as solitary, unilateral papules which may slowly progress to verrucous nodules and plaques and may ulcerate.  

Fonsecaea pedrosoi is the commonest agent of chromoblastomycosis. Other agents include Phialophora verrucosa, Cladophialophora carrionii

Sclerotic bodies, also called medlar bodies are thick-walled, dark brown pigmented, globe-shaped fungal bodies seen in the histopathological specimens. They are pathognomonic for chromoblastomycosis.

questions.text: Which of the following amino acid enters the Krebs cycle by forming succinyl Co-A?
questions.solution:
Valine is a branched chain amino acid that is metabolized to succinyl Co-A, an intermediate of Kreb’s cycle.

 

All or a portion of the carbon skeleton of every amino acid is convertible either to carbohydrate, fat, or both fat and carbohydrate. Based on this, amino acids can be classified as glucogenic or ketogenic or both.

questions.text: The device shown in the given image is used for the monitoring of:
questions.solution:
The given image depicts a pulse oximeter. Pulse oximetry is used for monitoring pulse rate and oxygen saturation of a patient.

A small sensor is placed on the finger, toe, earlobe, or another convenient place.

The relative absorption of light by oxyhemoglobin (HbO) and deoxyhemoglobin is assessed by measuring the amount of red and infrared light emerging from tissues traversed by light rays and processed by the device, producing an oxygen saturation level.

Pulse oximetry does not measure the absolute content or the partial pressures of oxygen or carbon dioxide.

questions.text: The structure marked by the arrow in the given image is:
questions.solution:
The arrow in the given image shows the Trochlear nerve. It is identified easily as it is the only cranial nerve to emerge from the dorsal surface of the brainstem.

Trochlear nerve:

  • Thinnest/smallest cranial nerve
  • Only cranial nerve with Dorsal exit
  • emerges from the midbrain and passes onto the crus of the cerebral peduncle on its lateral surface.
  • Longest intracranial course

questions.text: Failure to produce discoloration of skin on injection of yellowish green fluorescein dye is a feature of__________________
questions.solution:
Failure to produce discoloration of skin on injection of yellowish green fluorescein dye is a feature of Icard’s Test. It is one of the tests used to confirm the cessation of circulation.

Tests for confirming cessation of circulation:

No audible heart sounds on continuous auscultation on the precordial area of the chest for a minimum of 5 minutes and a flat ECG recording for 5 minutes.

Other tests:

  • Magnus’s test (Ligature test)—fingers fail to show congestion distal to a ligature applied at their base.
  • Diaphanous test (Transillumination test)—Failure to show redness in the web space between the fingers on transillumination from behind.
  • Icard’s test — fluorescent dye on being injected at a given site in a dead body fails to produce any discoloration.
  • Fingernail test — no blanching and filling of blood in the fingernail on the application of pressure and release.

Tests for confirming cessation of breathing:

No audible breath sounds on continuous auscultation of the upper part of the chest and in front of or on the larynx for a minimum of 5 minutes, confirms cessation of breathing.

 Other tests:

  • Feather test – no movement of a feather held in front of the nose.
  • Mirror test – a mirror held in front of the nose does not turn dim due to any moisture of breath.
  • Winslow’s test – no movement of the surface of the water in a bowl kept on the chest.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man develops thick yellowish discharge from his urethra 2 weeks after an unprotected sexual encounter. Which of the following is the recommended diagnostic test?
questions.solution:
Chlamydial urethritis is the likely diagnosis in this patient as it has an incubation period of 1-3 weeks. Nucleic acid amplification test (NAAT) is the only diagnostic test recommended for detecting Chlamydia.

The samples used are:

  • Men - first void urine 
  • Women - vaginal or endocervical swabs

NAAT can only detect Chlamydia species, but cannot differentiate between LGV and non-LGV types. Genotyping of Chlamydia‐positive samples is needed to specifically diagnose LGV infection.

Serology, cell culture, and microscopy have no role in routine screening or diagnosis.

questions.text: The capsular types of Staphylococcus aureus that are commonly associated with human infections are:
questions.solution:
Most human Staphylococcus aureus infections are due to capsular types 5 and 8.  

The polysaccharide microcapsule has antiphagocytic properties. The capsule is a zwitterion and plays a crucial role in abscess formation.    

Note:

S. aureus has capacity for intracellular survival in phagocytes and PMNs. Intracellular environment favors the phenotypic expression of small colony variants.

questions.text: All of the following are true about FDG-18 PET CT except:

choices.text: Gold standard for assessment of myocardial viability
Poor FDG uptake in areas of compromised circulation
18 fluorodeoxyglucose has a half life of 110 minutes
Identifies areas of hibernating myocardium also

questions.solution:
FDG-18 PET CT shows enhanced, not decreased/poor FDG uptake in regions of decreased perfusion.

(FDG-18 PET CT - Fluorodeoxyglucose Positron Emission Tomography-Computed Tomography)  

This is because with reduced myocardial blood flow and ischemia substrate utilization shifts from fatty acids and lactate towards glucose causing enhanced myocardial FDG uptake.    

Also, FDG PET CT has the ability to pick up even ischemic or hibernating myocardium that is likely to improve in function after revascularization.

questions.text: Which of the following is not considered a suitable home available fluid?
questions.solution:
Weak unsweetened tea is a suitable home available fluid, not sweetened tea.

Sweetening raises the osmolality of the solution making it unsuitable.

Suitable Fluids: 

  • Plain water
  • Rice water(salted and unsalted)
  • Vegetable/chicken soup
  • Yogurt
  • Tender coconut water
  • Weak unsweetened Tea
  • Unsweetened fresh juices  

Unsuitable Fluids:

  • Commercial carbonated beverages
  • Commercial fruit juices
  • Sweetened tea
  • Sweetened fresh juices

questions.text: A 12 year old girl presents to the emergency department after sustaining electrical burn injuries of 10% total body surface area. Her bodyweight is 40 kg. What is the amount of fluid that must be administered within the first 8 hours after burn injury?
questions.solution:
In electrical injuries, adjusted fluid rates are given at a rate of 4ml LR x kg x %TBSA until urine clears.

The calculated fluid volume is initiated in the following manner: (a 40-kg girl with 10% TBSA burns requires 4 × 40 × 10 = 1,600 mL in 24 hours).

One-half of that volume (800 mL) should be provided in the first 8 hours.

The remaining one-half of the total fluid is administered during the subsequent 16 hours.

In electric injury, the current enters at one point and then leaves the body at an exit point, usually to the earth or the neutral conductor of the electricity supply. It tends to take the shortest route between entry and best exit, irrespective of the varying conductivity of different internal tissues.

When a hand is brought into contact with a live conductor, and the body is earthed either through the feet or the opposite hand, the most common passage of current is across the heart.

It has been claimed that the most dangerous current path is contacted with the right hand and exit through the left foot, as this causes the maximum (up to 8.5 percent) of the total body current to flow through the heart when compared with head to feet (up to 5.9 percent), left hand to feet (up to 5.1 percent), hand to hand (up to 4.4 percent) or foot to foot (up to 0.4 percent)

Direct current (d.c.) is less dangerous than alternating current (a.c.). Most deaths from electricity are from cardiac arrhythmias, usually, ventricular fibrillation ending in cardiac arrest.

Related Pearl: Burns – Formulae for Fluid Calculation(Updated according to ATLS 10th edition 2018 guidelines)

Parkland’s formula gives the total fluid requirement for 24hours. Half of this volume is infused in the first 8 hours, and the remaining half is infused in the next 16 hours.

This formula is recommended for those who have sustained large deep partial-thickness or full-thickness burns that cover more than 20% of the TBSA in adults and more than 10% in children. 

Formulas provide a starting target rate; Subsequently, the amount of fluid provided should be adjusted based on urine output.

Category of burn Age Amount of Ringer’s Lactate given for 24 hours (ml) Target urine output (ml/kg/hour)
2nd/3rd-degree burns Adults  2 x weight in kgs x % TBSA 0.5
<14 years 3 x weight in kgs x % TBSA 1
< 1 year or <30kgs 3 x weight in kgs x % TBSA + 5% dextrose on a maintenance rate 1
4th-degree burns / Electrical burns All ages 4 x weight in kgs x % TBSA 1-1.5 (until urine clears)

Dextrose maintenance:

  • 100 ml/ kg in 24 hours for 10 kg
  • 50 ml/kg for next 10 kg
  • 20 ml/kg for every kg after 20 kg

Evan’s formula is used for normal saline.

For the first 24 hours:

  • Amount of NS administered = weight in kgs x % TBSA
  • Amount of colloid administered = weight in kgs x % TBSA
  • 5% Dextrose administered= 2000 ml

After 24 hours, the amount of NS and colloid administered is half. 2000 ml of dextrose is maintained.

Muir and Barclay’s formula for colloids:

  • 1 portion of colloid = (weight in kgs x % TBSA)/2
  • 6 portions of colloid are administered over 36 hours

questions.text: You place a cell that is equilibrated at 160 mOsm solution, in a solution containing 70 mmol of NaCl and 50 mmol of Urea (Urea is membrane permeable). The change you would expect is:

choices.text: Cell shrinkage followed by cell swelling to original size eventually
Cell swelling followed by cell shrinking to original size eventually

questions.solution:
The cell shrinks followed by the cell swelling to original size.

 

Step 1:

It is given that the cell is equilibrated in a solution at 160 mOsm. Let us assume this as 'solution A'.

Equilibrated means that concentration of both the intracellular fluid and the solution are 160 mOsm.

As long as the cell is in 'solution A' it neither shrinks nor swells.

 

Step 2:

The cell is now placed in another solution. Let us assume this as 'solution B'.

It is given that the concentration of NaCl and urea in solution B are 70 mmol and 50 mmol respectively. We need to convert mmol to mOsm, and add them to find the osmolality of solution B.

Osmolal concentration = molar concentration X no. of freely moving particles liberated by a molecule.

  • NaCl is an ionizable solute. Each molecule of NaCl liberates two ions (one Na+ ion and one Cl- ion). Hence Osmolal concentration of NaCl = 70 mmol X 2 = 140 mOsm.
  • Urea is non ionizable. Hence, osmolal concentration of urea = 50 mmol X 1 = 50 mOsm.

∴ Osmolal concentration of solution B is 140 mOsm + 50 mOsm = 190 mOsm.

 

Step 3:

The solution B (190 mOsm) is hyperosmolal compared to intracellular fluid (160 mOsm).

When the cell is placed in solution B, the water moves from hyposmolal region (intracellular) to the hyperosmolal solution, therefore the cell initially shrinks.

However, since urea is membrane permeable, it slowly moves into the cell until the osmolality of both the intracellular fluid and the solution becomes equal.

As the urea moves in, the osmolal concentration inside the cell rises, and the water moves back into the cell. Thus the cell returns to its original size.

questions.text: Section 376D of the IPC deals with_______

choices.text: Rape by a person in authority

questions.solution:
Section 376D deals with Gang Rape. It is a cognizable, non-bailable offense.  

The punishment is rigorous imprisonment for not less than 20 years but which may extend to imprisonment for life which shall mean imprisonment for the remainder of that person's natural life and a fine to be paid to the victim.    

376DA deals with Gang rape on a woman under sixteen years of age 376DB deals with Gang rape on a woman under twelve years of age.

questions.text: You treat a patient suffering from Non-Hodgkin Lymphoma with IV cyclophosphamide. The drug is present in a vial in powdered form. The drug is to be given as IV infusion after restitution with normal saline. After the infusion, you decide to discard the waste. Which of the following is true about disposal?

choices.text: The glass vial is to be discarded in puncture proof blue box
Mask worn by you is considered general waste
Discard the plastic saline bottle in non-chlorinated yellow plastic bag
Unused drug to be discarded in cytotoxic labelled white bag

questions.solution:
Cyclophosphamide is a cytotoxic drug. All cytotoxic drugs and items contaminated by it (including glass vials, ampoules, saline bottles) should be collected in yellow-colored non-chlorinated plastic bags labeled as cytotoxic hazard.

Option A: All glassware except those contaminated by cytotoxic drugs to be disposed of in puncture-proof, leak-proof blue box.

Option B: Mask and gowns (biochemical waste) which are reusable should be discarded in yellow-colored non-chlorinated plastic bags.

Option D: White translucent, puncture-proof, leak-proof, tamper-proof container to be used for discarding waste sharps.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presented to the gynecology OPD with a history of abdominal pain and distension of abdomen. Ultrasound imaging revealed tumor in the right ovary. Serum level of inhibin was raised. The histopathology of the tumor is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and histopathology showing Call-Exner bodies are suggestive of granulosa cell tumor.

Call-Exner bodies are small, distinctive, glandlike structures filled with an acidophilic material resembling immature follicles. Additionally, small, cuboidal to polygonal cells are seen which may grow in anastomosing cords, sheets, or strands. 

Granulosa cell tumors are composed of cells that resemble granulosa cells of a developing ovarian follicle. It can be of adult and juvenile types. Elevated tissue and serum levels of inhibin, a product of granulosa cells, are associated with this tumor.

Mutations of the FOXL2 gene are seen in most adult granulosa cell tumors.

questions.text: The micrograph of a section of a diseased liver, stained with Masson’s Trichrome stain,  is given below.  The arrow points to:
questions.solution:
The arrow in the above micrograph of the diseased liver points to areas of fibrosis containing collagen that is stained blue by Masson’s trichrome stain.

questions.text: Massive Transfusion is defined as

choices.text: > 8 units of packed RBCs within the first 24hrs
> 8 units of packed RBCs within the first 12hrs

questions.solution:
Massive transfusion, most often defined as more than 4 units of RBCs in 1 hour or > 10 units of RBCs within the first 24 hours of admission.

It is indicated in Class IV(severe) blood loss, where >40% of blood loss has occurred. Early administration of pRBCs, plasma, and platelets in a balanced ratio to minimize excessive crystalloid administration may improve patient survival.

Simultaneous efforts to rapidly control bleeding and reduce the detrimental effects of coagulopathy, hypothermia, and acidosis in these patients are extremely important.

Related Pearl: Complications of a Massive Transfusion

Massive transfusion (MT) is defined as the replacement by transfusion of 10 units of pRBCs in 24 hours or more than 4 units of pRBCs in one hour.

Complications from massive transfusion include:

Complication Mechanism
Hypothermia As blood products are normally stored between 1°C and 6°C
Coagulopathy

MT with PRBCs alone causes a dilutional coagulopathy (vs consumptive coagulopathy caused by massive hemorrhage)

Can be prevented by starting early transfusion of FFP, platelets, pRBCs in a 1:1:1 ratio
Acidosis/ Alkalosis

Mild acidosis - increased CO2 levels in stored blood by 21-35 days

Metabolic alkalosis - citrate gets metabolized to bicarbonate

Metabolic acidosis - due to tissue hypoperfusion
Hyperkalemia/ Hypokalemia

Initially - Hyperkalemia, as stored blood has high K+ levels due to inactivated Na/K/ATPase pump

Later - Hypokalemia, due to intracellular potassium uptake and metabolic alkalosis
Hypocalcemia Stored blood is anticoagulated with citrate, which binds calcium.
Hypomagnesemia Infusion of large volumes of magnesium-poor fluids and binding of magnesium to citrate
Impaired O2-carrying capacity of hemoglobin Decreased 2, 3 DPG
Volume overload Due to massive transfusion

questions.text: An old man who was lying on the roadside is brought to the causalty by the police. On detailed history, he reveals that he has had no food for the past few weeks. On examination, he is severely emaciated. What is the likely finding in the gall bladder?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario points to starvation. In this condition, the gall bladder is distended.

In starvation, bile does not get secreted into the duodenum due to the absence of food entering the stomach and intestine. Hence, bile gets accumulated in the gall bladder which gets distended.

The feeling of intense hunger lasts for 30–48 hours. A person can survive for 10–12 days without food and water and for 6–8 weeks without food alone. 

Loss of 40% of body weight is usually fatal. Loss of 70–90% of body fat and 20% of body protein is fatal. There is a reduction in the weight and size of all organs except the brain.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man was brought to the clinic in an agitated state. When asked how he is feeling, he replies, ‘’I am wonderful, the most wonderful in the universe. The universal gym is my invention, but Jim is just dandy. Dandy was the name of my dad’s friend. A friend in need is a friend indeed. I need a beautiful girlfriend to have dinner with today. Yesterday I had Mexican food for dinner….’’.  What is this phenomenon known as?
questions.solution:
Flight of ideas best conceptualizes the given phenomenon as the individual parts of the speech (or thought) are logically connected by subtle association.

Related Pearl: Disorders of thought and perception

DISORDERS OF THOUGHT

DISORDER OF STREAM OF THOUGHT

(A) Disorder of tempo

(i) Flight of Ideas

Continuous flow of rapid speech that jumps from topic to topic

  • "I like mangoes, the weather is nice, India is great"

(ii) Retardation of thinking

Slow speed of speech and a prolonged latent period before a response

  • "I went to the market (pause)......... the shop was closed"

(iii) Circumstantialities

Inclusion of irrelevant details and going on in a roundabout manner, but their thought ultimately reaches the answer

  • Doctor: "How did you get that bruise?"

  • Patient: "I woke up and had a cup of coffee, read the newspaper and went for a walk. It was a wonderful day in the park. I returned home and watched the TV. I took a nap in the afternoon after lunch. I slipped and fell in the bathroom. The fall gave me this bruise."

(iv) Clang associations

Jumping from one word to another irrelevant rhyming word

  • I am Sam...I like jam...I travel in a tram"

(B) Disorder of continuity

(i) Perseveration

Repetition of out of context words, phrases, or ideas beyond the point of relevance.

  • Q1. What's your name?: "Rahul"

  • Q2. Where are you from?: "Rahul"

  • Q3. How old are you?: "Rahul"

(ii) Thought blocking

A sudden disruption of thought or a break in the flow of ideas

  • "I went to the market (extreme silence)...................."

DISORDER OF FORM OF THOUGHT

(i) Tangentiality

In response to a question, the patient gives a reply that is appropriate to the general topic but does not answer the question exactly. The speech moves away from the actual answer.

  • Doctor: "Have you had any trouble sleeping lately?"
  • Patient: "I usually sleep in my bed, but now I'm sleeping on the sofa"

(ii) Derailment

A breakdown in both the logical connection between ideas and the overall sense of goal-directedness. The words make sentences, but the sentences do not make sense.

  • "Some people just don't understand why I had breakfast in America during the first world war"

(iii) Neologisms

Bringing in new words that do not exist.

  • The world is not 'gooder' for people like me"

(iv) Desultory thoughts

Speech is grammatically correct, however, sudden unrelated ideas force their way in from time to time.

  • My actual problem is that the people never understand me and my stomach feels like an empty bucket"

(v) Word salad

Using a mixture of unintelligible meaningless words and sentences

  • Tree bus rain food home car tiger"

DISORDER OF POSSESSION OF THOUGHT
A. Thought alienation

(i) Thought insertion

Thoughts are being inserted into the patient's mind and they recognize them as being foreign and coming from without any stimulus

  • "I have repeated thoughts of killing my neighbors and I believe aliens are putting these ideas into my head at night"

(ii) Thought withdrawal

Delusion that someone or something is removing from one's mind and the patient has no power over this.

  • "Lately, I am losing all my memories and I believe that the 'government agents' are stealing them when I go to sleep"

(iii) Thought broadcasting

Belief that one's thoughts are quietly escaping from one's mind and that other people might be able to access them and hear or see them.

  • "I believe my exact thoughts appear on the TV and the internet and I think I can broadcast them globally" 

(iv) Thought echo

Patient hears the 'echo' of his own thoughts in the form of a voice after he has made the thought.

  • "I thought of making a sandwich in the morning and surprisingly a voice, from nowhere, told me to make a sandwich out loud" 

 B. Obsessions and Compulsions

1. Obsessions

Recurrent and persistent thoughts, impulses. or images that cause distress to oneself.

  • Fear of dirt or contamination
  • Fear of becoming ill
  • Constant thoughts of a certain number
  • Need for symmetry or exactness
  • Worry about whether something has been done "right"
  • Forbidden sexual or religious thoughts

2. Compulsions

Repetitive behaviors or actions that the person feels driven to perform in response to an obsession

  • Washing hands
  • Blinking eyes
  • Counting items, such as currency
  • Checking to see if doors are locked
  • Arranging items in a certain way
  • Requiring constant approval from people around them

 
 DISORDER OF CONTENT OF THOUGHT

(i) Phobias

Persistent fear of an object or situation, typically disproportional to the actual danger posed, in which the sufferer goes to great lengths in avoiding it

  • Arachnophobia - fear of spider
  • Barophobia - fear of gravity
  • Cynophobia - fear of dogs
  • Hemophobia - fear of blood
  • Nosocomephobia - fear of hospitals

(ii) Religious preoccupations

Thoughts involving religious themes or subject matter.

  • "I get instructions from God on how to make my country great"

(iii) Ideas of hopelessness

Thoughts of complete despair where the patient strongly believes that the circumstances will never get better for him.

  • "I am never going to pass my final exams, no matter how hard I study"

(iv) Antisocial urges

Thoughts of indulging in some behaviors or actions that harm or lack consideration for the well being of others.

  • "I have these urges to go rob a bank or blackmail my neighbors for their money"

(v) Delusions

False beliefs that are strongly held and unchangeable in the face of refuting evidence and that are not consistent with the person's educational, social and cultural background.

The three main criteria for a belief to be considered a delusion are:

  • Certainty (held with complete confidence)
  • Incorrigibility (not changeable by proof to the contrary)
  • Impossibility or falsity of content (implausible, bizarre or patently untrue)
 DISORDERS OF PERCEPTIONS

  • Illusion: Misinterpretation of real external stimuli.

  • Hallucination: False sensory perception, externally.

  • Pseudohallucination: False sensory perception from within and having an insight.

  • Depersonalization: Feeling as if one is disconnected from reality, feeling detached from one's own thoughts and one's own physical body.

    "I sometimes drift into a dream-like state where I lose contact with my own self"

  • Derealization: Alteration in the perception or experience of the external world so that it seems unreal.

    "The world and everything around is nothing but just a dream"

questions.text: Fanconi Bickel syndrome is due to defect in:
questions.solution:
Fanconi Bickel syndrome is due to defect in GLUT 2(Glucose Transporter 2) causing Glycogen Storage Disorder Type XI.  

It occurs due to defect in SLC2A2 gene.

Clinical Features: 

  • Failure to thrive
  • Rickets
  • Hepatomegaly
  • Proximal Renal tubular dysfunction  leading to glucosuria, phosphaturia, generalized aminoaciduria, bicarbonate wasting, and hypophosphatemia
  • Impaired glucose and galactose utilization

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about the condition shown in the image below?

choices.text: This is an image of atypical coloboma
It is rarely seen with CHARGE syndrome
Occurs when optic cleft fails to close during the 4th week of intrauterine life
There is a high risk of retinal detachment.

questions.solution:
There is a high risk of retinal detachment, and prophylactic laser delimitation along the edges of the coloboma is sometimes advocated.  

Colobomas occur when optic cleft fails to close during the 6th week of intrauterine life.  

The most common syndrome found in patients with coloboma is CHARGE syndrome, which occurs in almost 20% of patients with uveal coloboma.

C - Coloboma,

A - choanal Atresia,

R - Retardation of growth and development,

G - Genitourinary problems, and

E - Ear anomalies  

Coloboma occurring in the lower part of the eye is called typical colobomata.

Colobomata of the iris found in other directions are called atypical.
