questions.text: A 52-year-old man was admitted for multiple episodes of seizures following 7 months of neurocognitive decline. He also had weight loss, paranoia, and delusions. Clinical workup revealed HIV infection along with the following findings on MRI. What is the ideal timing of steroid therapy in this condition?

choices.text: Just before obtaining the sample for a biopsy
There is no specific ideal timing

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of primary CNS lymphoma (PCNSL). In this condition, glucocorticoids should be administered only after a biopsy has been obtained. This is because steroids have a cytolytic effect on lymphoma cells and hence may lead to nondiagnostic tissue.  

On CT, PCNSL is identified as a hyperdense enhancing supratentorial mass. On MRI, vivid homogeneous enhancement, as well as restricted diffusion, is seen. 

PCNSL is a type of non-Hodgkin's lymphoma. The workup usually includes:

  • HIV testing
  • CSF analysis
  • MRI spine 
  • PET/CT to assess the extent of the disease
  • Bone marrow biopsy

World AIDS Vaccine Day, also known as HIV Vaccine Awareness Day, is observed annually on May 18. HIV vaccine advocates mark the day by promoting the continued urgent need for a vaccine to prevent HIV infection and AIDS.

Related Pearl: AIDS-defining opportunistic infections and neoplasm

Infections:

  • Protozoal and helminthic infections-
    • Cryptosporidiosis or Isosporiasis (cystoisosporiasis) - Chronic intestinal
    • Toxoplasmosis (pneumonia or CNS infection)
  • Fungal infections-
    • Candidiasis (esophageal, tracheal, or pulmonary)
    • Cryptococcosis (CNS infection)
    • Coccidioidomycosis (disseminated)
    • Pneumocystosis (pneumonia or disseminated infection)
    • Histoplasmosis (disseminated)
  • Bacterial infections-
    • Mycobacteriosis (“atypical,” e.g., Mycobacterium avium-intracellulare) disseminated or extrapulmonary
    • Mycobacterium tuberculosis (pulmonary or extrapulmonary)
    • Nocardiosis (pneumonia, meningitis, disseminated)
    • Salmonella infections, disseminated
  • Viral infections-
    • Cytomegalovirus (pulmonary, intestinal, retinitis, or CNS infections)
    • Herpes simplex virus (localized or disseminated infection)
    • Varicella-zoster virus (localized or disseminated infection)
    • Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy

Neoplasms:

  • Kaposi sarcoma
  • Primary lymphoma of brain
  • Invasive cancer of uterine cervix

questions.text: The chest x-ray of a patient reveals the presence of garland triad. You would not expect the involvement of which of the following structures in his gallium 67 scan?
questions.solution:
Left Paratracheal nodes are not involved.

Garland triad in the chest x-ray is a sign of sarcoidosis. It is also called 1,2,3 sign/ Pawnbroker Sign.

It causes involvement of Left and Right hilar nodes along with Right Paratracheal(not left) paratracheal nodes.

On performing a gallium 67 scan in this patient involvement of the same 3 group of nodes, right and left hilar with right paratracheal will be seen, producing a lambda pattern. So, this is called Lambda sign.

questions.text: Outpatient prophylaxis of a patient with an SVT is best accomplished with the administration of
questions.solution:
Outpatient prophylaxis of a patient with an SVT is best accomplished by administering diltiazem - Ca2+ channel blocker. It is a class IV anti arrhythmic drug.

Supraventricular tachycardias (SVTs) are treated effectively by class II and class IV antiarrhythmics.

In addition, adenosine is indicated for SVTs and nodal tachycardias but only acutely since it must be administered IV and has an extremely short duration.

The primary actions of both beta blockers (esmolol) and CCBs (diltiazem) are at the AV node, but esmolol is too short-acting to be useful as prophylaxis.

Mexiletine is a class IB drug that is used in ventricular arrhythmias.

questions.text: A patient presents with sudden onset of massive, painless, recurrent hematemesis with hypotension. Endoscopy shows the following lesion in the stomach. Histologic section shows a tortuous artery in the submucosa. On angiography the ectatic artery is commonly found in the distribution of?
questions.solution:
Sudden hematemesis with the presence of a dilated tortuous artery in the submucosa in the stomach is indicative of Dieulafoy’s lesion.

On angiography the ectatic artery is commonly found  in the distribution of left gastric artery.

Dieulafoy's lesion is aberrant vessel in mucosa that bleeds from a mucosal defect.Occurs 6-10 cm from GE junction ,generally in fundus near cardia along lesser curvature.

Clinical features:

  • Sudden onset of massive,painless ,recurrent hematemesis with hypotension.
  • recurrent bleeding with spontaneous cessation is common.

Treatment:

  • Intial attempts at endoscopic control are often successful 
  • Application of thermal or sclerosant therapy is effective in 80-100% of cases.
  • Endoscopic therapy failure ,angiographic coil embolization can be successful.
  • When other modalities have failed,Gastric wedge resection to include the offending vessel is reserved.

Dieulafoy’s lesion also occurs in

  • Stomach – 71%
  • Duodenum – 15%
  • Oesophagus – 8%
  • Rectum – 2%
  • Colon – 2%

questions.text: A 22-year-old female patient presents with fever and hypotension. Erythroderma and conjunctival hyperemia is also present. She gives a history of tampon usage which leads you to diagnose her with Staphylococcal Toxic Shock Syndrome(TSS). If it is the menstrual TSS, then the correct conclusion would be

choices.text: Onset is 1 day after the start of menstruation
Onset is on the day of menstruation
Onset is 2-3 days after the start of menstruation
Onset is after the 5th day of menstruation

questions.solution:
The menstrual TSS (Toxic Shock Syndrome) has an onset 2-3 days after the start of menstruation  

Case Definition of S. aureus Toxic Shock Syndrome   

  1. Fever: temperature of ≥38.9C ( ≥102F)
  2. Hypotension: systolic blood pressure of ≤90 mmHg
  3. Diffuse macular rash, with desquamation 1–2 weeks after onset (including the palms and soles)
  4. Multisystem involvement
    a. Hepatic: bilirubin or aminotransferase levels ≥2 times normal
    b. Hematologic: platelet count ≤100,000/μL
    c. Renal: blood urea nitrogen or serum creatinine level ≥2 times the normal upper limit
    d. Mucous membranes: vaginal, oropharyngeal, or conjunctival Hyperemia
    e. Gastrointestinal: vomiting or diarrhea at onset of illness
    f. Muscular: severe myalgias or serum creatine phosphokinase level ≥2 times the normal upper limit
    g. Central nervous system: disorientation or alteration in consciousness without focal neurologic signs and in the absence of fever and hypotension
  5. Negative serologic or other tests for measles, leptospirosis, and Rocky Mountain spotted fever as well as negative blood or cerebrospinal fluid cultures for organisms other than S. aureus

questions.text: Which lymph nodes are considered always pathological when they are palpable?
questions.solution:
Palpable epitrochlear nodes are considered always pathological.

Head and neck lymphadenopathy is seen in 55% of patients, inguinal is seen in 14% of patients, and axillary lymphadenopathy is seen in 5% patients and the significance of these is varied.

questions.text: The peripheral smear of a patient diagnosed with multiple myeloma is shown below. What does the marked structure contain?
questions.solution:
The given image shows a Mott cell which is a plasma cell with globular cytoplasmic inclusions containing immunoglobulins called Russell bodies.

Inclusions containing Ig are frequently seen in the cytoplasm (Russell bodies) or the nucleus (Dutcher bodies) of some of the plasma cells in myeloma.

Related Pearl: Pathological Cells/Bodies in Multiple Myeloma

  • Dutcher bodies - pale-staining, PAS-positive intranuclear inclusions within plasma cells containing Ig, which are more common in IgA myeloma (Image below). 

Russell bodies - They are globular intracellular accumulations of immunoglobulins (Ig). Russell bodies are distended endoplasmic reticulum. Plasma cells filled with multiple Russell bodies are called Mott cells.

  • Flame cells - Plasma cells with fiery red cytoplasm due to vermillion-staining, glycogen-rich IgA in cytoplasmic projections

questions.text: Patients taking which of the following drugs should be advised to avoid drinking grapefruit juice?
questions.solution:
Patients taking Atorvastatin should be advised to avoid drinking grapefruit juice. It is because, grapefruit juice inhibits CYP3A4 in the liver, particularly at high doses, leading to decreased drug elimination via hepatic metabolism and can increase potential drug toxicities. Atorvastatin is metabolized via this pathway.

Other options:

  • Aspirin is cleared via renal mechanisms.
  • Pravastatin is not metabolized to any appreciable extent by the CYP system and is excreted unchanged in the urine. However, other HMG-CoA reductase inhibitors like lovastatin, simvastatin are metabolized via CYP3A4.
  • Losartan is metabolized by CYP2C9.

Related Pearl: Difference between microsomal and non microsomal enzymes:

  Microsomal enzymes Non microsomal enzymes
Location Smooth endoplasmic reticulum (a system of microtubules inside the cell), primarily in liver, also in kidney, intestinal mucosa and lungs Cytoplasm and mitochondria of hepatic cells as well as in other tissues including plasma.
Reactions catalysed Most of the oxidations, reductions, hydrolysis and glucuronide conjugation. Some oxidations and reductions, many hydrolytic reactions and all conjugations except glucuronidation.
Induction Microsomal enzymes are inducible by drugs, diet and other agencies. Not inducible
Examples Monooxygenases, cytochrome P450, UGTs,epoxide hydrolases, etc Esterases, amidases, some flavoprotein oxidasesand most conjugases

questions.text: Which of the following statement is true regarding the organism that most commonly causes the condition given in the image ?

choices.text: It is a gram positive cocci which shows α hemolytic activity
M protein is the virulence factor

questions.solution:
The image given above shows acute paronychia, which is most commonly caused by Staphylococcus aureus.

Staphylococcus aureus produces both coagulase and clumping factor.  

Coagulase, an enzyme-like protein, is produced extracellularly that clots oxalated or citrated plasma. Coagulase binds to prothrombin, together, they become enzymatically active and initiate fibrin polymerization.  

The clumping factor is cell wall-bound and is an example of MSCRAMM - microbial surface components recognizing adhesive matrix molecules. It is responsible for the adherence of the organisms to fibrinogen and fibrin. When mixed with plasma, S aureus forms clumps. The clumping factor is distinct from coagulase. Because the clumping factor induces a strong immunogenic response in the host, it has been the focus of vaccine efforts.

Other options:

Option A:  Staphylococcus Aureus is a gram-positive cocci that shows β-hemolytic activity with a clear area surrounding the colony on blood agar. 

Option B: Staph aureus ferments mannitol, which distinguishes it from other subspecies. Mannitol-salt agar is a commonly used screening device for S. aureus. Staphylococcus aureus ferments mannitol, which lowers the pH, causing the agar to turn yellow, whereas S. epidermidis does not ferment mannitol, and the agar remains pink.

Option C:  Protein A is an important virulence factor of Staph. aureus. Whereas M protein is the important virulence factor of Streptococcus pyogenes, which blocks phagocytosis.

questions.text: While examining a newborn, you notice the newborn holds onto your finger as shown in the image. Which of the following is incorrect regarding the involved reflex?

choices.text: It is strongly present after 32 weeks of gestation
It is prominent upto 6 months of life
This allows lifting of baby at 37 weeks of gestation

questions.solution:
Palmar grasp is prominent until 2-3 months of life.

It becomes less prominent after 3 months of life when voluntary grasping develops.  

Palmar grasp is clearly present at 28 weeks of gestation and is fully developed by 32 weeks of gestation. Palmar Grasp reflex allows lifting of the baby at 37 weeks of gestation.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a diagnostic indication of TRUS (TRUS - Transrectal Ultrasound)?
questions.solution:
Prostatic abscess aspiration is a therapeutic, not diagnostic indication of TRUS

Sextant protocol or Modified sextant protocol is used for TRUS guided prostate biopsy.

questions.text: Which among the following is a cell cycle independent anti-cancer drug?
questions.solution:
Cisplatin is a cell cycle independent anti-cancer drug.

Its mode of action has been linked to its ability to crosslink with the purine bases on the DNA, interfering with DNA repair mechanisms, causing DNA damage, and subsequently inducing apoptosis in cancer cells.

It is used in the treatment of testicular, bladder, ovary, and lung carcinomas. However, there are incidences of drug resistance and numerous undesirable side effects such as:

  • Severe kidney injury
  • Hearing loss especially in younger patients 
  • Decrease immunity to infections
  • Marked emesis
  • Electrolyte disturbances like hypocalcemia, hypomagnesemia, hypokalemia, hypophosphatemia
  • Allergic reactions

Hence, other platinum-containing anti-cancer drugs such as carboplatin, oxaliplatin have been used.

Other options:

Option B- Vinblastin is an M phase-specific anti-cancer drug. Vinca alkaloids bind β-tubulin and inhibit its polymerization into microtubules → prevents mitotic spindle formation.

Option C- Cladribine is an S phase-specific anti-cancer drug. It is incorporated into DNA where it produces DNA strand breaks and depletion of NAD and ATP, leading to apoptosis. Also, it is a potent inhibitor of ribonucleotide reductase.

Option D- Topotecan is an S phase-specific anticancer drug. It inhibits topoisomerase 1 and prevents DNA unwinding and replication.

questions.text: A 17 year old male patient comes with the complaints of unilateral nasal stuffiness, headache and recurrent epistaxis for the past 4 months. Examination revealed a mass in the nasal cavity. Which of the following is the main vessel commonly involved in bleeding in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical finding is suggestive of juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma.  

Internal maxillary artery from external carotid artery is the most common vessel involved in bleeding in JNA.

The average age of presentation of this tumour is 14 years.

It is more common in males which is hypothesised due to androgen dependence of the tumour. JNA originates within the sphenopalatine foramen, and further spreads locally into the pterygopalatine fossa, nasal cavity and paranasal sinuses.

Patients usually present with a triad of

  • Progressive nasal obstruction,
  • Recurrent epistaxis and
  • Mass in the nasal cavity and nasopharynx.

It has potency to cause proptosis, affecting both the orbit and with intracranial extension, eventually leading to cranial nerve palsies and loss of vision.

Angiofibroma can be diagnosed using CT, MRI, and magnetic resonance angiography.

Anterior bowing of the maxillary wall due to presence of a mass in the pterygomaxillary space on CT known as the Holman-Miller sign is a characteristic finding of JNA.

questions.text: The best time for a breast examination is
questions.solution:
Days 5-7 of the cycle are the best time for examination of the breast.  

Generally, in premenopausal women, lesions that are equivocal or nonsuspicious should be reexamined during the follicular phase of the menstrual cycle.    

 

Note:

A palpable mass not visualized on ultrasound must be presumed to be solid as not all solid masses are visualized.  

Related Pearl: Risk Factors and Protective Factors for Breast Carcinoma

Risk factors:

  • Age: Incidence increases with increasing age.
  • Sex: more common in females.
  • Family history of breast cancer
  • Race, ethnicity (white women have increased risk compared to women of other races)
  • History of radiation exposure
  • Mammographically dense breast
  • Genetic factors:
  • Mutations in tumor suppressor genes:
    • BRCA 1
    • BRCA 2
    • TP53
    • CHEK2
  • Hereditary syndromes:
    • Li Fraumeni syndrome
    • Cowden’s syndrome
    • HNPCC syndrome
    • Peutz-Jegher’s syndrome
    • Ataxia telangiectasia
  • Hormonal factors (hyperestrogenemia is the risk factor):
    • Early menarche
    • Late menopause
    • First full-term pregnancy >30 years
    • Nulliparity
    • Obesity (postmenopausal)
  • Higher socioeconomic status, high fat diet, alcohol intake

Protective factors:

  • Early age at first pregnancy
  • Multiparity
  • Breastfeeding
  • Oophorectomy
  • Exercise
  • Tamoxifen and Aromatase inhibitors

questions.text: All of the following are true about blackouts except?

choices.text: The person appears confused to the onlookers.
Remote memory is relatively intact during the blackout.
It is a discrete episode of anterograde amnesia.
It is associated with alcohol intoxication

questions.solution:
During an episode of a blackout, a person’s intellectual faculties (except specific short-term memory) are well preserved and they can perform complicated tasks and appear normal to casual observers.

Blackouts are discrete episodes of antero­grade amnesia that occur in association with alcohol intoxica­tion. They are similar to transient global amnesia. A person has relatively intact remote memory but experiences a specific short-term memory deficit. Alcohol blocks the consolidation of new memories into old memories, a process that is thought to involve the hippocam­pus and related temporal lobe structures. Blackouts occur when blood alcohol concentration reaches 200-300mg/dL.

Safety Profile of medications in pregnancy as classified by the FDA.   

Category  A. Strong evidence of safety based on human studies.

Category  B. Varying and/or contradictory  human and animal data.

Category  C. Shown side effects in animal models, or where inadequate animal and human studies are available.

Category  D. Shown risk to the human fetus.

Category  X. Strong risk of birth defects.

questions.text: Which of the following is disabling hearing loss in adults according to the WHO definition of hearing loss?

choices.text: >40 dB in the worser hearing ear
>50 dB in the worser hearing ear
>40 dB in the better hearing ear
>50 dB in the better hearing ear

questions.solution:
Disabling hearing loss: refers to hearing loss greater than 40 dB in the better hearing ear in adults and greater than 30 dB in the better hearing ear in children.

Grades of hearing loss :
Mild : 26 - 40 dB
Moderate : 41 - 60 dB
Severe : 61 - 80 dB
Profound : >81 dB

questions.text: You are instructed by your senior to suture a wound of midline laparotomy. To reduce the chances of incisional hernia, you will have to

choices.text: Place sutures 1 cm apart and 1cm deep.
Place intra-abdominal drain through a separate incision.

questions.solution:
intra-abdominal drains should be brought out through separate incisions and not through the main incision, as this might lead to hernia formation.

There is no evidence that interrupted sutures are better than continuous if the suturing procedure is done appropriately.

Optimal ratio of suture length to wound length is 4:1 (Jenkin’s rule).

Recent research has also shown that smaller and closer bites taken during suturing leads to reduced incisional hernia and infection rates.

questions.text: The images given below are of indirect immunofluorescence of salt split human skin in various immunobullous diseases. The incorrectly matched pair is
questions.solution:
Linear IgA disease shows an immunofluorescence pattern characteristic of image A, in which linear binding of antibodies is seen in the roof of the artificial split.

The autoantibodies against BP180, BP230, and α6β4 integrin show a linear binding at the roof of the artificial split.
On the other hand, antibodies to laminin 332, laminin gamma-1, p200 antigen, and type VII collagen label the floor of the artificial split.

The corresponding diseases are tabulated below:

Immuno-fluorescence assay Antibodies against Diseases associated
Linear band on Roof of split BP180, BP230 and α6β4 integrin
  • Bullous pemphigoid
  • Mucous membrane pemphigoid
  • Linear IgA disease
  • Pemphigoid gestationis
Linear band on Floor of split Laminin 332, Laminin gamma-1, p200 antigen and Type VII collagen
  • Epidermolysis bullosa acquisita
  • Mucous membrane pemphigoid
  • Anti -p200 pemphigoid

Note: Mucous membrane pemphigoid has antibodies to both BP 180 and Laminin 332 and hence can show both the patterns.

questions.text:
A patient is posted for a non-cardiac surgery. You are requested to assess the patient’s functional capacity in order to reduce his postoperative cardiac complications. 
What is the minimum activity that can be performed by the patient to make him a suitable candidate for major surgery?

choices.text: Daily activities like eating and dressing

questions.solution:
If a patient is able to climb a flight of stairs (>4 METs), they can be considered suitable candidates for major surgery.

One MET (Metabolic Equivalent) is equivalent to the oxygen consumption of an adult at rest(3.5mL/kg/min).

Having <4 METs is considered as poor functional status assessment.

Poor functional capacity is associated with increased cardiac complications in noncardiac surgery

questions.text: Moh’s surgery is done all of the following except?
questions.solution:
Mohs surgery is done in all the given options except in Kaposi’s sarcoma.  

Mohs surgery allows precise microscopic control of the margins.

It is generally indicated for the treatment of tumors in areas where a high risk of recurrence exists, and cosmetic results are critical.

questions.text: A patient presented with a classical finding of pulsus parvus et tardus. Which of the following pressure-volume loops will be associated with this finding?
questions.solution:
Pulsus parvus et tardus (i.e. a weak and late pulse) is classically associated with aortic stenosis. Amongst the given pressure-volume loops, the one that corresponds to aortic stenosis is A.  

In aortic stenosis, as there is high outflow resistance, the pressure gradient across the aortic valve is increased. The stroke volume is also severely decreased as the ventricles are not completely emptied.

The image given below shows pressure-volume loops in various valvular heart disorders.

The pressure-volume curve represents the changes in volume and pressure in the left ventricle during a single cardiac cycle. The relationship between ventricular pressure (Y-axis) and volume (X-axis) throughout the cardiac cycle is represented by this loop.

  • A - Mitral valve opens
  • B - Mitral valve closes
  • C - Aortic valve opens
  • D - Aortic valve closes

Phase I: Period of filling

It begins at a ventricular volume of about 50 ml (end-systolic volume) and a diastolic pressure of 2 to 3 mm Hg. As venous blood flows into the ventricle from the left atrium, the ventricular volume normally increases to about 120 ml (end-diastolic volume) and the diastolic pressure rises to about 5 to 7 mm Hg.

Phase II: Period of isovolumic contraction

The volume of the ventricle does not change because all valves are closed. However, the pressure inside the ventricle increases to equal the pressure in the aorta (80 mm Hg) as depicted by point C.

Phase III: Period of ejection

During ejection, the systolic pressure rises even higher because of still more contraction of the ventricle. At the same time, the volume of the ventricle decreases because the aortic valve has now opened and blood flows out of the ventricle into the aorta.

Phase IV: Period of isovolumic relaxation

At the end of the period of ejection (point D), the aortic valve closes and the ventricular pressure falls back to the diastolic pressure level. This results in a decrease in intraventricular pressure without any change in volume. Thus, the ventricle returns to its starting point, with about 50 ml of blood left in the ventricle and at an atrial pressure of 2 to 3 mm Hg.

The area subtended by this functional volume-pressure diagram (the shaded area, labeled EW) represents the net external work output of the ventricle during its contraction cycle.

The image given below shows a normal pressure-volume loop.

questions.text: Which of the following events is most likely to be due to bacterial conjugation?

choices.text: A strain of Corynebacterium diphtheriae produces a toxin encoded by a prophage.
A strain of Pseudomonas aeruginosa produces β-lactamase encoded by a plasmid similar to a plasmid of another gram negative organism
An encapsulated strain of Streptococcus pneumoniae acquires the gene for capsule formation from an extract of naked DNA from another encapsulated strain.
A gene encoding resistance to gentamicin in the Escherichia coli chromosome appears in the genome of a bacteriophage that has infected E. coli

questions.solution:
A strain of Pseudomonas aeruginosa produces β-lactamase encoded by a plasmid similar to a plasmid of another gram negative organism. This explains the process of gene transfer called conjugation.

Conjugation requires donor cell-to-recipient cell contact to transfer only one strand of DNA. The recipient completes the structure of dsDNA by synthesizing the strand that complements the strand acquired from the donor.


Other options:

An encapsulated strain of Streptococcus pneumoniae acquires the gene for capsule formation from an extract of naked DNA from another encapsulated strain. This explains the process of gene transfer called transformation. It is the direct uptake of naked donor DNA by the recipient cell.

Option (a) and (d) explains the gene transfer process called transduction. In transduction, donor DNA is carried by a phage coat and is transferred into the recipient by the mechanism used for phage infection.

Genes for the following 5 bacterial toxins are encoded in a lysogenic phage (ABCD’S):

  • Group A strep erythrogenic toxin
  • Botulinum toxin
  • Cholera toxin
  • Diphtheria toxin
  • Shiga toxin

questions.text: A 36-year-old female presented with amenorrhea, nausea, and vomiting. She was apprehensive about being pregnant after having unprotected sex. She gave a history of having undergone tubal ligation 8 months ago and admitted having a low mood following it. On examination, her breasts were enlarged with pigmented areola and contained milk. The abdomen was distended and a pigmented line was observed from the umbilicus to the pubis. The urine pregnancy test was negative and the pelvic ultrasound was unremarkable. What would be the next step of management?
questions.solution:
The given history of amenorrhea presently and tubal ligation 8 months ago, clinical findings of breast enlargement and linea nigra, along with a negative pregnancy test point towards a diagnosis of pseudocyesis for which psychotherapy is recommended. 

Pseudocyesis is characterized by the presence of the classic symptoms of pregnancy- amenorrhea, nausea, breast enlarge­ment and pigmentation, abdominal distention, and labor pains, in a nonpregnant woman. It signifies the ability of the psyche (mind) to dominate the soma (body).

A true somatic delusion may be present in the patient but it is usually resolved after a negative urine pregnancy test result or pelvic ultrasound. Predisposing factors like a pathological wish or fear of pregnancy, gender or sexuality-related conflicts, and a history of miscarriage or tubal ligation, are usually present.

Management involves psychotherapy during or after such a presentation, to determine the underlying psychological abnormality and treat it.

Note: Couvade syndrome is a related phenomenon seen in some cultures where the would-be-father undergoes simulated labor. However, in those cultures, couvade is a normal phenomenon.

questions.text: A female patient in normal labor is being administered care with active management of the third stage of labor. What is the dose of misoprostol that you would administer orally for the prevention of postpartum hemorrhage (PPH)?
questions.solution:
600 micrograms of misoprostol administered orally at delivery is effective for the prevention of postpartum hemorrhage (PPH).  

Misoprostol is a synthetic prostaglandin E 1 analog that has been used for the prevention and treatment of uterine atony and PPH.   

Although contrasting evidence about its effectiveness is present, it is to be used at a dose of 600 micrograms when used orally.

Related Pearl: Uses of Misoprostol

INDICATIONS PRIMARY DOSE OF MISOPROSTOL REMARKS

MEDICAL TERMINATION OF PREGNANCY

 

Combined Regimen(recommended):
Upto 12 weeks of gestation-800mcg vaginally, buccally or sublingually.

Beyond 12 weeks of gestation-400mcg vaginally, buccally or sublingually every 3 hours


Misoprostol only regimen:
Upto 12 weeks-800mcg vaginally, buccally or sublingually

Beyond 12 weeks-400mcg vaginally, bucally or sublingually every 3 hours

Ideally used 1-2 days after 200mg of Mifepristone in the combined regimen.


The mucosal route of administration is preferred over the oral route of administration.


These doses also apply for incomplete and missed abortion.

SURGICAL ABORTION

12-14weeks- both medical and surgical methods can be done

>14weeks-surgical method 

 Cervical preparation: 400mcg vaginally/ sublingually

Another method: Oral Mifepristone 200mg 24-48 hours before the procedure

 
PPH Prophylaxis

800mcg sublingual single dose OR 600mcg orally/ sublingually/rectally

single dose for PPH secondary prevention (approx >350ml blood loss)

  Where oxytocin is not available or storage conditions are inadequate
PPH treatment 800 mcg sublingually single dose

questions.text: Immunohistochemistry for HER2 protein expression is performed in 3 patients with breast carcinoma, with the following results. Which of the following patients should be subjected to fluorescence in-situ hybridization?
questions.solution:
The immunohistochemistry (IHC) pattern of patient C reveals moderately strong circumferential staining (faint brown color) in >10 % of cells, which is classified as 2+ or equivocal staining. Hence, she should be subjected to fluorescence in situ hybridization (FISH) to confirm HER2-positive gene amplification status.

The following are classified as HER2-positive tumors:

  • Tumors that show 3+ staining on IHC (here FISH is not needed).
  • Tumors with 2+ staining on IHC, followed by HER2-gene amplification confirmed by FISH

Once HER2-positive status is confirmed, targeted therapy against HER2 can be initiated with trastuzumab or lapatinib. 

Related Pearl: Newer molecular tests in breast cancer

Newer molecular tests for breast cancer have been developed, which help in predicting the advantage of adding chemotherapy. These are:

  • Oncotype Dx (21-geneassay)
  • Mammaprint (70-gene assay)
  • EndoPredict (12-gene assay)
  • PAM50 (50-gene assay)

Oncotype Dx can only be used in hormone (ER, PR) receptor-positive cancers, while mammaprint can be used in both hormone receptor (ER, PR) positive and hormone receptor-negative cancers. 

These tests are used for T1,2 N0 M0 breast cancers – (node-negative, metastasis-negative). Using these molecular tests, a recurrence score (0 – 100) is calculated.

  • If the score is low, then there is no advantage of adding chemotherapy
  • If the score is high, then chemotherapy should be added

questions.text: Which of the following is an advantage of mediolateral episiotomy over a midline episiotomy?
questions.solution:
The primary advantage of mediolateral episiotomy over midline episiotomy is that there is a lesser chance of extension through perineum till anal sphincter. But it is more difficult to repair, and there is an increased risk of blood loss and it shows a less reliable healing.

Characteristic Midline Episiotomy Mediolateral Episiotomy
Surgical Repair Easy More difficult
Healing Better Not as good
Post-op Pain Less More
Anatomical Results Excellent Not as good
Blood Loss Less More
Dyspareunia Rare Occasional
Extensions Common Uncommon

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy presents with right upper quadrant pain and fever. O/E he is icteric. CT reveals the Central Dot sign and HIDA scan shows a Beaded appearance of intrahepatic bile ducts. The probable diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
The Boy is probably suffering from Caroli’s Disease.  

Clinical features of Right upper quadrant pain, fever with the presence of icterus point towards a liver pathology.  

But, the beaded appearance of Intrahepatic bile ducts on HIDA scan and Central Dot sign on CT are characteristic findings associated with Caroli's disease. This effectively rules out the other options.  

Caroli’s Disease is an autosomal recessive condition multifocal cystic dilatation of segmental intrahepatic bile ducts. According to Todani classification, it is classified as a type V choledochal cyst.  

USG may show dilated intrahepatic bile ducts in these individuals.

Related Pearl: Classification of Choledochal Cysts

Type

Feature

Type I

The most common choledochal cyst type; it involves only the extrahepatic biliary tree and is generally a fusiform dilation.

Type II

Saccular diverticulum off the common bile duct and may be mistaken for an accessory gallbladder.

Type III

A cystic dilation of the intramural common bile duct, within the wall of the duodenum, known as choledochoceles.

Type IV

Type IVa: Cysts involving the intrahepatic and extrahepatic biliary tree

Type IVb: Multiple cysts limited to the extrahepatic biliary tree.

Type V

Also known as Caroli disease, involve the intrahepatic ducts only.

questions.text: Acid Citrate Dextrose (ACD), used to store blood, preserves the RBCs for a period of 21 days. The storage period when adding phosphate alone and when adding adenine and phosphate together to ACD would respectively be?
questions.solution:
The storage period when adding phosphate alone to ACD would be 21 days and when adding adenine and phosphate together would be 35 days.

When adding phosphate to ACD, Citrate Phosphate Dextrose (CPD) is formed – It has a storage period of 21 days. There is no change in the shelf life as phosphate only increases the 2,3 DPG levels of the stored blood.

When adding both phosphate and adenine to ACD, Citrate Phosphate Dextrose Adenine (CPDA-1) is formed. It has a storage period of 35 days. It increases the shelf life by improving ATP synthesis of RBCs.

Using additive solutions containing saline, adenine, and glucose, with or without mannitol (SAGM) decreases RBC hemolysis, thus increasing the storage period to 42 days.

Related Pearl: Causes of Increased and Decreased 2,3- DPG

Increase in 2,3-DPG

  • Chronic hypoxia
  • Anemia
  • Acclimatization (high altitude)
  • Thyroid
  • Growth hormone
  • Androgens
  • Exercise

Decrease in 2,3-DPG

  • Blood stored in blood bank
  • Acidosis

NOTE:Because acidosis inhibits red cell glycolysis, the 2,3-DPG concentration falls when the pH is low.

questions.text: The egg shown in the given image is recovered from the perianal region using the scotch tape technique. Identify the parasite.
questions.solution:
The egg shown in the given image is that of Enterobius vermicularis.

The eggs of E. vermicularis are plano-convex in shape, have a double-layered outer shell, and are approximately 50–60 μm in length. Infectious larvae, which are tadpole-shaped, are often visible inside the egg. Unlike those of other intestinal nematodes, these eggs are not found in the stools. The female worm lays eggs in the perianal region.

The eggs are recovered using the scotch tape technique in the morning before a bowel movement. Transparent scotch tape is applied directly to the perianal area and then placed on a microscope slide for examination.

Other options: 

Ascaris lumbricoides eggs are large, broadly oval, with thick mammillated shell, and are typically stained golden brown with bile.

Ancylostoma duodenale eggs are oval and thin-shelled and contain a clearly visible four to eight-cell stage embryo. There is a characteristic clear space between the shell and the developing embryo.

Strongyloides stercoralis eggs hatch within the mucosa of the small intestine forming rhabditiform larvae. These larvae are passed in the stools, not the eggs.

Related Pearl: Eggs in parasitology

Related Pearl: Helminth eggs that float in saturated salt solution

The following are the helminths whose eggs float in a saturated salt solution. (mnemonic: THE FAN)

  • Trichuris trichiura
  • Hymenolepis nana
  • Enterobius vermicularis
  • Fertilized eggs of Ascaris lumbricoides
  • Ancylostoma duodenale
  • Necator americanus.

questions.text: The given image shows the various curves obtained for three different screening tests (A, B, C) employed on a population. Which of the following represents the correct match with respect to the Receiver-Operator-Curve (ROC) obtained in each of them?
questions.solution:
The correct match is A – 2, B – 1, C – 3.

The curves obtained mean the following:

  • A – There are some false negatives and some false positives as shown below. Therefore, the area under the curve is around 0.7 to 0.8. The ROC curve would thus be as shown in Image 2.
  • B – There are almost nil false positives or negatives. The test completely differentiates between healthy and diseased. Thus, the area under the ROC would be close to 0.9 to 1 as shown in Image 1.
  • C – The test does not differentiate between healthy and diseased people at all. The area under the curve for such tests would be 0.5 as represented by Image 3.

Note:

The ROC curve is a fundamental tool for diagnostic test evaluation. In a ROC curve the true positive rate (Sensitivity) is plotted in function of the false positive rate (100-Specificity) for different cut-off points of a parameter. Each point on the ROC curve represents a sensitivity/specificity pair corresponding to a particular decision threshold. The area under the ROC curve (AUC) is a measure of how well a parameter can distinguish between two diagnostic groups (diseased/normal).

questions.text: The spread of Nipah virus which occurred during May 2018 in Kerala was a
questions.solution:
The spread of Nipah virus disease in Kerala has been confirmed by the National Centre for Disease Control to be a local occurrence (not a major outbreak).  

Epidemic refers to an increase, often sudden, in the number of cases of a disease above what is normally expected in that population in that area. Outbreak carries the same definition of epidemic, but is often used for a more limited geographic area.  

Endemic refers to the constant presence and/or usual prevalence of a disease or infectious agent in a population within a geographic area.   

Salient points on Nipah virus disease:  

  • It is an RNA virus which belongs to family Paramyxovidae, genus henipavirus.
  • It is a zoonotic virus.
  • Natural host: Fruit bats of the pteropodidae family
  • Transmission:
    • Animals (bats, pigs) to humans
    • Human-to-human
  • C/F: Asymptomatic infection (subclinical), acute respiratory infection, fatal encephalitis.
  • There is no treatment or vaccine available for either people or animals. The primary treatment for humans is supportive care.
  • Nipah virus is on the WHO list of Blueprint priority diseases.

questions.text: A 19-year-old female patient presents with sore throat, fever and lymphadenopathy. Paul-Bunnell test returns positive. Which of the following is true regarding the image given?

choices.text: B cells infected by the causative organism can be seen
Reactive B cells can be seen
Reactive T cells can be seen
Myelocytes and metamyelocytes can be seen

questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of a teenager with  and a positive Paul-Bunnell test is suggestive of infectious mononucleosis/glandular fever. The peripheral blood smear image shows atypical lymphocytes, also called as Downey Type 2 cells, which are reactive T-cells. 

Epstein-Barr virus (EBV), also called Human Herpesvirus Type 4, is the causative organism for infectious mononucleosis, which is a lymphoproliferative disease transmitted by direct contact, commonly by saliva. 

The virus infects nasopharyngeal epithelial cells, salivary and lymphoid tissues by binding to the CD21 receptors. Latent infection of B cells, induces B-cell mitogenesis and results in the production of atypical reactive EBV specific CD8+ T cells (Downey cells). The B-cells produce antibodies that are reative to horse and sheep erythrocytes, called Heterophile antibodies, which are detected by the Paul-Bunnell or monospot test, which is one of the diagnostic tests for the disease.

Patients present with sore throat, fever, lymphadenopathy and often splenomegaly associated with significant lymphocytosis. The diagnosis is usually based on the presence of atypical lymphocytes, a positive Paul-Bunnell test and positive titres of viral capsid antigen or EB nuclear antigen (EBNA) on ELISA. Early infection induces IgM formation, and later specific IgG which exists for life.

The disease is usually self-limiting and treatment is supportive in nature as in other viral infectious diseases.

Other conditions caused by EBV infection include:

  • Hairy oral leukoplakia
  • Burkitt lymphoma
  • Nasopharyngeal carcinoma
  • Hodgkin and non-Hodgkin lymphoma

questions.text: Which of the following is used for the classification of the endoscopic appearance of bleeding peptic ulcers in a patient with peptic ulcer disease?
questions.solution:
Forrest classification is used for classifying the endoscopic appearance of bleeding peptic ulcers. It stratifies the risk of rebleeding based on observed stigmata of recent hemorrhage. 

Stigmata of Recent Hemorrhage

Forrest Classification

Active Spurting

I A

Active Oozing

I B

Non-bleeding vessel

II A

Adherent Clot

II B

Flat Pigmented Spot

II C

Clean Based Ulcer

III

Forrest classification is clinically very significant as it provides prognostic information to the surgeon about the need for endoscopic therapeutic intervention and the risk of rebleeding.

Option B: The Glasgow–Blatchford bleeding score (GBS) is a screening tool to assess the likelihood that a patient with acute upper gastrointestinal bleeding (UGIB) will need medical intervention such as a blood transfusion or endoscopic intervention. It incorporates the patient’s blood urea level, hemoglobin level, blood pressure, and other clinical parameters.

Option C: Rockall score assesses the risk of rebleeding and in-hospital mortality in patients with an upper GI bleed.

Option D: The Bismuth–Corlette classification system provides an anatomic description of the tumor location and longitudinal extension in the biliary tree.

questions.text: During Pelvic Radiotherapy, the organ that you would expect to be least affected is:
questions.solution:
The order of radiosensitivity of the organs is Ovary>Rectum>Bladder>Vagina.  

The most radiosensitive:

  • Tissue - bone marrow
  • Blood Cell - Lymphocyte
  • Stage of cell - G2-M interphase
  • Cell type - Rapidly dividing cells
  • Ocular structure - Lens
  • Retinal structure - Rods>Cones    

Least Radiosensitive: 

  • Tissue - nervous tissue
  • Blood Cell - platelet
  • Stage of cell -  S phase
  • Cell type - Quiescent cells
  • Ocular structure - Sclera
  • Retinal Layer - Ganglion cell layer  

Interestingly, sebaceous gland function does not recover after radiotherapy.

Related Pearl: Radiosensitive and Radioresistant Tumors

Highly radiosensitive tumors :

  • Lymphoma
  • Seminoma
  • Myeloma
  • Ewing’s sarcoma
  • Wilms tumor

 Highly radioresistant tumors :

  • Melanoma
  • Osteosarcoma
  • Pancreatic carcinoma
  • Hepatic carcinoma
  • Renal cell carcinoma
  • glioblastoma

Related Pearl: Radioprotectors and Radiosensitizers

Radioprotectors:

Radioprotectors are substances that protect normal tissues from the effect of radiation. These include:

  • Zinc oxide
  • Pentoxifylline
  • Estramustine
  • Amifostine
  • Chlorhexidine (radiation-induced stomatitis)
  • Potassium iodide (for thyroid against radioactive iodine)
  • Melatonin
  • Antioxidants

Radiosensitizers:

Radiosensitizers make the tumor more susceptible to the action of radiotherapy. These include:

  • Oxygen
  • Cisplatin
  • 5 FU
  • Gemcitabine
  • Nitroimidazoles

Radiation potentiators:

The following drugs potentiate the action of radiation when used in conjunction: 

  • Doxorubicin
  • Dactinomycin

questions.text: On seeing an X-ray image you notice inferior rib notching (Roesler’s Sign) to be present. The condition you would not suspect in this case is?
questions.solution:
Superior Rib Notching (not Inferior) is seen in Marfan’s Syndrome. Hyperparathyroidism and NF Type 1 cause both superior and inferior rib notching  

Rib notching refers to deformation of superior or inferior surfaces of the rib.  

Conditions causing inferior rib notching:   

  • Conditions causing enlarged collateral vessels like
    • Coarctation of aorta
    • Subclavian artery obstruction - Ex - Takayasu Disease,
    • SVC obstruction
    • TOF - tetralogy of Fallot

Conditions causing superior rib notching  

  • Abnormal Osteoblastic Activity
    • Connective Tissue Diseases
      • Scleroderma
      • Sjogren’s Syndrome
      • Marfan’s Syndrome
      • SLE
      • Rheumatoid Arthritis
  • Osteogenesis Imperfecta  

Conditions causing Superior and inferior rib notching

  • Hyperparathyroidism
  • Neurofibromatosis Type 1

questions.text: A 45-year-old male who is a smoker presents with complaints of gastric reflux for the past 3 months. Endoscopy and biopsy results are as shown in the images given below. Which among the following histopathological images correctly represent the carcinoma which this patient would most likely develop?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is characteristic of Barrett’s esophagus which has the potential to transform into an adenocarcinoma in the future. The slide B correctly represents an adenocarcinoma of esophagus showing tubular glands infiltrating the lamina propria and the squamous epithelium.

The given endoscopy reveals patches of red, velvety mucosa extending upward from the gastroesophageal junction.
The histopathological slide shows the intestinal type mucosa (left) replacing the normal squamous esophageal mucosa.
Hence a diagnosis of Barrett’s esophagus can be confirmed.

Other options:

  • Slide A – Represents a normal squamous esophageal epithelium
  • Slide C – Represents a squamous cell carcinoma of esophagus. On high power, keratin pearls are characteristically seen in SCC.
  • Slide D – Represents a squamous papilloma of the esophagus which is a benign entity.

Related Pearl: The most commons in GIT

Most common Structure/Conditions
Congenital intestinal atresia Imperforate anus
True diverticulum Meckel's diverticulum
Site of ischemia Colon
Site of fistulization Esophagus
Site of GI polyp Colorectum
Malignancy of GI tract Adenocarcinoma colon
Cause of esophagitis Acid reflux
Benign tumor of the esophagus Leiomyoma
Esophageal cancer in India and worldwide Squamous cell carcinoma
Esophageal cancer in Western countries Adenocarcinoma
Type of chronic gastritis Type B gastritis (Helicobacter pylori gastritis)
Malignancy of the stomach Adenocarcinoma
Site of extranodal lymphoma Stomach
Mesenchymal tumor of the stomach Gastrointestinal stromal tumor (GIST)
Tumor of small intestine/appendix Carcinoid

 

Related Pearl: Endoscopic Findings in Esophagitis

 

Conditions Endoscopic findings
Infectious esophagitis Diffuse and involve the proximal esophagus  
HSV esophagitis Vesicles and small punched-out lesions (volcano ulcers)
CMV esophagitis Serpiginous ulcers
Peptic esophagitis Solitary and distal  
Eosinophilic esophagitis Multiple esophageal rings, linear furrows, or white punctate exudates (feline esophagus)
Pill esophagitis Singular and deep at points of luminal narrowing with sparing of the distal esophagus
Candida esophagitis White friable plaques, in advance form - adherent, grey-white pseudomembranes.

 

The image below shows the lesions of CMV esophagitis.

The image below shows the lesions of candida esophagitis.

The image below shows feline esophagus in eosinophilic esophagitis.

The image below shows the erosive lesion of pill esophagitis.

The image below shows the lesions of HSV esophagitis.

questions.text: The imaging modality that employs Blood Oxygen Level Dependent signal changes is :
questions.solution:
Blood Oxygen Level Dependent signal changes (BOLD) is the principle used in the fMRI(functional Magnetic Resonance Imaging)

Functional MRI (fMRI)

  • It is used to study cortical activation.
  • During cortical activation, there is an increase in relative cerebral blood flow (rCBF) and thus an increase in oxygen delivery to the activated brain, which exceeds the local oxygen metabolic requirement.
  • There is a net increase in oxyhemoglobin concentration in the venules and veins in the vicinity of the activated brain, which results in a tiny increase in MR signal, the so-called blood oxygenation level-dependent or, BOLD effect.
  • fMRI is mainly used for brain mapping.

 When neurons are activated the increased oxygen demand is met by increasing perfusion. This further rises venous oxyhemoglobin and reduces deoxyhemoglobin concentration. As deoxyhemoglobin is paramagnetic, the intensity of fMRI images increases in the activated areas. By performing different activities that activate different areas, a mapping can be done in fMRI.

Optical Coherence Tomography uses coherent light to obtain images of tissue in 2D or 3D up to micrometer resolutions. Currently, it is primarily employed in ophthalmology and interventional cardiology. The image in question shows a optical coherence tomography image of fluid accumulation in subretinal space with shallow retinal detachment.The following image shows OCT of a retina.


The following image shows an Intracoronary OCT image. The image shows a intracoronary plaque from 6 o'clock to 8 o’clock

Perfusion MRI is used to do assessment of tissue perfusion using a gadolinium contrast

SPECT is Single Photon Emission Computed Tomography that uses gamma rays to perform nuclear imaging that can provide 3D images also.

questions.text: The weight of a baby on day 10 of life is normally:
questions.solution:
The newborn baby loses weight in the first few days after birth, and it regains its birth weight by 7-10 days.  

Hence, the weight on day 10 of life would be the same as birth weight.

questions.text: Which of the following abnormalities is least likely to be detected in the first trimester sonography?
questions.solution:
Corpus callosum agenesis is least likely to be detected in the first trimester sonography.  

Detection rates are very high for anencephaly, holoprosencephaly and ventral wall defects.  

First trimester sonography can reliably diagnose

  • Anembryonic gestation,
  • Embryonic demise,
  • Ectopic pregnancy, and
  • Gestational trophoblastic disease.

The first trimester is also the ideal time to evaluate the uterus, adnexa, and cul-de-sac.

Determination of chorionicity in a multifetal gestation is most accurate in the first trimester.    

Some Indications for First-Trimester Ultrasound Examination :

  1. Confirm an intrauterine pregnancy
  2. Evaluate a suspected ectopic pregnancy
  3. Define the cause of vaginal bleeding
  4. Evaluate pelvic pain
  5. Estimate gestational age
  6. Diagnose or evaluate multifetal gestations
  7. Confirm cardiac activity
  8. Assist chorionic villus sampling, embryo transfer, and localization and removal of
  9. an intrauterine device
  10. Assess for certain fetal anomalies, such as anencephaly, in high-risk patients
  11. Evaluate maternal pelvic masses and/or uterine abnormalities
  12. Measure nuchal translucency when part of a screening program for fetal aneuploidy
  13. Evaluate suspected gestational trophoblastic disease

questions.text: The relative protein content of milk is in the order
questions.solution:
Human milk has the lowest protein content of all milk.  

Relative contents of nutrients in different kinds of milk.   

Fat, Protein and energy content: Buffalo>Goat>Cow>Human . 

Lactose - Human>Buffalo>Goat>Cow.      

Related Pearl: Baby-friendly hospital initiative (revised 2018)

Ten steps to successful breastfeeding (Revised 2018)

Critical management procedures

1  a. Comply fully with the International Code of Marketing of Breast-milk Substitutes and relevant World Health Assembly resolutions.

    b. Have a written infant feeding policy that is routinely communicated to staff and parents.

    c. Establish ongoing monitoring and data-management systems.

2. Ensure that staff has sufficient knowledge, competence, and skills to support breastfeeding.

Key clinical practices

3. Discuss the importance and management of breastfeeding with pregnant women and their families.

4. Facilitate immediate and uninterrupted skin-to-skin contact and support mothers to initiate breastfeeding as soon as possible after birth.

5. Support mothers to initiate and maintain breastfeeding and manage common difficulties.

6. Do not provide breastfed newborns any food or fluids other than breast milk, unless medically indicated.

7. Enable mothers and their infants to remain together and to practice rooming-in 24 hours a day.

8. Support mothers to recognize and respond to their infants’ cues for feeding.

9. Counsel mothers on the use and risks of feeding bottles, teats, and pacifiers.

10. Coordinate discharge so that parents and their infants have timely access to ongoing support and care.

questions.text: A patient with attention deficit hyperactive disorder is treated with atomoxetine. Which of the following drug has similar mechanism of action?
questions.solution:
Atomoxetine is a selective norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor and is indicated for the treatment of attention-deficit hyperactivity disorder.

Among the given drugs, nortriptyline(tricyclic antidepressant) is a selective norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor.

Other Tricyclic antidepressants:

  • Selective norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor : desipramine, protriptyline, amoxapine
  • Both norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor and serotonin reuptake inhibitor : imipramine and amitriptyline

Tricyclic antidepressants also blocks other receptors and can cause a number of side effects which limits its usage :

  • Antihistaminic : sedation
  • α1-blockade : orthostatic hypotension
  • Anticholinergic : tachycardia, urinary retention, dry mouth

Other options:

Methylphenidate is structurally similar to amphetamine and is a CNS stimulant. It can be used in the treatment of ADHD. It increases the concentration on dopamine and norepinephrine in the synaptic cleft.

Clonidine is alpha 2 agonist that can be used for hypertensive emergency, ADHD and tourette syndrome.

Entacapone prevents peripheral degradation of L-Dopa to 3-O-methyldopa by inhibiting catechol-O-methyl transferase enzyme. It is used in the treatment of parkinson disease.

questions.text: A patient presents with complaints of glare and discomfort of the eyes. Findings seen on slit-lamp examination are given below. He suffers from lupus erythematosus, for which he is being treated with chloroquine. Which of the following findings would you expect to see on a fundoscopy?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the slit lamp findings of cornea verticillata point to toxicity caused due to chloroquine. The fundoscopy in this patient is most likely to reveal bull’s eye maculopathy.

Prolonged administration of chloroquine leads to bull’s eye maculopathy.  

The image below shows bull’s eye maculopathy:

 

Causes of Bull’s eye maculopathy: 

  • Chloroquine maculopathy
  • Advanced Stargardt disease
  • Cone and cone-rod dystrophy
  • Fenestrated sheen macular dystrophy
  • Benign concentric annular macular dystrophy
  • Clofazimine retinopathy.

Cornea Verticillata is a condition where a whorl-like opacity is seen in the corneal epithelium seen on treatment with medica­tion such as chloroquine, amiodarone, phenothiazines, and indomethacin. It is also seen in Fabry disease.

Hypotonic maculopathy is the maculopathy occurring because of decreased intraocular pressure (less than 6 mmHg). It usually occurs due to excessive drainage after glaucoma filtration surgery.

questions.text: Find the correct match regarding collagen proteins in the human body.

choices.text: Type I – Forms sheets or meshwork
Type III – Anchoring or linking role

questions.solution:
Type II collagen proteins are involved in forming fibrils.

Regarding collagen proteins in the human body,

  • Types I, II, III, V and XI, form fibrils.
  • Types IV, VIII and X form sheets or meshwork.
  • Types VI, VII, IX, XII, XIV and XVIII have an anchoring or linking role.
  • Types XIII and XVII are transmembrane proteins.

However, biochemically all the collagens have a number of features in common. They are triple helical polypeptides containing high levels of hydroxyproline.

questions.text: Screening of a CSF sample is done by using:

choices.text: Antigen testing with a rapid test

questions.solution:
Gram staining is the preferred method of screening a CSF sample. Molecular methods can also be used when available as they have a higher sensitivity and specificity.  

Bacterial antigen testing of CSF using rapid tests are no longer recommended as a screening tool as they are no more sensitive than gram staining. However, they may be used as an adjunct to gram staining.  

Cultures are not used as a screening modality.

questions.text: All are true about PTH and PTHrP except

choices.text: They have  amino  acid  sequence  similarity,  particularly  in their amino-terminal regions.
Both hormones bind to a single PTH receptor that is expressed in bone and kidney
Hypercalcemia caused due to either can be easily distinguished solely  on the basis of  serum chemistries.

questions.solution:
Hypercalcemia caused due to either cannot be easily distinguished solely  on the basis of  serum chemistries  

Hypercalcemia and hypophosphatemia may result from excessive production of either hormone PTH or PTHrP, making it difficult to distinguish hyperparathyroidism from hypercalcemia of malignancy solely on the basis of serum chemistries.  

Sensitive and specific assays for PTH and PTHrP can be used to distinguish between both.

Related Pearl: Causes of Hypercalcemia

  • Parathyroid-Related
    • Primary hyperparathyroidism
      • Adenoma(s)
      • Multiple endocrine neoplasia
      • Carcinoma
    • Lithium therapy
    • Familial hypocalciuric hypercalcemia
  • Malignancy-Related
    • Solid tumour with metastases (breast)
    • Solid tumour with humoral mediation of hypercalcemia (lung, kidney)
    • Hematologic malignancies (multiple myeloma, lymphoma, leukemia)
  • Vitamin D–Related
    • Vitamin D intoxication
    • ↑ 1,25(OH)2D :
      • Sarcoidosis and other granulomatous diseases
      • Impaired 1,25(OH)2D metabolism due to 24-hydroxylase deficiency
    • Associated with high bone turnover
      • Hyperthyroidism
      • Immobilization
      • Thiazides
      • Vitamin A intoxication
      • Fat necrosis
    • Associated with renal failure
      • Severe secondary hyperparathyroidism
      • Aluminium intoxication
      • Milk-alkali syndrome

questions.text: A 22 year old male who is a known HIV patient presents with the complaints of anorexia, nausea and watery diarrhoea and abdominal pain for the past two weeks. Given is the histology image of the patient’s jejunum. Which of the following is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
The above given image shows the histology of jejunum with basophilic spherical structures attached to microvillus surface of epithelium which is seen in Cryptosporidium hominis.

The organism is acquired by fecal–oral transmission of oocysts from either human sources (primarily) or from animal sources.

The oocysts excyst in the small intestine, where the trophozoites attach to the gut wall. Invasion does not occur. The jejunum is the site most heavily infested.  

The disease in immunocompromised patients presents primarily as a watery, nonbloody diarrhea causing large fluid loss. Symptoms persist for long periods in immunocompromised patients, whereas they are self-limited in immunocompetent patients.

Other options:

A) Isospora belli can also cause similar symptoms in immunocompromised patients, but histology shows presence of schizonts and gametocytes within the epithelial cells of the large intestine with villous atrophy and inflammatory cells in the lamina propria. (Image below)

Note : In cryptosporidiosis, it is restricted to the apical region of the epithelial cells.

C) Giardia lamblia: Organisms are teardrop (pear) shaped with paired nuclei in lumen between villi that just adheres to the duodenal epithelium or free lying in the mucosa and never invades.

D) Entamoeba histolytica most commonly affects colon rather than small intestine. Organism burrow into lamina propria and cause tissue necrosis with relatively little inflammation.

questions.text: The given image is a transverse section of the mid-thigh. The architecture of the muscle highlighted in the image can be best described as
questions.solution:
The muscle marked in the given image is Adductor magnus.
It is a massive triangular muscle which is considered as partially cruciate and partially spiral. It is because it contains two or more planes of fibres arranged in differing directions. Other examples of such types of muscles are Sternocleidomastoid and Masseter.

Adductor magnus is a composite muscle which means it is doubly innervated by the obturator nerve and by the tibial division of the sciatic nerve.

questions.text: Follistatin is the serum binding protein for
questions.solution:
Follistatin is the serum binding protein for Activin    

Hormones and their Binding Proteins  

  1. T4  and T3  bind to thyroxine-binding globulin  (TBG),  albumin,  and  thyroxine-binding  prealbumin  (TBPA)  
  2. Cortisol binds to cortisol-binding globulin (CBG);  
  3. Androgen and estrogen bind to sex hormone–binding globulin (SHBG);  
  4. IGF-I and -II bind to multiple IGF-binding proteins (IGFBPs);  
  5. GH interacts with GH-binding protein (GHBP), a circulating fragment of the GH receptor extracellular domain;
  6. Activin binds to follistatin.

questions.text: A 26-year-old man was rushed to the ER after a motorbike accident causing a head injury. He was confused, could open eyes on command and was withdrawing on painful stimuli. His GCS score is __________
questions.solution:
Since the patient is

  • Confused – V4
  • Opens eye on command – E3
  • Withdraws to painful stimuli – M4

Therefore the GCS score is 4+3+4 =11.

Related Pearl: Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS)

GCS Score

  • 13-15 represent mild injury
  • 9-12 represent moderate injury
  • Scores ≤8 represent severe injury 

Head Injury Severity: Clinical classification 

Eyes Opening

 Score
Spontaneously 4
To verbal command 3
To painful stimulus 2
Do not open 1

Non-testable

 NT

 

Verbal response Score
Normal-oriented conversation 5
Confused 4
Inappropriate words only 3
Sounds only 2
No sounds 1

Non-testable

 NT

 

Motor Response Score
Obeys commands 6
Localizes to pain 5
Withdrawal response to pain 4
Abnormal flexion/ Decorticate posturing  3
Abnormal extension/ Decerebrate posturing  2
No motor response 1

Non-testable

 NT

Minimum value: 3

Maximum value: 15

  • GCS, in particular, the motor score, is the best predictor of neurological outcome.
  • If an area cannot be assessed, no numerical score is given for that region, and it is considered “non-testable." (NT)
  • In case of endotracheal intubation or tracheostomy, the verbal component of the score is denoted as NT.
  • A score of  ‘1’ is not recorded in missing components, instead, NT is used
  • when a component is Not Testable, a total score is not recorded because the score will be low and this could be confusing to medical colleagues. This may also imply that the patient is more unwell than they actually are.

 

NOTE: 

A new parameter, "pupil reactivity score" has been added to GCS, and now, it is referred to as GCS-P.

P stands for "Pupils unreactive to light"

Pupils unreactive to light Score
Both pupils 2
One pupil 1 
Neither  0

The pupillary score is subtracted from the GCS score to give the final value. Therefore, the range of GCS-P is 1–15.

Note: The minimum frequency of observations for patients with GCS equal to 15 should be as follows, starting after the initial assessment in the emergency department:

  • Half-hourly for 2 hours,
  • Then 1-hourly for 4 hours,
  • 2-hourly thereafter.

Should the patient with GCS equal to 15 deteriorate at any time after the initial 2-hour period, observations should revert to half-hourly and follow the original frequency schedule.

Related Pearl: NICE Guidelines for CT in Head Injury

National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (NICE) Guidelines for Computed Tomography (CT) in Head Injury

Indications for CT imaging within 1 hour of the following risk factors being identified:

  • Glasgow Coma Score (GCS) <12 on initial assessment
  • GCS <15 at 2 hours after injury on assessment in an emergency department
  • Focal neurological deficit
  • Suspected open, depressed, or basal skull fracture
  • More than one episode of vomiting
  • Post-traumatic seizure

Indications for CT imaging within 8 hours:

  • Age >65 years
  • Bleeding or clotting disorders
  • Dangerous mechanism of injury (e.g., fall from a height of >1 meter/5 stairs, road traffic accident)
  • Retrograde amnesia >30 minutes

questions.text: Choose the correct match.

choices.text: Gross Domestic Product- gross income generated only from within the country
Gross National Product- gross domestic product minus the depreciation on a country’s capital goods
Net National Product- income generated from within the country and income received from abroad
Net Domestic Product- market value of all final goods and services in a country during a year after allowing for depreciation

questions.solution:
Gross Domestic Product (GDP) is the income generated only from within the country and does not include income received from abroad.

Related Pearl: Economics

  • Gross National Income (GNI):
    • It is also known as the gross national product (GNP). It is the gross income generated from within the country as well as the income received from abroad. It is expressed as either ‘at current prices’ or ‘at constant prices’.
  • Per capita income:
    • It is arrived at by dividing the GNP by the total population of a country. It is a general indicator of national wealth.
  • Gross Domestic Product (GDP):
    • It is the gross income generated only from within the country. It doesn’t include income from abroad.
  • Net National Product (NNP):
    • It is the market value of all final goods and services in a country during a year after depreciation has been allowed for.
  • Net Domestic Product (NDP):
    • It is gross domestic product (GDP) minus the depreciation of a country’s capital goods.
  • Purchasing Power Parity (PPP):
    • It is an economic theory that compares the currencies of different countries through a market basket of goods approach. According to this concept, two currencies are in equilibrium when a market basket of goods is priced the same in both countries.

questions.text: Troilism is sexual gratification derived by____________

choices.text: Watching the act of urination or defecation by partner
Intercourse with a prepubescent underage individual
Watching the wife having intercourse with another man
By merely seeing or feeling of female body parts

questions.solution:
Troilism is sexual gratification derived by watching the wife having intercourse with another man.

  • Fetishism: Sexual gratification obtained by merely seeing or feeling female body parts /articles belonging to women.  
  • Pedophilia: Sexual arousal to a prepubescent individual, generally 13 years of age or younger
  • Undinism: Gets sexual gratification by watching the act of passing urine or defaecating by a woman  

Related Pearl: Paraphilic disorders

DSM-5 includes eight specific paraphilic disorders:

Disorder Description
Exhibitionistic disorder Sexual arousal from exposing their genitals to a stranger
Pedophilic disorder Sexual arousal to a prepubescent individual, generally 13 years of age or younger
Voyeuristic disorder Sexual arousal from observing other's sexual activities
Sexual sadism disorder Sexual arousal upon inflicting suffering or humiliation  
Frotteuristic disorder Sexual arousal by touching or rubbing against a non-consenting person
Fetishistic disorder Sexual arousal from the use of inert objects, such as female
undergarments
Transvestic disorder Sexual arousal from cross-dressing
Sexual masochism Sexual arousal from being humiliated, beaten, bound, or made to suffer

As per ICD-11, the first five are included under paraphilic disorders. Two other subclasses in addition to this are:

  • Other paraphilic disorders involving non-consenting individuals (e.g., arousal patterns involving corpses or animals)
  • Paraphilic disorders involving solitary behaviour or consenting individuals (e.g., asphyxophilia, fetishism, fetishistic transvestism).

questions.text: A 20 year old male patient with an autosomal dominant familial dyslipidemia comes to the hospital with acute pancreatitis. His lab reports shows triglyceride level of 1100 mg/dl, cholesterol - 143 mg/dl, VLDL - 206 mg/dl, HDL - 39 mg/dl. The overproduced lipoprotein has all of the following except?
questions.solution:
The above given clinical finding and lab values are suggestive of Type IV hypertriglyceridemia.

The overproduced lipoprotein is VLDL which has apolipoprotein E, C-II and B-100, but not apo A-I. Apo A-I is present in HDL and chylomicrons.

  • Apo C-II - lipoprotein lipase cofactor
  • Apo B-100 - binds LDL receptor
  • Apo B-48 - mediates chylomicron secretion into the lymphatics
