questions.text: A patient presented with loose stools and skin rashes over the sun-exposed areas. Diet history revealed that the patient had been consuming a jowar-rich diet since childhood. This condition results due to excess of which amino acid in the diet?
questions.solution:
This clinical scenario is suggestive of pellagra. It is caused by the excess of leucine in jowar.

Excess of leucine in jowar (sorghum) and maize interferes with the conversion of tryptophan to niacin causing pellagra.  It presents with the following features:

  • Diarrhea
  • Dermatitis (sun-exposed areas)
  • Dementia

People consuming jowar also have a higher risk of developing genu valgum and osteoporosis due to greater retention of ingested fluoride.

questions.text: A patient presented with a rectal mass protruding through the anus after straining as shown below.  Which of the following statements is incorrect with respect to the management of this condition?

choices.text: Well's procedure is done through abdominal approach
Abdominal approach is preferred for younger patients
Perineal route is not preferred if there is a high operative risk
Altemeier’s procedure is done through the perineal approach

questions.solution:
The above scenario with protrusion of a rectal mass with circumferential folds on straining is suggestive of rectal prolapse. The perineal approach for the surgical correction of rectal prolapse is often preferred in patients with high operative risk and limited life expectancy, i.e. in the elderly. It is associated with less morbidity but has a higher recurrence rate. 

Rectal prolapse occurs when a mucosal or full-thickness layer of rectal tissue protrudes through the anal orifice. Rectal prolapse is of two types:

1) Partial rectal prolapse- in this type, only the mucosal layer of the rectum is prolapsed. It is seen in children. The first episode is managed by digital reposition. If there is a recurrence, then Theirsch's wiring or sclerotherapy is done. 

2) Complete rectal prolapse- in this type, all the layers of the rectum are prolapsed. It is seen in adults due to the weakening of the pelvic floor. It is managed by using the following approaches:

  • The perineal approach- it is easy to perform, has fewer complications but a high recurrence rate. It is preferred in elderly patients with comorbidities. The surgeries done using this approach for rectal prolapse are the following:
    • Thiersch's wiring- a steel wire/silastic/nylon tape, is placed around the anal canal. Largely obsolete now due to problems with chronic perineal sepsis, anal stenosis, and obstructed defaecation. This procedure is rarely used now.
    • Delorme's mucosectomy- in this procedure, the rectal mucosa is stripped circumferentially from the rectum over the length of the prolapse. The underlying muscle is plicated with a series of sutures. The excess rectal mucosa is excised and a mucosal anastomosis is performed.
    • Altemeier's rectosigmoidoscopy- in this procedure, the rectum is prolapsed through the anal canal and a full-thickness resection is performed, incorporating any associated colonic prolapse. Restoration of colorectal continuity can be performed by hand-sewn/stapled anastomosis. This is the procedure of choice in patients presenting with incarcerated and strangulated prolapse.

The perineal approach is often preferred in patients with high operative risk and limited life expectancy, i.e. in the elderly. It is associated with less morbidity but has a higher recurrence rate. 

  • The abdominal approach- it is difficult to perform, has more complications but a lower recurrence rate. The surgeries done using this approach are the following: 
    • Ripstein's procedure- it involves the placement of a prosthetic mesh around the mobilized rectum, with the attachment of the mesh to the presacral fascia (anterior) below the sacral promontory.
    • Well's procedure- it involves posterior rectopexy. 
    • Suture rectopexy
    • Mesh rectopexy
    • Lateral (Orr-Loygue)
    • Ventral
    • Resection rectopexy (Frykman–Goldberg)

The principle of all abdominal operations for rectal prolapse is to fix the rectum in its normal anatomical position. Abdominal approaches (laparoscopic, robotic, or open) are preferred for younger patients, particularly those with constipation or associated pelvic floor disorders.

questions.text: In women when Sex Hormone Binding Globulin (SHBG) decreases because of insulin resistance or androgen excess, the unbound testosterone concentration is increased and leads to hirsutism. This lack of regulation is because

choices.text: Bound testosterone levels is the regulator of reproductive axis not the unbound form.
Estrogen, not testosterone, is the primary regulator of the reproductive axis
Testosterone is a weak stimulator and hence a large variation is required in its levels before eliciting a response.
Unbound Testosterone gets sequestered in adipose tissue.

questions.solution:
Estrogen, not testosterone, is the primary regulator of the reproductive axis.  

The increased unbound testosterone level does not result in an adequate compensatory  feedback  correction because Estrogen, not testosterone, is the primary regulator of the reproductive axis. So, when SHBG decreases because of insulin resistance or androgen excess, the unbound testosterone concentration is increased, potentially leading to hirsutism.

Related Pearl: Endocrinological changes of PCOD

  1. Elevated Estrone/E1 levels.
  2. LH level is raised over 10 IU/mL. FSH level remains normal to low, but FSH/LH ratio falls.
  3. Testosterone and epi-androstenedione levels rise.
    • Testosterone elevated but < 200 ng/dL (normal range 20 -80 ng/dL)
    • Testosterone > 200 ng/dL suggests androgen-secreting ovarian tumor
    • DHEA-S values may be normal or slightly elevated
    • DHEA >700 ng/mL suggests adrenal tumour
  4. Serum SHBG is reduced.
  5. Triglyceride level >150 mg/dL-hyperlipidaemia HDL <50 mg/dL.
  6. Fasting blood glucose/fasting insulin <4.5 suggests insulin resistance
  7. Prolactin is mildly raised in 15% cases
  8. Fasting insulin is more than 10 mIU/L in PCOS in 50–70%cases
  9. Thyroid function tests may be abnormal (hypothyroidism)
  10. 17-a-hydroxyprogesterone in the follicular phase >300 ng/dL suggests adrenal hyperplasia due to 21-hydroxylase deficiency.
  11. Urinary cortisol <50 μg/24 h.

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about Russel-Silver Syndrome?
questions.solution:
Russel silver syndrome is a growth disorder characterized by slow growth before and after birth. Hence, it presents as Low birth weight, not macrosomia.

Features:

Normal Head growth is present but affected children are thin and have a poor appetite.

Low birth weight and failure to thrive are often associated.  

Parent-specific differences in gene expression are caused due to genomic imprinting.

Hence Uniparental disomy can cause it.

Genes in chromosome 7 and 11 are involved in this.

questions.text: In a person with hearing impairment, brainstem evoked response audiometry (BERA) was performed. Wave IV in the given image corresponds to the activity of which of the following?
questions.solution:
Wave IV of the given image corresponds to activity in the superior olivary nucleus.

Brainstem Evoked Response Audiometry (BERA) is an objective and non-invasive method of hearing assessment that detects electrical activity from the inner ear to the inferior colliculus. 

Related Pearl: BERA (Brainstem Evoked Response Audiometry) or ABR (Auditory Brainstem Response)

It is an objective test that records electrical activity occurring in the auditory pathway.

Normally, 7 waves are produced in the first 10ms. 

  • Wave I – distal part of the cochlear nerve
  • Wave II –proximal part of the cochlear nerve
  • Wave III – cochlear nucleus
  • Wave IV – superior olivary complex
  • Wave V – lateral lemniscus
  • Wave VI & VII – inferior colliculus

Findings:

  • Conductive or cochlear pathology- delayed wave-I but inter-peak latency of I-V is normal
  • Retrocochlear pathology- wave-I present, rest of the waves absent
  • Acoustic neuroma or vestibular schwannoma- increased inter-peak latency of wave I-V and increased inter-aural latency of wave V > 0.2ms.

Uses:

  • To objectively find hearing threshold- wave-V appears 10dB above the hearing level obtained through PTA
  • Best audiometric test for:
    • Confirming hearing loss in infants
    • Diagnosing acoustic neuroma
    • Differentiating cochlear and retro-cochlear hearing loss
    • Diagnosing non-organic hearing loss.

questions.text: A young lady who had jumped from the fourth floor of her apartment building was brought to the casualty. CT pelvis revealed jumper's fracture. Which of the following best describes the fracture?

choices.text: Fracture of the dome of the acetabulum
Combination fracture of pubis and ilium
Bilateral fracture of both pubic rami
H or U shaped sacral fractures

questions.solution:
Jumper’s fracture is H or U-shaped fracture of the sacrum.

These are called jumper's or suicide jumper's fracture as they are seen in falls from height. There are two longitudinal fractures that run through the sacral foramina and a transverse fracture. The level of the transverse fracture line determines if it is H or U shaped. 

As these fractures pass through the sacral foramina, they can cause injury to the spinal cord and result in cauda equina syndrome.

questions.text: On experimental infusion of serotonin into the coronary artery, which of the following responses do you expect?

choices.text: Hypertension, Tachycardia & Rapid  Shallow Breathing-> Apnoea
Hypotension, Bradycardia & Apnea -> Rapid  Shallow Breathing
Hypotension, Tachycardia & Apnea -> Rapid  Shallow Breathing

questions.solution:
Hypotension, Bradycardia & Apnea -> Rapid Shallow Breathing will be produced.  

Bezold Jarisch Reflex will get stimulated on experimental infusion of serotonin into the coronary artery.

Other substances that can elicit the same reflex includes veratridine, capsaicin, phenylbiguanide etc.

Bezold Jarisch Reflex is also called Coronary Chemoreflex.  The sequence of events are:

Receptors -> C fiber endings Afferent -> Vagus Response -> Apnea -> Tachypnoea->Hypotension->Bradycardia  

This response is elicited only when infused into the coronary artery and not on infusion into the right ventricles.

Clinical Relevance: 

  • This reflex may be activated
    • During myocardial ischemia and reperfusion as a result of increased production of oxygen radicals 
    • By agents used as radiocontrast for coronary angiography.   
  • Another hypothesis is that it may help reduce the amount of inspired pollutants that gets absorbed into the blood, thereby protecting vital organs from potential toxicity of these pollutants, and facilitating their elimination 
  • Vasovagal syncope has also been attributed to Bezold-Jarisch Reflex

Related Pearl: Respiratory responses mediated by airway and lung receptors

Related Pearl: Physiological significance of Hering-Breuer inflation and deflation reflex

Advantage of Hering-Breuer inflation reflex

  • By cutting down the inspiration time-
    • Prevents overinflation of the lungs
    • Lungs operate at lower lung volumes thus wastage of energy is prevented

Advantage of Hering-Breuer deflation reflex

  • Prevents atelectasis of the lungs

questions.text: Granulomatosis infantiseptica is an infection due to ____________
questions.solution:
Granulomatosis infantiseptica is an overwhelming listerial fetal infection.  

Features are miliary microabscesses & granulomas in the skin, liver, and spleen.  

Maternal listeriosis presents in the form of myalgias, arthralgias, backache & headache and it is mostly associated with a bacteremia.  

Preterm delivery is a common complication that is associated with maternal listeriosis

questions.text: In which of the following conditions is peroral endoscopic myotomy done?
questions.solution:
Peroral endoscopic myotomy (POEM) is used in achalasia cardia.

Treatment options: 

  • Pneumatic dilatation
  • Laparoscopic myotomy
  • POEM (per-oral endoscopic myotomy)

With the use of an operating endoscope, the mucosa of the esophagus is divided around the mid to the distal third, and a submucosal tunnel is created. 

Through this tunnel, the muscular layer of the distal esophagus, lower esophageal sphincter (LES), and cardia are visualized and divided, effectively performing an endoscopic myotomy.

The major downside of POEM is that an effective anti-reflux valve cannot be created, exposing the patient to a 40%–50% risk of post-procedural gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD).

questions.text: Which  of  the  following  statement  is  not  true  about  anterior  cruciate  ligament?

choices.text: Prevents anterior displacement of the tibia on the femur
It is stronger than the posterior cruciate ligament
Tension of the ACL is greatest when the knee is extended
It is attached to the anterior tibia and ascends posterolaterally, to attach high on the posteromedial aspect of the lateral femoral condyle.

questions.solution:
Anterior cruciate ligament is not stronger than the posterior cruciate ligament. It is most likely to get injured among these two ligaments.  The posterior cruciate ligament is thicker and stronger than the anterior cruciate ligament. 

The cruciate ligaments provide both anteroposterior and rotatory stability. They also help to resist excessive valgus and varus angulation.

The anterior cruciate has anteromedial and posterolateral bundles, whereas the posterior cruciate has anterolateral and posteromedial bundles.  

Anterior displacement of the tibia is resisted by the anteromedial bundle of the anterior cruciate ligament whilst the posterolateral part tightens as the knee extends.

Posterior displacement is prevented by the posterior cruciate ligament (PCL), specifically by the anterolateral bundle when the knee is in near 90 degree flexion and by the posteromedial bundle when the knee is straight.  

Attachments:

  • The anterior cruciate ligament(ACL) is attached to the anterior intercondylar area of the tibia. It ascends posterolaterally, twisting on itself and fanning out to attach high on the posteromedial aspect of the lateral femoral condyle.
  • Posterior cruciate ligament (PCL) attaches to the posterior aspect of the tibia and courses superiorly, anteriorly, and medially to attach to the medial condyle of the femur.

questions.text: The upgradation of existing and the setting up of new AIIMS institutions is covered under which government health program?
questions.solution:
The upgradation of existing and the setting up of new AIIMS institutions is covered under PMSSY.

The Pradhan Mantri Swasthya Suraksha Yojana (PMSSY) was announced in 2003 with objectives of correcting regional imbalances in the availability of affordable/ reliable tertiary healthcare services and also to augment facilities for quality medical education in the country.

PMSSY has two components:

  • Setting up of AIIMS like Institutions
  • Upgradation of Government Medical College Institutions.


Other options:

  • The PMJAY is a component of the Ayushman Bharat launched on 23rd September 2018. It pertains to providing health protection cover to poor and vulnerable families.
  • RAN Scheme provides for financial assistance to patients, living below poverty line and who suffer from major life threatening diseases, to receive medical treatment at any of the super specialty Government hospitals / institutes.

questions.text: Which among the following cephalosporins has activity against MRSA?
questions.solution:
Among the given cephalosporins, ceftaroline has activity against MRSA.

Drug Class Antibacterial spectrum

First generation :

Cefazolin,cephalexin, cefadroxil,cephradine

 Streptococci; Staphylococcus aureus, some Proteus, E. coli, Klebsiella. 

Second generation :

Cefuroxime

Cefuroxime axetil

Cefprozil

Cefoxitin

Cefotetan

Cefmetazole 

 Escherichia coli, Klebsiella, Proteus, Haemophilus influenzae, Moraxella catarrhalis. Not as active against gram-positive organisms as first-generation agents.   Inferior activity against S. aureus compared to cefuroxime but with added activity against Bacteroides fragilis and other Bacteroides spp. 

Third generation

Cefotaxime

Ceftriaxone

Cefdinir

Cefditoren pivoxil

Ceftibuten

Cefpodoxime proxetil

Ceftizoxime 

 Escherichia coli, Klebsiella, Proteus, Haemophilus influenzae, Moraxella catarrhalis, Citrobacter, Enterobacter; Serratia; Neisseria gonorrhoeae;  Activity for S. aureus, Streptococcus pneumoniae, and Streptococcus pyogenes comparable to first-generation agents.  Activity against Bacteroides spp. inferior to that of cefoxitin and cefotetan. 

Antipseudomonal

Cephalosporins 

Ceftazidime  

Ceftazidime/avibactam   

Ceftolozane/tazobactam

Cefepime 

   Gram-negative activity similar to third generation with addition of activity against Pseudomonas; poor activity vs. gram-positive organisms.   Expands ceftazidime’s activity against Pseudomonas and multidrug-resistant Enterobacteriaceae, but not against gram-positives.   Similar to ceftazidime, with enhanced activity against Pseudomonas and extended-spectrum β-lactamase-producing Enterobacteriaceae.   Comparable to third generation but more resistant to some β-lactamases (especially those of Pseudomonas and Enterobacter); gram-positive activity similar to cefotaxime. 

Anti-MRSA Cephalosporins 

Ceftaroline

Ceftobiprole 

    Similar activity to 3rd generation but with activity against methicillin resistant Staphylococcus aureus 

Related Pearl: Methicillin-Resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA)

MRSA Definition: Methicillin MIC 8 μg/ml or more, Oxacillin MIC 4 μg/ml or more.

Resistance in MRSA is mediated by mecA gene which is chromosomally coded. It alters PBP (penicillin-binding protein) present on S.aureus cell wall to PBP-2a which has less affinity for beta-lactam antibiotics.

Penicillin Binding Protein:

  • Normal protein present in all bacterial cell wall.
  • Transpeptidase in nature.
  • Required for cross-linking of the peptidoglycan layer (essential for cell wall synthesis).
  • It is also the site of attachment for- beta-lactam drugs to bind & inhibit.

Types of MRSA:

  • Community-acquired - mediated by mec A subtype IV and Possess PV Toxin(Panton-Valentine Toxin), monodrug resistance,more virulent
  • Hospital-acquired - mediated by mec A subtype I, II, III, multidrug resistance,less virulent.

Detection of MRSA:

  • Antibiotic susceptibility test on Muller Hilton agar (Disk diffusion test) by using Methicillin or Oxacillin disc or cefoxitin disc.
  • PCR for detection of mecA gene.

Treatment:

  • Vancomycin is Drug Of Choice (should be used only if other drugs are resistant ).
  • Others- Teicoplanin, Linezolid, streptogramin, cipro/levofloxacin, cotrimoxazole, clindamycin, mupirocin, minocycline.
  • Newer Drugs – Daptomycin, ceftobiprole, tigecycline, oritavancin, dalbavancin, telavancin, delafloxacin.
  • Ceftobiprole and ceftaroline are 5th generation β lactams effective against MRSA.

questions.text: A 45 years old male patient presented to the emergency department with chest pain and breathlessness after a road traffic accident. No penetrating injury to the chest is seen. His chest X-ray is as given below. Which of the following is an indication for thoracotomy?

choices.text: Persistence of hemothorax despite a tube thoracostomy
Continuous bleeding < 50 ml/h for 3 consecutive hours
Drainage of > 1500 ml blood when chest tube is first inserted

questions.solution:
Drainage of >1500 ml blood when the chest tube is first inserted is an indication for thoracotomy.

The above clinical scenario with the chest radiograph showing blunting of the costophrenic angle and opacification of the half of the hemithorax is suggestive of hemothorax. 

Thoracotomy is a creation of access to contents of the thoracic cavity by an incision between the ribs.

The indications for thoracotomy in a thoracic trauma are:

  • Drainage of more than 1500 ml (blunt trauma) or 1000ml (penetrating trauma) blood when the chest tube is first inserted
  • Continuous hemorrhage of more than 200 mL/h for 3 consecutive hours (Option C)
  • Caked hemothorax (Persistence of hemothorax despite two tube thoracotomies) (Option B)
  • Great vessel injury
  • Pericardial tamponade
  • Cardiac herniation
  • Inadequate ventilation with a massive air leak in chest tube
  • Trachea or main stem bronchial injury(diagnosed on imaging or endoscopy)
  • Open pneumothorax
  • Esophageal perforation
  • Air embolism

Other options:

Option A- Surgical emphysema is a common phenomenon complication tube thoracostomy for pneumothorax. It is usually benign, self-limiting that requires only conservative treatment.

questions.text: A patient requires ampicillin 260 mg. You have a 5ml syringe with 5 divisions per ml. The vial contains 500 mg/5 ml of ampicillin. How many divisions of the 5 ml syringe will you fill to give 260 mg of ampicillin?
questions.solution:
The vial contains 500 mg of ampicillin in 5 ml
i.e 100 mg in 1 ml.
For the patient to receive 260 mg of ampicillin 2.6 ml of the drug is needed.
1 ml has 5 divisions in the syringe, 2.6 ml will have 2.6 * 5 ml = 13 divisions

questions.text: In the given image, the perineal membrane is denoted by:
questions.solution:
In the given image of a median sagittal section of a male perineum, the perineal membrane is denoted by the arrow marked as C.

The perineal membrane divides the urogenital triangle into:

  • A deep perineal space lying above it
  • A superficial perineal space lying below it

It has a distinct dorsal and a ventral portion, which are closely connected with Levator ani.
The dorsal portion is related to the support of the perineal body and lateral vaginal wall by its attachment to the ischiopubic ramus. The ventral portion, on the other hand, is contiguous with the structures supporting urethra.

questions.text: The factor responsible for pubertal growth in females is :

choices.text: Pulsatile release of GnRH during sleep
Increased sensitivity of the Hypothalamo-Pituitary-Ovarian(HPO) axis to estrogen

questions.solution:
The pulsatile release of GnRH during sleep is the factor responsible for pubertal growth in females.  

The various events that happen are

  • HPO axis differentiates and develops during fetal life and becomes fully functional before birth but remains inactive after late infancy. 
  • Adrenarche happens in late childhood, i.e an increase in adrenal androgen production
  • Pubarche follows, resulting in the growth of axillary and pubic hair.
  • FSH & LH rise followed by a gradual rise of estradiol causing thelarche
  • Pulsatile secretion of GnRH increases and this stimulates the HPO axis, resulting in gonadarche and also in Pubertal growth.

 

Note:

Though the growth spurt is an effect of increased GH due to high estrogen levels, the onset of puberty per se is due to pulsatile secretion of GnRH and is the main underlying factor behind puberty and associated growth. Hence that is considered to be the more appropriate answer.

questions.text: Which of the following occurs when beta oxidation of the fatty acid predominates in the liver following starvation?

choices.text: Carboxylation of mitochondrial pyruvate to oxaloacetate for gluconeogenesis
Carboxylation of pyruvate to phosphoenolpyruvate for gluconeogenesis
Inhibition of pyruvate carboxylase by acetyl-CoA
Oxidative decarboxylation of pyruvate to acetyl-CoA for oxidation in Kreb’s cycle

questions.solution:
When beta oxidation of the fatty acid predominates in the liver following starvation, there is carboxylation of mitochondrial pyruvate to oxaloacetate for gluconeogenesis.  

After an overnight fast, glycogenolysis and gluconeogenesis make approximately equal contributions to blood glucose; as glycogen reserves are depleted, gluconeogenesis becomes progressively more important.  

Hepatic gluconeogenesis requires expenditure of ATP and is always dependent on β-oxidation of fatty acids in the liver. During hypoglycemia, adipose tissue releases these fatty acids by breaking down triglyceride.  

Since, conversion of phosphoenolpyruvate to pyruvate is an irreversible process, two seperate endothermic reactions occur for the conversion of pyruvate to phosphoenolpyruvate during gluconeogenesis. Pyruvate cannot be directly converted to phosphoenolpyruvate for gluconeogenesis.  

Pyruvate carboxylase is a mitochondrial enzyme requiring biotin. It is activated by acetyl-CoA (from β-oxidation). The product oxaloacetate(OAA), a citric acid cycle intermediate, cannot leave the mitochondria but is reduced to malate that can leave via the malate shuttle. In the cytoplasm, malate is reoxidized to OAA.  

Pyruvate cannot be converted to acetyl-CoA for oxidation in Kreb’s cycle because the acetyl-CoA from β-oxidation will inhibit pyruvate dehydrogenase required for the conversion.  

Related Pearl: Irreversible enzymes in gluconeogenesis pathway

The enzymes can be remembered using the mnemonic Pathway Produces Fresh Glucose.

Enzymes Reaction and site Cofactors
Pyruvate carboxylase

Pyruvate → Oxaloacetate

mitochondria

Biotin, ATP

Activated by acetyl-CoA
Phosphoenolpyruvate carboxykinase Oxaloacetate → PhosphoenolPyruvate (cytosol) GTP
Fructose-1,6-bisphosphatase Fructose-1,6-bisphosphate → fructose-6-phosphate (cytosol)

Citrate(+ve)

Fructose 2,6 bisphosphate (-ve)
Glucose-6-phosphatase Glucose-6-phosphate → glucose Endoplasmic reticulum

questions.text: Which of the following is the method of sterilization used for Hepatitis B infected blood spill in the operation theatre?
questions.solution:
The method of sterilization used for hepatitis B infected blood spill in operation theatre is sodium hypochlorite.

The exact mechanism by which free chlorine destroys microorganisms has not been elucidated.

Inactivation by chlorine can result from a number of factors:

  • Oxidation of sulfhydryl enzymes and amino acids
  • Ring chlorination of amino acids
  • Loss of intracellular contents
  • Decreased uptake of nutrients
  • Inhibition of protein synthesis
  • Decreased oxygen uptake
  • Oxidation of respiratory components
  • Decreased adenosine triphosphate production
  • Breaks in DNA and
  • Depressed DNA synthesis

The actual microbiocidal mechanism of chlorine might involve a combination of these factors or the effect of chlorine on critical sites.

All these can cause disruption of the genome and protein function of the virus.

Related Pearl: Methods of sterilisation

Method of disinfection or sterilisation Material
Red Heat Inoculating wire loop, tip of forceps
Incineration Contaminated clothes, animal carcasses, plastics like polythene
Hot air oven Glasswares, scalpels, forceps, cutting instruments, test tubes
Inspissator Heat labile culture media containing egg, sugar or serum
Autoclave Culture media, dressings, gloves, aprons, all instruments except sharps, suture materials except catgut
Isopropyl alcohol Clinical thermometers, stethoscopes, probes
Methyl alcohol Fungal spores

Beta propiolactone/

formaldehyde

 Fumigation of operating theatres, wards and labs
2% gluteraldehyde Cystoscopes, bronchoscopes, fibre-optic endoscopes, plastic ETT, face masks
Plasma sterilisation Arthroscopes, urethroscopes
Ethylene oxide Heart lung machines, respirators, dental equipments, sutures, books, clothings
Filtration (Seitz filters) Bacterial vaccines, intravenous solutions
5% cresol, hot air oven Sharp instruments

Ionising radiation

(Cold air sterilization)

 Catgut, swabs, plastic, syringes, needles, gloves, catheters, grafts
Chlorhexidine Disinfecting surgeon’s hands prior to surgery
Iodophor Disinfecting surgical site prior to surgery
70% ethanol Disinfectant skin prior to venepuncture or immunisation
Thiomersal Preservative in vaccine
Silver sulfadiazine Cleanse burn wounds
Hypochlorite Cleanup of blood spill from a patient with hepatitis B or C
Hydrogen peroxide Cleanse wounds

questions.text: The prevalence rate of Leprosy as on 1st April 2016 in India is
questions.solution:
The Prevalence rate of Leprosy in India as on 1st April 2016 is 0.66 per 10, 000 population.

On the other hand, the Annual case detection rate is (ANCDR) 10.17 per 1,00,000 Population.

questions.text: You notice the following response on stroking one side of the spine. Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding this?

choices.text: The reflex elicited is known as galant reflex
The right side of spine has been stroked in the image
Persistence of the reflex interferes with walking movements

questions.solution:
The image shows Galant Reflex also known as Lateral Trunk incurvation reflex.

It is elicited by holding the newborn in ventral suspension (face down) and stroking along the one side of the spine. The normal reaction is for the newborn to laterally flex toward the stimulated side.

Succinctly, the trunk moves towards the side of stimulus.

It is a spinal reflex,and its persistence interferes with development of normal walking movements and postures

questions.text: A population of 25000 were subjected to a screening test to detect lung cancer. The prevalence of the disease was 20% among the population. The test could correctly detect the disease in only 80% of the diseased people. Another 5% of the normal people were also identified as diseased by the test. Considering the population doubles in the next 5 years while the prevalence rate remains the same, which of the following with respect to screening test would be true?

choices.text: The likelihood of a diseased person being detected as positive is 16 times as compared to a normal person
The sensitivity would remain the same but negative predictive value would change
The sensitivity of the test will be equal to the negative predictive value of the test in 5 years
The specificity of the test will be double that of sensitivity

questions.solution:
The positive likelihood ratio (the likelihood of a diseased person being detected as positive is as compared to a normal person) for the given screening test is 16.

For the given data the following table can be constructed.

  Disease positive Disease negative  
Test Positive 4000 (TP) 1000 (FP) 5000
Test Negative 1000 (FN) 19000 (TN) 20000
  5000 20000 25000

From the table, the following values can be calculated:

  • Sensitivity: TP/ (TP + FN) * 100 = 4000/5000 * 100 = 80%
  • Specificity: TN/ (TN+ FP) * 100 = 19000/20000 * 100 = 95%
  • Positive Likelihood ratio: Sens / (1- Spec) = 0.8 / 0.05 = 16
  • Negative Likelihood ratio: (1-Sens) / Spec = 0.2 / 0.95 = 0.21
  • Positive Predictive Value: TP/ (TP + FP) * 100 = 4000/5000 * 100 = 80%
  • Negative Predictive Value: TN / (TN+ FN) * 100 = 19000/20000 * 100 = 95%

If the population doubles, and the prevalence is the same, there is no change in the values as can be seen below:

  Disease positive Disease negative  
Test Positive  8000 (TP) 2000 (FP) 10000
Test Negative 2000 (FN) 38000 (TN) 40000
  10,000 40,000 50000
  • Sensitivity: TP/ (TP + FN) * 100 = 8000/10000 * 100 = 80%
  • Specificity: TN/ (TN+ FP) * 100 = 38000/40000 * 100 = 95%
  • Positive Likelihood ratio: Sens / (1- Spec) = 0.8 / 0.05 = 16
  • Negative Likelihood ratio: (1-Sens) / Spec = 0.2 / 0.95 = 0.21
  • Positive Predictive Value: TP/ (TP + FP) * 100 = 8000/10000 * 100 = 80%
  • Negative Predictive Value: TN / (TN+ FN) * 100 = 38000/40000 * 100 = 95%

Related Pearl: Validity of a Screening Test

  • Validity/ accuracy of a screening test depends upon the sensitivity, specificity, and predictive accuracy of the test.
  • It represents the closeness to a true value/ actual value.
  • These are the inherent properties of a screening test.
  • PPV and NPV are dependent on the Prevalence of disease.
  • Sensitivity & Specificity are independent of prevalence of disease.
Formulae 
Sensitivity      TP    
TP + FN
Specificity      TN    
FP + TN
Predictive value of a positive test (PPV)      TP    
TP + FP
Predictive value of a negative test (NPV)      TN     
TN + FN
Percentage of false positives      FP     
FP + TN
Percentage of false negatives      FN     
TP + FN
  • PPV varies directly with prevalence
  • NPV varies inversely with prevalence

questions.text: What is the daily requirement of high-quality protein for a 40-year-old man weighing 60 kgs?
questions.solution:
This man requires 50 g/day of high-quality protein.

High-quality protein refers to proteins containing all the essential amino acids. According to the FAO/WHO 2007 guidelines, the recommended high-quality protein intake for adult men and women is 0.83 g/kg/day. This man weighs 60 kgs. Hence he requires around 50 g (0.83*60 = 49.8) of high-quality protein per day.

Recommended high-quality protein intake by FAO/WHO:

Age Protein in g/kg/day
1-5 years 0.94
6-10 years 0.91
Adolescent male 0.88
Adolescent female 0.86
Adult man/woman 0.83

However, the mixed Indian diet does not meet the requirement for high-quality protein. Hence, the protein requirement in Indian adults (men and women) is 1g/kg/day of mixed Indian diet protein according to the ICMR 2010 guidelines.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child brought to the OPD with painless deformity. Given is the image of the X-ray of the child. Which of the following is not likely to be seen in this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical picture is suggestive of rickets. Pelkan spur is not seen in rickets.  

Pelkan spurs are metaphyseal spurs with marginal fractures. It is a radiographic finding seen in scurvy.

Related Pearl: Radiological Features of Rickets

Radiological features of rickets:

  • Loss of provisional zone of calcification: earliest radiological finding of rickets. 
  • Delayed appearance of the epiphysis
  • Widening of growth plate: normal width of growth plate is 2-4mm. It is increased in cases of rickets due to excessive accumulation of uncalcified osteoid at the growth plate.
  • Cupping of metaphysis: normally metaphysis meets epiphysis as a smooth line of sclerosis. But in rickets the line is absent and the metaphyseal ends appear irregular and the cartilage accumulating in the growth plate creates a depression in the metaphysis causing cupping.
  • Fraying: indistinct margins of the metaphysis
  • Bowing of diaphysis, with thinning of cortices
  • In healing rickets, zone of calcification becomes denser. 

The above features are prominent at the growth plates where growth is greatest:

  • Knee: distal femur, proximal tibia
  • Wrist: especially the ulna
  • Anterior rib ends: rachitic rosary

The below image shows bowing of legs in rickets.

Related Pearl: Radiological Features of Scurvy

Radiological features of scurvy:

  • Generalised osteopenia
  • Pencil-point cortex: Cortical thinning
  • Periosteal reaction due to subperiosteal hemorrhage
  • Scorbutic rosary: Expansion of the costochondral junctions
  • Hemarthrosis
  • Wimberger ring/ Wimberger sign: Circular, opaque radiological shadow surrounding epiphyseal centers of ossification, which may result from bleeding
  • Frenkel line: Dense zone of provisional calcification 
  • Trummerfeld zone: Lucent metaphyseal band underlying Frankel line
  • Pelken spur: Metaphyseal spurs which result in cupping of the metaphysis

questions.text: Which of the following types is the most common presentation of psoriatic arthritis?
questions.solution:
Asymmetric oligoarthritis is the most common type of Psoriatic arthritis.

Asymmetric oligoarthritis commonly involves a knee or another large joint with a few small joints in the fingers or toes, often with dactylitis.

Psoriatic arthritis is a seronegative inflammatory arthritis that is destructive to the joints, associated with moderate to severe psoriasis. It usually develops before 40 years of age.

A diagnosis of psoriatic arthritis can be made from the Classification Criteria for Psoriatic Arthritis (CASPAR) criteria, if there is an inflammatory articular disease of a joint, enthesis or spine, along with >=3 of the following criteria:

  1. Current or history of psoriasis/ family history of psoriasis
  2. Typical psoriatic nail involvement
  3. Rheumatoid factor negative
  4. Current or history of dactylitis
  5. Radiological evidence of juxta-articular new bone formation

Triggers include trauma to a joint or tendon (Koebner effect), smoking, alcohol excess and HIV infection. Streptococcal infection, medications like lithium or stress do not trigger the onset of psoriatic arthritis. There is an activation of both innate and acquired immunity with the overproduction of cytokines like TNF‐α, IL‐17 and IL‐23 via the JAK-STAT pathway. This results in joint fibrosis and erosion of bone with abnormal bone formation.

Wright & Moll Classification of Psoriatic Arthritis

  • Arthritis of the DIP joints
  • Asymmetric oligoarthritis
  • Symmetric polyarthritis
  • Axial involvement such as spine and sacroiliac joints
  • Arthritis mutilans, a destructive form of arthritis

Psoriatic arthritis involves proximal and distal interphalangeal joints (PIP, DIP) and metacarpophalangeal joints (MCP). Clinical features include:

  • Early morning stiffness
  • Swollen, tender, one or more joints
  • Enthesitis: Heel pain due to Achilles tendon inflammation
  • Plantar fasciitis
  • Dactylitis /sausage fingers with telescoping (shortening of toes due to osteolysis)
  • Nail changes: hyperkeratosis and onycholysis
  • Axial involvement may occur

The image below shows psoriatic arthritis of the hands:

 

Investigations include:

  • Inflammatory markers like CRP, ESR
  • Tests to rule out other arthritis: uric acid, rheumatoid factor, anti-CCP antibodies
  • Plain X‐rays of the hands and feet in erosive disease, which show:
    • Pencil-in-cup deformity of distal interphalangeal joint
    • Marginal erosions with adjacent bony proliferation 'whiskering'
  • MRI to assess axial disease and enthesitis

Given below is an X-ray showing the 'pencil-in-cup' appearance of the metacarpophalangeal joints

Psoriatic arthritis should be managed by a rheumatologist. Early treatment and interventions are necessary to prevent irreversible joint damage. The Group for Research and Assessment of Psoriasis and Psoriatic Arthritis (GRAPPA) management guidelines for psoriatic arthritis states the use of the following drugs in:

  • Peripheral arthritis: NSAIDs/ steroid injection/ Systemic treatments - methotrexate, cyclosporin/ biologicals
  • Dactylitis: NSAIDs/ Steroid injection
  • Axial disease / Enthesitis: NSAIDs / Physiotherapy / Biologicals

Tofacitinib is a novel, oral JAK 1/3 - Inhibitor which will inhibit the JAK-STAT pathway responsible for the production of cytokines and chemokines. It has been approved for the treatment of psoriatic arthritis, and is also used in rheumatoid arthritis and ulcerative colitis.

Newer drugs approved for the treatment of Psoriatic arthritis include:

Class of drug Drugs
Anti-TNF α

- Infliximab (only iv drug, rest all are s/c)
- Etanercept 
- Adalimumab 
- Golimumab
- Certolizumab
Anti-IL-17 - Secukinumab 
Anti-IL-23 - Ustekinumab 

Psoriatic arthritis is found to be associated with ocular diseases like conjunctivitis, uveitis, iridocyclitis, keratoconjunctivitis sicca and cataracts, obesity/metabolic syndrome, alcohol misuse and premature cardiovascular disease.

Differential diagnoses include:

  • Early rheumatoid arthritis
  • Ankylosing spondylitis
  • Gout
  • Osteoarthritis
  • Fibromyalgia

Asymmetric oligoarthritis is the most common type of psoriatic arthritis. Previously, symmetric polyarthritis was marked as the correct answer (based on Harrison's Textbook of Internal Medicine 20th Edition). However, after thorough review of literature and consultation of expert faculty, the answer has been changed to asymetric oligoarthritis as per:

  • Rook′s Textbook of Dermatology 9th edition - (Page no 35.44) 
  • ABC of Rheumatology 2018, Wiley-Blackwell- British Medical Journal (Page No 85)
  • Kelley and Firestein's Textbook of Rheumatology, 10th Edition (Page No 1288)

questions.text: Which of the following is not correct about FLAIR sequence imaging in MRI?

choices.text: Gives better visualisation of even small lesions

questions.solution:
The FLAIR sequence imaging shows lesions as hyperintense, not hypointense.  

FLAIR - Fluid Attenuated Inversion Recovery.  

In this 

  • Gray matter - Hyperintense
  • White matter - Hypointense
  • SF/Water - Hypointense
  • Lesions - appear Hyperintense  

It can detect even the smallest of lesions that can be missed in T2 Sequence though T2 is traditionally considered to be the window to detect pathology.

Generally, MRI is considered the best imaging for the spinal cord and nerves.

questions.text: Which of the following is false about biology of PTSD?

choices.text: Hippocampal size is negatively correlated with trauma severity.

questions.solution:
The corpus callosum is not affected in PTSD(Post traumatic stress disorder).


PTSD patients have elevated levels of dopamine and norepinephrine.Platelet a2- and lymphocyte /3-adrenergic receptors are downregulated in PTSD, possibly in response to chronically elevated catecholamine concentrations.

 
Hippocampal volume is negatively correlated with trauma severity, and the decrese in size may be due to elevated glucocorticoids.

questions.text: Identify the helminth from the life cycle given below.
questions.solution:
The image shows the life cycle of Strongyloides stercoralis.

Strongyloides stercoralis is the smallest nematode known to cause human infection. It has both a free-living and a parasitic life cycle. Its natural host is man. The infective form to man is the filariform larva. Infection occurs through penetration of the skin by larvae in the soil. Then, the larvae migrate to the small intestine. They molt twice and become adult female worms in the small intestine. The eggs laid in the mucosa of the intestine hatch immediately releasing the rhabditiform larva (L1 stage). Thus, it is ovoviviparous. These rhabditiform larvae in the bowel can develop directly into filariform larvae that penetrate the colonic wall or perianal skin and enter the circulation to repeat the migration. This establishes ongoing internal reinfection.

The rhabditiform larva can also be passed in the stool. It may directly metamorphose to the infective filariform larva in the soil, or develop into adult worms. The free-living adult worms then pass eggs, which hatch and mature to form infective filariform larvae. 

 In Ancylostoma duodenale infestation, eggs containing segmented ova (not rhabditiform larvae) are passed in the stool. The rhabditiform larva hatches 2 days after the eggs are passed in the soil. 

Note: Based on the method of reproduction, nematodes are classified as follows:

  1. Oviparous - They lay eggs:
    • Unsegmented eggs: Ascaris lumbricoides, Trichuris trichuria
    • Segmented eggs:  Ancylostoma duodenale, Necator americanus
    • Eggs containing larva: Enterobius vermicularis
  2. Viviparous - They produce larvae. e.g., Trichinella spiralis, Wuchereria bancrofti, Brugia malayi
  3. Ovoviviparous – They lay eggs containing fully formed larvae that hatch immediately. e.g., Strongyloides stercoralis

questions.text: Which of the following infections is an occupational hazard in funeral service workers?
questions.solution:
Funeral service workers have an increased risk of Mycobacterium tuberculosis infection. It is speculated that the transfer of the dead body and handling of cadavers may expel residual air from the lungs of the deceased.  

Sporothrix schenckii infections are more common in people who do gardening.  

Escherichia coli and Toxoplasma gondii are associated with raw or undercooked meat consumption.  

Salmonella typhimurium, Listeria monocytogenes, and Mycobacterium bovis are associated with consumption of unpasteurized milk.  

Leptospira, parasites and enteric bacteria are associated with consumption of unpurified water.

Vibrio, Norovirus, helminths, and protozoa are associated with raw seafood consumption.

questions.text: The synovial fluid analysis in a 45-year-old patient with pain and swelling over his ankle and metatarsophalangeal joints revealed the following finding as given below. Which of the following is true about the crystals shown in the image?
questions.solution:
The image shows characteristic long, slender, needle-shaped urate crystals found in Gout. They are negatively birefringent under polarized light. 

Precipitation of monosodium urate crystals (MSU) is the hallmark of Gout. The lower temperature of the peripheral joints promotes their precipitation. MSU crystals are frequently found in the cytoplasm of the neutrophils and are arranged in small clusters in the synovium.

One of the factors leading to the precipitation of these crystals is Lead toxicity (not copper). The condition is then known as Saturnine Gout.

In contrast, Calcium pyrophosphate crystals are deposited in pseudo-gout (also known as Chondrocalcinosis). Calcium pyrophosphate crystals are rhomboid and positively birefringent.

questions.text: Which of the following features would you least expect to see in a patient with Klippel-Feil syndrome?
questions.solution:
Elevated scapula is not a part of the clinical triad of Klippel-Feil syndrome. However, it is associated with Sprengel deformity, which occurs in approximately 30% of cases.

The classic clinical triad seen in this condition includes:

  1. Short neck
  2. Low posterior hairline
  3. Limited range of neck motion

Klippel-Feil syndrome is a developmental disorder caused by a failure of normal segmentation of the cervical somites during the 3rd to 8th week of embryogenesis. This results in a congenital fusion of at least 2 cervical vertebrae, sometimes a block of cervical vertebrae, and rarely the entire cervical spine.

X-rays may show the fusion of two or more cervical vertebrae. The vertebrae are also widened and flattened (wasp-waist appearance).

The below radiograph from a Klippel-Feil syndrome patient shows the fusion of C6, C7, and T1 vertebrae:

questions.text: Which of the following diseases should healthcare workers involved in handling biomedical waste be vaccinated against?
questions.solution:
Healthcare workers involved in handling biomedical waste should be vaccinated against hepatitis B and tetanus.

These are most likely to be transmitted by the handling of biomedical waste. Yearly health check-ups should be done, and a booster dose should be given if needed.

questions.text: Anthrax spores can remain dormant in the respiratory tract up to ________
questions.solution:
Anthrax spores can remain dormant in the respiratory tract for 6 weeks.  

Anthrax is caused by the gram-positive spore-forming rod Bacillus anthracis. Although not spread person to person, inhalation anthrax has a high mortality, has low infective dose (5 spores), and may be spread widely with aerosols after bioengineering and hence is a potential bioterrorism agent.

Because anthrax spores can remain dormant in the respiratory tract for 6 weeks, the incubation period can be quite long, and post-exposure are recommended for 60 days.

Related Pearl: Mechanism of action of various bacterial toxins

The mechanism of action of various bacterial toxins are as given below:

Increase in cAMP

  • Bordetella pertusis
  • Bacillus anthracis
  • Vibrio cholerae - Cholera toxin
  • Enterotoxigenic E.coli (ETEC) - heat labile toxin

Increase in cGMP

  • Enterotoxigenic E.coli (ETEC) - heat stable toxin

Inhibition of protein synthesis

  • Diptheria toxin: inhibit elongation factor-2 (EF-2)
  • Pseudomonas: inhibit elongation factor-2 (EF-2)
  • Clostridium difficile
  • Enterohemorrhagic E.coli (EHEC)-Shiga-like toxin: inhibit 60S
  • Shigella dysenteriae- Shiga toxin: inhibit 60S

Used to stain pathological specimens

Polychrome methylene blue is used in McFadyean’s reaction.
Neutral stains

Wright and Giemsa stains are Romanowsky stains used to stain peripheral blood and bone marrow smears.  

Giemsa stain is used for histopathological diagnosis of malaria and other protozoan blood parasites.  

 

B. Differential stains: Imparts different colors to different bacteria. (These contain more than one stain).

Type of stain Applications
Gram stain: To differentiate between gram positive (stain purple/violet) and gram negative bacteria (stain pink or red).
Acid-fast stain:  Used in Ziehl–Neelsen staining technique for identification of acid–fast microorganisms such as M. tuberculosis, M. leprae, and Nocardia.

questions.text: Carcinoid heart disease is characterized by glistening white intimal plaques mainly involving the tricuspid valve of the heart. Similar plaques can be produced by all of the following drugs except
questions.solution:
Digoxin does not produce any plaques like carcinoid heart disease. Rather it used to treat the heart failure caused by carcinoid heart disease.

Fenfluramine, Ergot alkaloids like ergotamine and methysergide tend to affect systemic serotonin metabolism. Hence in these conditions plaques similar to those found in Carcinoid heart disease are found.

The cardiac manifestations of carcinoid syndrome are caused by the paraneoplastic effects of vasoactive substances such as serotonin, histamine, tachykinins, and prostaglandins released by the malignant cells rather than any direct metastatic involvement of the heart.

questions.text: Regarding the given box-whisker plot, the true statement is:
questions.solution:
The given box-whisker plot represents a positively (or right) skewed distribution.  In a positively skewed distribution, the mean > median > mode.

To further understand and correlate the fact, have a look at the following images:

Related Pearl: Mean, Median, Mode in Different Distribution Shapes

  • The relationship between the mean, median and mode depends upon the distribution.
  • In a unimodal symmetrical distribution like a normal distribution, all the three measures are approximately the same, as shown in Figure (2) in the following image, i.e., mean = median = mode.
  • Figure (3) in the following image shows a positively skewed distribution in which the longer tail is towards the positive direction. In this, the mean will be larger than the median and mode, i.e., mean > median > mode.
  • Figure (1) in the following image shows a negatively skewed distribution in which the longer tail is towards the negative direction. In this, the mean will be smaller than the median, i.e., mean < median < mode.

Unimodal symmetrical distribution

Mean = Median = Mode

Positively (right) skewed distribution

Mean > Median > Mode

Negatively (left) skewed distribution

Mean < Median < Mode
  • As seen in the figures above, in any distribution curve, the mode is generally the highest point. The mean will be pulled up or down based on the values in the distribution. The median will lie between the mode and mean and divide the distribution in two equal halves under the curve.
  • A bimodal distribution will have two high points as shown in the image below.
  • Mathematically, the relationship between mode, median and mean in asymmetrical distributions can be given as:
    Mode = 3 median – 2 mean (or) Mean = ½ (3 median – mode).
  • Outlier is the statistical term used for an observation or value that is very distant from other observations in the distribution.
  • In a distribution with outliers, preferred measure of central tendency is the median.
  • Mode is least affected by outliers but mean is the most affected out of all the measures of location.

Related Pearl: Box and Whisker Plot

  • A box and whisker plot is used to show variation in a set of data.
  • They can summarize data from various sources and display it in a single graph.
  • A box and whisker plot is usually based on median, quartiles and percentiles.
  • It is also called a box plot.
  • In the box plot as shown in the image, a simple box is divided into two by the median value. Above and below it are the whiskers. The top and bottom ends of the whiskers are the highest and lowest value of that group. 
  • A box plot can help in identifying outliers and the interquartile range (IQR), as shown in the image below.

questions.solution:
This semen analysis result is suggestive of Teratozoospermia  

Abnormal sperm morphology is termed as teratozoospermia. When normal morphology of the sample falls below 4 percent, it is suggestive of teratozoospermia.  

Asthenospermia is decreased sperm motility < 40%

questions.text: Urine LAM is used for the diagnosis of ___________
questions.solution:
Urine lipoarabinomannan (LAM) assay is used for the diagnosis of tuberculosis.

Lipoarabinomannan (LAM) antigen is a lipopolysaccharide present in mycobacterial cell wall. It is released from metabolically active cells or degenerating cells of patients having tuberculosis. Urine LAM testing is especially useful in diagnosing TB in patients with HIV and low CD 4 counts.

questions.text: Cardiovascular effect of this new drug(X) that activates autonomic receptors is shown below.The most probable receptor affinities of the new drug(X) are
questions.solution:
A decrease in mean blood pressure, an increase in pulse pressure, plus a marked increase in heart rate are characteristic of a drug such as isoproterenol.  

It has receptor affinities for β1, β2.  

PVR and mean BP are decreased because of activation of β2 receptors in the vasculature.  

Systolic BP remains the same or increases because of activation of β1 receptors in the heart, leading to an increase in stroke volume, as well as the increase in heart rate.

questions.text: A child presents with neonatal hypotonia, tachypnoea, abnormal eye movements, and mental retardation. On axial imaging, the fourth ventricle is abnormally shaped with a ‘batwing appearance’ as given below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the image showing the Molar tooth sign suggest the diagnosis of Joubert syndrome. The image shows an axial T2 weighted image at the level of superior cerebellar peduncles demonstrating the molar tooth sign.

Joubert syndrome:

These are a group of recessive congenital ataxia disorders in which typically there is

  • Neonatal hypotonia
  • Tachypnoea
  • Abnormal eye movements
  • Mental retardation associated with a particular pattern of cerebellar dysgenesis with a molar tooth-type malformation and vermis hypoplasia

MRI features :

  • The cardinal feature is the presence of a molar tooth sign which is created by a combination of
    • Midbrain hypoplasia with an
    • Abnormally deep interpeduncular fossa and
    • A failure of the superior cerebellar peduncles to decussate across the midline.
  • On axial imaging, the fourth ventricle is abnormally shaped with a batwing appearance
  • Cerebellar hypoplasia
  • Midline vermian cleft
  • Dysplastic small vermis
  • The midbrain is small

Related Pearl: Investigation of choice in Neurology

Generally, MRI is considered the best imaging for the spinal cord and nerves.

Conditions in which MRI is used include:

  • Optic neuritis
  • Vestibular schwannoma
  • Multiple sclerosis
  • Pituitary adenoma
  • Spinal cord tumor
  • Neurofibroma
  • Viral encephalitis
  • Hippocampal volumetry.

CT scan is preferred when the timing is critical. So, the investigation of choice for stroke is an NCCT. This helps to rule out hemorrhagic stroke.

The investigation of choice for ischemic stroke is a diffusion-weighted MRI.

questions.text: Identify the condition seen in this X-ray.
questions.solution:
This X ray shows a typical finding of multiple gas-filled cysts of the gastrointestinal tract which is indicative of Pneumatosis intestinalis.

It is an uncommon condition where cysts may be located in the subserosa, submucosa, and, rarely, muscularis layer and vary in size from microscopic to several centimeters in diameter.

Pneumatosis not associated with other lesions is referred to as primary pneumatosis.

questions.text: A 48-year-old male patient presented with severe restlessness, palpitations, facial flushing, and sweating. The patient had an episode of dysentery 2 days prior and had been prescribed medication for that. The patient reports taking alcohol 2 hours after his medications. Which of the following drug does not cause similar effects?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a patient developing symptoms like restlessness and flushing after taking alcohol after medication is suggestive of a disulfiram-like reaction. Among the given drugs, ofloxacin is not associated with a disulfiram-like reaction.

Some important drugs which cause a disulfiram-like reaction are:

  • Metronidazole, Tinidazole
  • Some cephalosporins like cefoperazone
  • 1st generation sulfonylureas like tolbutamide
  • Procarbazine

These drugs inhibit aldehyde dehydrogenase, similar to disulfiram. When alcohol is combined with these drugs, acetaldehyde accumulates and causes unpleasant symptoms like flushing, sweating, tachycardia, hypotension, nausea, vomiting, dizziness, and headache.

questions.text: A patient presented with the following cutaneous finding to the dermatology OPD. Which of the following organisms is least likely to cause this?
questions.solution:
The serpiginous/serpent-like skin lesions seen are cutaneous larva migrans or larva currens. Ancylostoma duodenale and Necator americanus are hookworms that cause human infection and are least likely to cause cutaneous larva migrans.

Cutaneous larva migrans is caused by non-human hookworms like Ancylostoma braziliense, Ancylostoma caninum acquired from direct skin contact with soil contaminated by dog or cat feces. 

Serpentine or linear single-track lines later mark the course of the larvae as they migrate through the epidermis of the trunk and lower extremities. Symptoms begin to appear within the first two weeks of the patient’s return from a tropical or endemic country. The larval track progresses at approximately 1 cm/h with cutaneous lesions only progressing a few millimeters to a few centimeters daily.

Larva currens aka 'running larva’ of Strongyloidiasis stercoralis. It is known for its distinct rapidity, with the larval track progressing at approximately 0.2 cm/min, with cutaneous lesions progressing up to 10 cm/hour. 

Ivermectin is the preferred treatment and is given at 0.15–0.2 mg/kg every day per oral for 1 or 2 days.

questions.text: Pandu, a 24-year-old man with a history of depression is brought to the emergency department after being found confused in his garage. He has a high anion gap metabolic acidosis, elevated serum creatinine, and dumbbell-shaped crystals are seen in his urine on microscopic analysis. Ethylene glycol level is pending. Arterial pH is 7.33. Measured serum osmolality is 320 mmol; serum sodium is 140, blood urea nitrogen (BUN) is 28, and glucose is 180. What is the next appropriate step?

choices.text: Await ethylene glycol level before initiating therapy
Start intravenous antibiotics and obtain renal imaging to evaluate for staghorn calculi

questions.solution:
This patient is suffering from ethylene glycol (antifreeze; used in engine coolants) toxicity and hence the next step is to administer fomepizole.

Diagnosis is facilitated by high anion gap metabolic acidosis, the presence of an osmolar gap (both attributable to metabolites of ethylene glycol- oxalic acid and glycolic acid) and recognition of oxalate crystals in urine.

Here, the osmolar gap is 20 [{calculated osmolality is 2(Na)+BUN/2.8+glucose/18=300};measured osmolality- calculated osmolality= 320-300=20].

The combination of a high anion gap and a high osmolar gap in a patient suspected of ethylene glycol ingestion should be considered as a case of ethylene glycol toxicity. And treatment should not be delayed awaiting the report of ethylene glycol level in this setting.

Treatment includes prompt administration of saline or osmotic diuresis, thiamine and pyridoxine supplements, fomepizole and if needed, hemodialysis.

The IV administration of the alcohol dehydrogenase inhibitor, fomepizole (4-methylpyrazole; 15 mg/kg as loading dose) is the treatment of choice. IV ethanol, if used, should be infused to achieve a blood level off 22 mmol/L (100 mg/dL). Both fomepizole and ethanol reduce toxicity because they compete with ethylene glycol for metabolism by alcohol dehydrogenase.

Haemodialysis is indicated when the arterial pH is <7.3 or the osmolar gap exceeds 20 mOsm/kg.

questions.text: All of the following clinical conditions can lead to L-lactic acidosis except?
questions.solution:
Short bowel syndrome is associated with D-lactic acidosis and not L-lactic acidosis.  

D-lactic acidosis which may be associated with jejunoileal bypass, short bowel syndrome, or intestinal obstruction, is due to the formation of D-lactate by gut bacteria.  

The other forms of lactic acidosis typically seen in situations of inadequate oxygen delivery to tissues are due to elevations of intrinsically produced L-lactic acid.

questions.text: The drug that is least preferred to treat infections of Acinetobacter among the following is ____________
questions.solution:
Fosfomycin has poor activity against Acinetobacter and hence is not used for the treatment of Acinetobacter infections.  

Polymyxins(Polymyxins B and Colistin) and tigecycline are used for carbepenam resistant strains.  

Sulbactum, Trimethoprim-Sulphomethoxazole, Meropenam and Amikacin are other commonly used drugs against Acinetobacter.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a clinical feature of St. Anthony’s fire?
questions.solution:
Dry gangrene, and not wet gangrene, is a feature of St. Anthony's fire.  

St. Anthony's fire is another name for ergotism. Ergot alkaloids exert their primary CNS effects by stimulating adrenergic receptors, both centrally and peripherally.  

Clinical features

  • Acute poisoning:
    • GI - Nausea, vomiting, diarrhea
    • CNS effects - Headache, giddiness
    • Respiratory - Chest tightness, difficulty in breathing
    • Musculoskeletal - Weakness, exhaustion, tingling, numbness, paresthesia 
  • Chronic poisoning:
    • Tingling and numbness
    • Dry gangrene due to vasomotor disturbance
    • Tactile hallucination - Formication

questions.text: Which of the two vaccines given below enlisted in the National Immunisation Schedule have the same route of administration?
questions.solution:
BCG and fIPV are both administered 0.1 ml intradermally in the left and right upper arm respectively according to the National Immunisation schedule.

Earlier IPV was given as single dose of 0.5 ml intramuscular (IM) injection in thigh at 14 weeks. Now, two fractionated doses of IPV (fIPV) of 0.1 ml given intradermally at 6 and 14 weeks which produces better immunogenicity than the previous one. 

Other options:

Option A: Rabies can be given intra dermally but however it is not included in the National Immunisation Schedule. Hence not the right answer.

Option C: JE- 1 and measles vaccines are administered subcutaneously.

Option D:  Hepatitis B is given intramuscularly immediately after birth or within 24 hours of birth.

questions.text: A burns victim passes away 96 hours after sustaining burns. The probable cause of death is:
questions.solution:
Septic shock is the probable cause of death in this patient. 

In burns, the most common cause of

  • Death at the site of Burns - Asphyxia
  • Early death - Hypovolemic Shock
  • Late Death - Septicemia
  • Overall Deaths - Septicemia

questions.text: Post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis in children is diagnosed by______

choices.text: Heavy proteinuria, high cholesterol, high ASO titre
Heavy proteinuria, hematuria, low ASO titre
Mild proteinuria, hematuria, high ASO titre
Mild proteinuria, high cholesterol, normal ASO titre

questions.solution:
Post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis is a classical example of nephritic syndrome characterized by 

  • Hematuria
  • Mild proteinuria,
  • Elevated levels of antistreptolysin O (ASO) and anti-DNAase antibodies (indicative of streptococcal infection) and
  • Reduced levels of serum C3.

Glomerular Syndromes

Acute nephritis, proteinuria, and acute renal failure

Azotemia and uremia progressing for many years

questions.text: Which of the following is routinely used for suturing the cornea in penetrating keratoplasty?
questions.solution:
10-0 Nylon sutures are used for suturing of the cornea after transplantation.  

After injecting vis­coelastic material to fill the anterior chamber, the donor cornea is placed in the host bed and sutured in place using 16 interrupted sutures or a combination of inter­rupted and continuous sutures of 10-0 nylon.

Size 10-0 nylon monofilament sutures are routinely used because they are less likely to cause inflammation

questions.text: Cyanide blocks citric acid cycle by blocking which of the following ?
questions.solution:
Cyanide blocks citric acid cycle by blocking NAD+.

Cyanide blocks complex 4 of the electron transport chain, thereby directly inhibiting electron transport, causing ↓ proton gradient and block ATP synthesis.

As a result electron carriers NADH and FADH cannot unload their electrons, thus reducing the concentration of NAD+ and FAD+ which is required for the Kreb’s cycle to proceed.

Related Pearl: Electron transport chain: components and its inhibitors

questions.text: According to the International Health Regulations, on diagnosing a patient with which of the following diseases is notification not mandatory in all countries?
questions.solution:
According to the International Health Regulations(IHR), notification is not mandatory if a patient is diagnosed with tuberculosis in all countries.

It needs to be notified only by the countries where the public health impact is serious and there is a risk of international spread.

The government of India made the reporting of new cases of TB mandatory for all medical practitioners from 2012. An online web-based application named Nikshay is available for this purpose. Treatment providers are given a nominal cash incentive of Rs.1000/- per TB patient reported.

questions.text: Which of the following determines the sex of the fetus?
questions.solution:
The sex of the fetus is determined by Yp11, which is a region present on the short arm of the Y chromosome.

It contains the SRY gene, which produces the protein called the testis determining factor. This causes the gonads to develop into the testes. The target gene for SRY which favours testis differentiation is SOX9.

If SRY gene or Y chromosome are absent, the gonads develop as ovaries. The genes that favor this are:

  • WnT4
  • Rspo
  • DAX1

Related Pearl: Sexual Differentiation

questions.text: Inflammatory markers are used to assess a patient’s general level of inflammation.  ESR(Erythrocyte Sedimentation Rate) and CRP (C reactive protein) are  __________ and ___________ measures of acute phase response respectively
questions.solution:
ESR(Erythrocyte Sedimentation Rate) and CRP (C reactive protein) are indirect and direct measures of acute phase response respectively.  

ESR changes relatively slowly as it is an indirect measure and is measured once a week.

CRP changes more rapidly, consistent with being a direct measure and daily measures may be necessary.

Note : Although these markers are sensitive indicators of inflammation, neither is very specific.

questions.text: All of the following are characteristics of a difficult airway except?

choices.text: More than one attempt at intubation with the same laryngoscopic blade.
Need for a change in langryngoscopic blade.
Need for an alternative intubation technique or rescue.

questions.solution:
More than two attempts, not one, at intubation with the same laryngoscopic blade is one of the characteristics of a difficult airway.

The American Society of Anesthesiologists defines a difficult airway as difficulty with bag-mask ventilation, difficulty with tracheal ventilation, or both.

Other characteristics of a difficult airway include:

  • More than two attempts at intubation with the same laryngoscopic blade.
  • Need for a change in blade or use of intubation stylet.
  • Need for an alternative intubation technique.

Related Pearl: Predictors of Difficult Airway

Risk factors:

  1. Obstructive sleep apnea
  2. History of snoring
  3. Obesity
  4. Facial and neck deformities from previous surgery
  5. Previous head and neck radiation
  6. Head and neck trauma
  7. Congenital abnormalities of the head and neck
  8. Rheumatoid arthritis
  9. Down syndrome
  10. Scleroderma
  11. Cervical spine disease or previous cervical spine surgery

Specific tests for assessment:

  1. Mallampati scores (III and IV)
  2. Thyromental distance less than 6 cm
  3. Sterno-mental distance <12.5 cm with head in maximum extension
  4. Increased neck circumference >17 inches in men or >16 inches in women
  5. Upper lip bite test: Inability to protrude the mandible or lower teeth in front of the upper teeth
  6. Cormack and Lehane (laryngoscopic view) - Grade III and IV

Although the presence of these risk factors may not be sensitive in detecting difficult intubation, the absence of these findings indicates ease with intubation.

questions.text: Cofactor for glycogen phosphorylase, an important enzyme in glycogenolysis pathway, is also used for the synthesis of which of the following?
questions.solution:
Vitamin B6 - pyridoxine which is converted to pyridoxal phosphate(PLP) is the cofactor for glycogen phosphorylase.

It also acts as a cofactor for the synthesis of

  • Neurotransmitters serotonin, epinephrine, norepinephrine, dopamine and GABA
  • Cystathionine
  • Heme
  • Niacin
  • Histamine

Other options:

Glutathione(GSH) is a tripeptide, γ -glutamyl-cysteinyl-glycine, which readily undergoes oxidation to form a disulphide linked hexapeptide, oxidized glutathione(GSSG).
Functions of glutathione include:

  • Phase 2 metabolism of electrophilic compounds forming glutathione conjugates to be excreted into bile and urine.
  • It provides the reductant for the reduction of potentially toxic hydrogen peroxide to water in the reaction catalyzed by glutathione peroxidase.
  • It is an important intracellular reductant and antioxidant, helping to maintain essential -SH groups of enzymes in their reduced state.
  • GSH as a carrier has been used in the transport of some amino acids across membranes in the kidney.

Creatine is derived from glycine and arginine with cofactor vitamin B12.

Melanin is derived from tyrosine by hydroxylation by tyrosinase enzyme requiring copper.

 

Related Pearl: Amino Acid Derivatives

questions.text: If a drug is known to be distributed into the total body water, what dose of the drug is needed to obtain an initial plasma level of 5 mg/L in a male patient weighing 70 kg?
questions.solution:
The drug dose needed to achieve initial plasma concentration is the loading dose, which is 210 mg in this case.

The equation for loading dose or the volume of the distribution equation can be used for calculation.
Loading Dose = Vd × Cp

Since the patient weighs 70 kg and 60% of his body weight is water, he has 42 L (70 L x 60%) of total body water.
Loading Dose = 42 L × 5 mg/L = 210 mg.

questions.text: Which of the following structures form the angle of anteversion?
questions.solution:
The angle of anteversion is formed between the long axis of the cervix and the long axis of the vagina.

The angle of anteflexion which is formed by the body of the uterus and the long axis of the cervix.

When the whole of the uterus leans backwards at an angle to the vagina, it is called retroversion. If the uterus angles backwards in relation to cervix it is called retroflexion.

questions.text:
Which of the following is incorrectly matched?

A - Diamnionic, dichorionic separate

B - Diamnionic, dichorionic fused

C - Diamnionic, monochorionic

choices.text: All three (A, B, and C) are correct

questions.solution:
All three images (A, B, and C) are correctly matched.

  • Image A – Represents Diamnionic, Dichorionic – separated placentation. Separation of the first two blastomeres results in separate implantation sites.
  • Image B - Represents Diamnionic, dichorionic - fused placentation in twins. Here the chorionic membranes are fused but the fetuses occupy separate choria.
  • Image C – Represents Diamnionic, Monochorionic placentation. Reduplication of the inner cell mass can result in a single placenta and chorionic sacs but separate amniotic cavities.

questions.text: A 12-year-old girl presents with a lower abdominal mobile cystic mass that extends up to the umbilicus. O/E finger insinuation between the mass and pubic bone is not possible. The probable diagnosis is?
questions.solution:
The probable diagnosis, in this case, is an ovarian cyst.  

Inability to pass the finger between the mass and pubic bone suggests a pelvic origin for the tumor and the only feasible option among those given is Ovarian cyst. Others are abdominal, not intrapelvic.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common type of adverse event in the inpatient settings?
questions.solution:
Adverse drug events are the most common type of adverse event in the inpatient settings.

An adverse event is defined as an injury caused by medical management rather than the underlying disease of the patient.

According to the Harvard Medical Practice Study (one of the largest studies to quantify adverse events in hospitalized patients), the most common adverse events were adverse drug events, which occurred in 19% of hospitalizations. 

Other common adverse events included

  • wound infection (14%) and
  • technical complications of a procedure (13%).

Among non-operative events,

  • 37% were adverse drug events,
  • 15% were diagnostic mishaps,
  • 14% were therapeutic mishaps and
  • 5% were falls.

58% of these adverse events were considered preventable.

questions.text: An AIDS patient on treatment with  AZT, lamivudine, indinavir, ketoconazole, and cotrimoxazole, develops breast hypertrophy, central adiposity, hyperlipidemia, insulin resistance, and nephrolithiasis. Which of the following drugs could have caused these?
questions.solution:
Indinavir, a protease inhibitor, is the most likely cause for these adverse effects.

Patients being treated with protease inhibitors (e.g., indinavir) develop a syndrome involving the derangement of lipid metabolism. This causes changes in body fat distribution. Type 2 diabetes mellitus has also been reported. This is called HIV/HAART-associated lipodystrophy.

Indinavir can also precipitate in the urinary tract, causing nephrolithiasis, unless the patient is maintained in a high state of hydration.

Indinavir binds to the site of HIV-1 protease activity and inhibits cleavage of viral gag-pol polyprotein precursors into individual functional proteins required for infectious HIV. This results in the formation of immature, non-infectious viral particles.

Option A: Azidothymidine or zidovudine, is a nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitor. Chronic zidovudine administration has been associated with nail hyperpigmentation. 

Option C: Ketoconazole is an antifungal agent that inhibits fungal ergosterol synthesis. Its adverse effects include liver dysfunction and testosterone synthesis inhibition leading to gynecomastia. 

Option D: Lamivudine is a nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitor. It is one of the least toxic antiretroviral drugs. Neutropenia, headache, and nausea have been reported at higher-than-recommended doses.

questions.text: Which among the following drugs does not require any renal dose modification in those with chronic kidney disease?
questions.solution:
Linagliptin is a competitive dipeptidyl peptidase - 4 inhibitor does not require any renal dose modification.  

Linagliptin binds extensively to plasma proteins and is cleared primarily by the hepatobiliary system, with very little renal clearance.   Saxagliptin is another DPP - 4 inhibitor that binds covalently.

Saxagliptin and other DPP - 4 inhibitors circulate primarily in unbound form and are excreted largely unchanged in the urine. Renal dose modification is required in patients with reduced renal function.  

Repaglinide is a non sulfonylurea insulin secretagogue. A proportion of the drug is eliminated by the kidney and dose modification is required.  

Glyburide is a sulfonylurea insulin secretagogue which is metabolised in the liver and the metabolites are excreted in the urine. Thus it requires dose modification in both renal and hepatic insufficiency.

questions.text: Which of the following mimics lead poisoning?
questions.solution:
• δ-Aminolevulinic acid dehydratase porphyria (ALAD) is similar to lead poisoning.
  • It is also called Plumboporphyria/Doss porphyria due to its clinical similarity to lead poisoning, though not related to lead exposure.
  • ALAD catalyses the condensation of 2 molecules of ALA to form the pyrrole PBG.
  • The enzyme is subject to inhibition by lead because ALAD is the principal lead-binding protein in erythrocytes, and lead can displace the zinc atoms of the enzyme, thus inhibiting it.
  • Therefore, both lead poisoning and ALAD porphyria produce similar signs and symptoms.
  • Symptoms resemble other acute porphyrias, including acute attacks of abdominal pain and neuropathy.

Related Pearl: Types of porphyria

Clinically porphyrias can be classified into:

  • Hepatic porphyria: The overproduction of heme pathway intermediates occurs primarily in the liver.
  • Erythropoietic porphyria: The overproduction of heme pathway intermediates occurs primarily in bone marrow erythroid cells.
