questions.text: A young man presented with hypertensive episodes, bloody stools and cutaneous nodules. He has a past history of hepatitis B infection. Vasculitis was suspected and a biopsy of the vessel was done. The histopathology of the tissue from the vessel is shown below. Identify the type of necrosis.
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of polyarteritis nodosa and the above image depicts fibrinoid necrosis. It is seen in vasculitis like polyarteritis nodosa (PAN) in which the small and medium-sized blood vessels are affected as a result of immune complex deposition.

Polyarteritis nodosa is a medium and small-sized vessel vasculitis typically affecting the renal and visceral arteries, sparing pulmonary vessels. Patients present with variable symptoms including accelerated hypertension, abdominal pain, gastrointestinal bleeding, myalgias and cutaneous nodules. It is often associated with chronic hepatitis B infection, which causes the HBsAg-HbsAb complexes to deposit in affected vessels. Clinical manifestations are a result of ischemia and infarction of organs and tissues that are affected.

The diagnosis is based on the histopathological findings seen on a biopsy of the involved organs. Diagnosis can also be made by the demonstration of aneurysms of small and medium-sized arteries in the renal, hepatic, and visceral vasculature. 

Fibrinoid necrosis occurs in blood vessels in which the antigen-antibody complexes get deposited in the blood vessel walls. These complexes elicit an immune reaction leading to cell injury and leakage of fibrin and plasma proteins around the blood vessel and giving a circumferential pinkish appearance of necrosis. 

It is treated with immunosuppressive agents and has a high risk of mortality if left untreated.

The image below shows fibrinoid necrosis with intraluminal thrombosis in an artery of a patient with polyarteritis nodosa. 

Necrosis refers to irreversible cell death caused by the denaturation of proteins and enzymatic digestion of the injured cells. 

Gangrenous necrosis commonly occurs in the lower limbs due to decreased blood supply. This type of necrosis is usually coagulative necrosis and is called dry gangrene.

When this becomes superimposed with bacterial infection the harmful enzymes from the bacteria and inflammatory cells result in liquefactive necrosis which is called wet gangrene.

Caseous necrosis (cheese like) refers to a friable yellow white area of necrosis as seen in this image

  • On microscopic examination, the necrotic focus appears as a collection of fragmented or lysed cells with an amorphous granular pink appearance surrounded by inflammatory cells called as granuloma and is classical of tuberculosis as shown below.

Fat necrosis refers to the localised destruction of fat by pancreatic enzymes. The commonest cause of this type of necrosis is acute pancreatitis. In acute pancreatitis, these enzymes are released within or around the pancreas breaking down the triglycerides into fatty acids. When calcium binds to fatty acid it results in fat saponification giving a chalky white appearance.

Polyarteritis nodosa is a medium and small-sized vessel vasculitis typically affecting the renal and visceral arteries. Patients present with variable symptoms including accelerated hypertension, abdominal pain, gastrointestinal bleeding, myalgias and cutaneous nodules. It is often associated with chronic hepatitis B infection. Histology shows characteristic fibrinoid necrosis of the vessel wall with intraluminal thrombosis. This condition is treated with immunosuppressive agents and has a high risk of mortality.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents with classic pill rolling resting tremor and gait disturbances. The area of the brain most likely to be involved is
questions.solution:
The given case scenario suggests a diagnosis of Parkinson’s disease (PD) and the area most likely to be involved is substantia nigra, a part of the mesencephalon (midbrain).

The hallmark features of PD are degeneration of dopaminergic neurons in the substantia nigra pars compacta (SNc), reduced striatal dopamine, and intracytoplasmic proteinaceous inclusions known as Lewy bodies (containing the protein alpha synuclein).

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding labia majora?

choices.text: They join posteriorly to form the posterior commissure
It is homologous to scrotum in male
The round ligament terminates at its posterior end
It contains sebaceous glands and apocrine glands

questions.solution:
The round ligament terminates at the anterior end of the labia majora.

The labia majora lie on either side of the vulva and join posteriorly to form the posterior commissure. The inner side is hairless. Labia majora are homologous to the scrotum in males. The labia majora and the mons veneris contain:

  • Hair follicles
  • Sebaceous glands
  • Modified sweat glands, known as apocrine glands

The labia minora are two cutaneous folds between the labia major. Anteriorly they enclose the clitoris and unite with each other in front and behind the clitoris to form prepuce and frenulum respectively. The labia minora are homologous to the ventral aspect of the penis.

The clitoris is a small erectile body lying in the anterior-most part of the vulva. The clitoris is homologous to glans penis.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male presents with a testicular mass. It is likely to be ______
questions.solution:
A testicular mass in a male > 50 years of age is regarded as a lymphoma until proven otherwise.  

Testicular germ cell tumors occur commonly in the age group of 20-40 years.  

Hydrocoele presents as a cystic scrotal swelling, not as a testicular mass    

Related Pearl: Most common testicular tumors

Pre-pubertal age group Yolk sac tumor
15–34 years Germ-cell tumors
Adults Seminomatous and non-seminomatous
Elderly age group Lymphoma
Germ-cell testicular tumor Seminoma
Bilateral testicular tumor Lymphoma

 

Related Pearl: TNM staging of testicular tumour: American Joint Committee on Cancer (AJCC) and Union Internationale Contre le Cancer (UICC)

Primary tumor (T)

The extent of the primary tumor is usually classified after radical orchiectomy (except for pTis and pT4) and, for this reason, a pathologic (p) stage is assigned.

pTx - Primary tumor cannot be assessed

pT0 - No evidence of primary tumor (e.g., a histologic scar in testis)

pTis -  Germ-cell neoplasia in situ

pT1 - Tumor limited to the testis and epididymis without vascular/lymphatic invasion; tumor may invade into tunica albuginea but not tunica vaginalis

pT2 - Tumor limited to testis and epididymis with vascular/lymphatic invasion or tumor extending through the tunica albuginea, with the involvement of tunica vaginalis

pT3 - Tumor invades spermatic cord with or without vascular/lymphatic invasion

pT4 - Tumor invades the scrotum with or without vascular/lymphatic invasion

Regional lymph nodes (N)

NX - Regional lymph nodes cannot be assessed

N0 - No regional lymph node metastasis

N1 - Metastasis with lymph node mass ≤2 cm in greatest dimension; or multiple lymph nodes, none more than 2 cm in greatest dimension

N2 - Metastasis with lymph node mass, 2–5 cm in greatest dimension; or multiple lymph nodes, anyone mass >2 cm but not more than 5 cm in greatest dimension

N3 - Metastasis with lymph node mass >5 cm in greatest dimension

Distant metastasis (M)

MX - Distant metastasis cannot be assessed

M0 - No distant metastasis

M1 - Distant metastasis

M1a - Nonregional nodal or pulmonary metastasis

M1b - Distant metastasis at site other than nonregional lymph nodes or lung

SX - Marker studies unavailable or not performed

S0 - Marker study levels within normal limits

LDH <1.5 × N 1.5–10 × N  >10×N
hCG(MIU/mL) <5000 5000–50,000  >50,000

questions.text: In Cushing Syndrome, the mineralocorticoid effects are because of

choices.text: Glucocorticoid and mineralocorticoid receptors are not specific as the mineralocorticoid receptor also binds glucocorticoids with high affinity.
11β-hydroxysteroid dehydrogenase in renal tubular cells that usually inactivates glucocorticoids, allowing selective responses to mineralocorticoid gets saturated.
11β-hydroxysteroid dehydrogenase in renal tubular cells that usually inactivates glucocorticoids, allowing selective responses to mineralocorticoid gets inactivated.

questions.solution:
11β-hydroxysteroid dehydrogenase in renal tubular cells that usually inactivates glucocorticoids, allowing selective responses to mineralocorticoid gets saturated.  

Normally, 11β-hydroxysteroid dehydrogenase in renal tubular cells inactivates glucocorticoids, allowing selective responses to mineralocorticoid.

When very high glucocorticoid concentrations occur, as in Cushing’s syndrome, the glucocorticoid degradation pathway becomes saturated, allowing excessive cortisol levels to exert mineralocorticoid effects  (sodium retention, potassium wasting).  

This phenomenon is particularly pronounced in ectopic adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH) syndromes  

Related Pearl: Causes of Cushing's Syndrome

Exogenous causes (iatrogenic)

  • Prolonged administration of glucocorticoids (most common cause of Cushing's)

Endogenous causes

  • ACTH independent (primary hypercortisolism)
    • Adrenocortical adenoma 
    • Adrenocortical carcinoma 
    • Bilateral adrenal hyperplasia
  • ACTH dependent (secondary hypercortisolism)
    • Cushing’s disease: ACTH secreting pituitary adenoma (most common cause of endogenous Cushing's)
    • Paraneoplastic causes: Ectopic ACTH secreting tumors
      • Small-cell lung carcinoma
      • Bronchial or pancreatic carcinoid tumors
      • Medullary thyroid carcinoma
      • Pheochromocytoma

Rare causes

  • Macronodular adrenal hyperplasia
  • Primary pigmented nodular adrenal disease
  • McCune – Albright syndrome

Related Pearl: Initial Tests for Diagnosing Cushing's Syndrome

These include two steps:

1. Tests to detect hypercortisolism

  • Midnight salivary or serum cortisol (highly sensitive test): The presence of cortisol in the saliva or serum at midnight signifies loss of diurnal variation of cortisol
  • 24-hour urinary free cortisol excretion: Increased three times the normal value
  • Overnight dexamethasone suppression test (DST): Plasma cortisol >1.8 μg/dL at 8 a.m after overnight exposure to dexamethasone (1 mg given at 11 p.m)
  • Low dose DST (highly specific test): Plasma cortisol >1.8 μg/dL at 8 a.m. on the third day after giving 0.5 mg dexamethasone every 6 hours for 2 days

2. Test to rule out pseudo Cushing's syndrome

  • Low-dose DST + CRH stimulation test: Plasma cortisol levels are increased in true Cushing’s but remain unaffected in pseudo Cushing's. Dexa-induced negative feedback is overcome by CRH in true Cushing’s.

questions.text: A person is brought to the emergency department following a blast. On investigation, a small metallic foreign body is found entrapped in the lens of his right eye. What is the best treatment option?
questions.solution:
For a patient with a foreign body in the lens, the best treatment option is complete removal of the lens.

If a foreign body lies within the lens, it is better to treat such particles as if they were non-magnetic or to remove the lens as a whole. For a non-magnetic foreign body:-

  • The foreign body on iris it can usually be picked out by an iris forceps through a suitably placed keratome incision. If entangled an iridectomy is performed.
  • If the foreign body is in the lens, a few days should be allowed to elapse for the aqueous to act upon the lens fibers. Aspiration is then performed and the foreign body is removed with the lens matter.
  • If the foreign body lies on the retina, and if accurate localization has been attained, it is removed directly by intra-vitreal forceps as part of a complete vitrectomy. Laser photocoagulation of the surrounding retina is also done to prevent a late retinal detachment.

questions.text: Project “Axshya” is in relation to controlling which of the following disease?
questions.solution:
Project Axshya was launched in 2010 to control TB. Axshya means ‘free from TB’ which is the ultimate goal of the project and the national TB programme.

Project Axshya is being implemented by The International Union Against Tuberculosis and Lung Disease (known simply as The Union). The project works to improve access to quality TB care and control through a partnership between government and civil society.

The guiding principles of project Axshya are:

  • Universal access to quality TB services
  • Community participation in TB care and control
  • Sustainable interventions and equitable distribution of project benefits with social and gender sensitivity

questions.text: All of the following statements are true regarding the use of enteral feeding for critically ill patients except?

choices.text: Enteral feeding increases splanchnic blood flow.
Enteral feeding stimulates secretion of gastrointestinal hormones to promote tropic gut activity.
Immunoglobulin G antibody release is stimulated by enteral feeding.
Seventy percent of nutrients used by the gut are directly derived food within the lumen of the gut.

questions.solution:
Immunoglobulin A (and not IgG) antibody release is stimulated by enteral feeding.

When possible, at least a portion of the nutritional support given to a critically ill patient should be in the form of enteral form of nutrition. Seventy percent of the nutrients utilized by the bowel and its associated organs are directly derived from food within the bowel lumen.

Moreover, enteral feedings are important for maintaining the immunological function of the gut as they stimulate secretion of IgA and hormones to promote the trophic activity of the gut.

In addition, the enteral feedings improve splanchnic blood flow and stimulate neuronal activity to prevent ischemia and paralytic ileus.

Related Pearl: Complications of enteral nutrition

1. Tube-related (most common):

  • Malposition
  • Displacement
  • Blockage
  • Breakage/leakage
  • Local complications (e.g. erosion of skin/mucosa)

2. Gastrointestinal:

  • Diarrhoea
  • Bloating, nausea, vomiting
  • Abdominal cramps
  • Aspiration
  • Constipation

3. Metabolic/biochemical:

  • Electrolyte disorders
  • Vitamin, mineral, trace element deficiencies
  • Drug interactions

4. Infective:

  • Exogenous (handling contamination)
  • Endogenous (patient)

questions.text: A 22-year-old female undergoes emergency C section. 1 hour postoperatively, you notice blood loss from her genital tract. The amount of blood loss to consider it PPH (PostPartum Hemorrhage) will be
questions.solution:
1000 ml blood loss from genital tract is considered PPH after a C section.  

Loss of more than 500ml of blood after completion of the third stage of labor in vaginal delivery is considered as PPH.

Recent Update :

PPH is classically defined by the volume of blood loss. But this definition will soon become obsolete due to its unreliability as the bleeding may not be visible externally, or blood in collection devices may be mixed with the amniotic fluid.

In 2017, the American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists revised their definition of PPH to

  • Cumulative blood loss of ≥1000 mL or
  • Bleeding associated with signs/symptoms of hypovolemia within 24 hours of the birth process (regardless of the route of delivery )

questions.text: On clinical examination, you find sensory loss in the region indicated. You would expect a deficit in:

choices.text: No associated motor weakness will be present

questions.solution:
The image shows Regimental Badge Sign. It is seen in Axillary nerve injuries. Axillary nerve supplies the deltoid which is responsible for abduction 15-90 degrees.

Other options:

  • Initiation of Abduction is not affected as it is caused by supraspinatus.
  • Overhead abduction is the function of serratus anterior and trapezius muscles and hence is not affected.
  • The posterior branch of axillary nerve supplies, teres minor and posterior of deltoid and terminates as the cutaneous nerve of armwhich supplies the skin over the lower half of deltoid. Deltoid muscle palsy can lead to loss of rounded contour of shoulder and palsy of lateral cutaneous nerve of arm are other significant features.

questions.text: On examining a case of wet drowning, you observe weights that are attached to the body to keep it underwater. What does this suggest?

choices.text: Can be either homicidal or suicidal

questions.solution:
Attachment of weights to the body to keep it underwater is consistent with both homicidal and suicidal drowning.

Differentiating points:

  • Suicidal drowning - determined suicidal person may attach weights to the body or tie his limbs. It is common among women. 
  • Homicidal drowning - the following additional features may point to a homicidal drowning:
    • Constriction/marks around the neck may be present
    • Evidence of struggle at the banks of the river from where the body was recovered
    • Articles belonging to someone other than the deceased found on the banks of the river associated with those belonging to the deceased

Accidental drowning is the most common form of drowning. It is seen among fishermen, bathers, dock workers, intoxicated, and epileptics. Homicidal drowning is the least common.

questions.text: The wrong statement regarding the practice shown in the below image is ________

choices.text: It reduces risk of hospital-acquired infection
It is not a part of warm chain
It can be done by fathers also
It increases rates of breast feeding

questions.solution:
Kangaroo mother care (as shown in the image) is a part of warm chain transportation of babies, especially when incubator ambulances are not available for transportation of the baby.  

Kangaroo discharge - Early discharge from hospital has been shown to cause reduced rates of hospital-acquired infections.

Kangaroo care is a part of the BFHI - Baby-Friendly Hospitals Initiative

Related Pearl: Baby-friendly hospital initiative (revised 2018)

Ten steps to successful breastfeeding (Revised 2018)

Critical management procedures

1  a. Comply fully with the International Code of Marketing of Breast-milk Substitutes and relevant World Health Assembly resolutions.

    b. Have a written infant feeding policy that is routinely communicated to staff and parents.

    c. Establish ongoing monitoring and data-management systems.

2. Ensure that staff has sufficient knowledge, competence, and skills to support breastfeeding.

Key clinical practices

3. Discuss the importance and management of breastfeeding with pregnant women and their families.

4. Facilitate immediate and uninterrupted skin-to-skin contact and support mothers to initiate breastfeeding as soon as possible after birth.

5. Support mothers to initiate and maintain breastfeeding and manage common difficulties.

6. Do not provide breastfed newborns any food or fluids other than breast milk, unless medically indicated.

7. Enable mothers and their infants to remain together and to practice rooming-in 24 hours a day.

8. Support mothers to recognize and respond to their infants’ cues for feeding.

9. Counsel mothers on the use and risks of feeding bottles, teats, and pacifiers.

10. Coordinate discharge so that parents and their infants have timely access to ongoing support and care.

questions.text: On performing a USG on a 23-year-old female, you notice a double bleb sign. The correct conclusion about the visualized structure would be:
questions.solution:
Double Bleb sign is a visualization of gestational sac containing a yolk sac and amniotic sac giving the appearance of two small bubbles.  

The two discs are separated by embryonic disc and distinguishes a pregnancy from a psudogestational sac or a decidual cast.  

This is different from the double decidual sign. 

The double decidual sac sign (DDSS) is a useful feature on early pregnancy ultrasound to confirm an early intrauterine pregnancy when the yolk sac or embryo is still not visualised. It consists of the decidua parietalis (lining the uterine cavity) and decidua capsularis (lining the gestational sac) and is seen as two concentric rings surrounding an anechoic gestational sac.

questions.text: Which of the following constitutes Leriche’s syndrome?
questions.solution:
Leriche syndrome is a rare form of Aorto-Iliac Occlusive Disease (AIOD) which presents with triad of intermittent claudication, erectile dysfunction and absent femoral pulses.

Option A: There is no atrophy of the abdominal vessels, but widespread atrophy of the lower extremities and a pale appearance of the extremities and foot can be seen in patinets with Leriche syndrome.

Option C: Since it is a chronic arterial disease, the distal pulses (eg.dorsalis pedis)  can be present due to formation of collaterals.

Note:

Although obstruction of the superficial femoral artery will cause claudication of buttock or thigh, associated or isolated discomfort of the calf can also be seen because the calf is the most distal large muscle group and is used extensively in walking.

questions.text:
A 10-year-old girl presents with an ovarian mass. Her serum biomarkers are normal except for elevated AFP. Identify the most likely diagnosis.

AFP: Alpha-fetoprotein
questions.solution:
The above given findings are suggestive of endodermal sinus tumor. Alpha- fetoprotein is commonly produced by these tumors. It is also called yolk sac tumour. 

It is an aggressive malignant germ cell tumor of ovaries. It occurs in ovaries or testes and sacrococcygeal area in young children.  

On appearance these tumors are yellow, friable (hemorrhagic), solid mass.  

50% of the tumors have Schiller-Duval bodies. This structure consists of a central capillary surrounded by tumor cells, present within a cystic space that may be lined by flat to cuboidal tumor cells. They are pathognomonic when present.

questions.text: The following statements are correct regarding TSH except:

choices.text: Actions of TSH are highly specific for thyroid gland
It has a stable secretion rate
TSH levels are increased in subclinical hypothyroidism
It has a relatively constant serum level

questions.solution:
TSH does not have a stable secretion rate, it is secreted in discrete pulses  

The actions of  TSH are highly specific for the thyroid gland.  

Its prolonged half-life accounts for relatively constant serum levels even though TSH is secreted in discrete pulses.  

TSH levels are indeed increased in subclinical hypothyroidism

Related Pearl: Causes of Hypothyroidism

 

Primary

(Low T3, T4 → Raised TSH levels)

(Low TSH levels → Low T3, T4)

(Low TRH → Low TSH → Low T3,T4)

questions.text: A patient presents with polyuria, polydipsia, lethargy and abdominal pain. He had an X-ray taken a few days ago, which is given below. Which of the following investigations would not be useful in arriving at a diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with the X-ray showing nephrocalcinosis is suggestive of primary hyperparathyroidism. Angiography of renal arteries is not a useful investigation for hyperparathyroidism.  

Nephrocalcinosis occurs in this condition due to hypercalcemia. It decreases renal concentrating ability, which may cause polyuria and polydipsia.

Clinical features of hyperparathyroidism:

  • Bones:
    • Pathological fractures
    • Subperiosteal bone resorption - 2nd and 3rd digits, most common in radial aspect
    • Salt and pepper skull
    • Osteitis fibrosa cystica or VonReckling Hausen’s disease of bone
  • Stones
    • Multiple and recurrent renal stones - most common
    • Nephrocalcinosis
  • Abdominal groans - colicky due to pancreatitis
  • Psychiatric overtones - raised PTH causing CNS depression and psychiatric symptoms
  • Band keratopathy
  • Features of hypercalcemia - 
    • Vomiting
    • Confusion
    • ECG changes: increased PR interval, shortened QT interval

 The image given below shows salt and pepper skull seen in hyperparathyroidism.

Investigations done in primary hyperparathyroidism:

  • Ultrasonography of the neck is a safe and widely used technique for the localization of abnormal parathyroid glands.  
  • Nuclear medicine scanning with radiolabeled Sestamibi is also a widely used technique. Sestamibi accumulates in parathyroid adenomas. This radionuclide is concentrated in the thyroid and parathyroid tissue but usually washes out of normal thyroid tissue in under an hour. It persists in abnormal parathyroid tissue.  
  • Dual-energy radiographic absorptiometry is a useful tool to demonstrate skeletal involvement in primary hyperparathyroidism.

The image given below shows a radiolabeled Sestamibi scan.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman expresses the desire to maintain a healthy lifestyle and has a focus on preventative health. She believes that she can prevent illness and cancer through ingesting supplements and antioxidants. When reviewing her current intake, you notice she is taking vitamin A 20,000 IU daily, for the past 12 months. What advice can you give her regarding this dose?

choices.text: Chronic ingestion of this dose could be associated with an increased risk of lung cancer even in non-smokers.
Chronic ingestion of this dose is associated with yellowing of the skin but not the sclerae.
She should discontinue this dose prior to attempting a pregnancy.
This dose is the highest daily recommended dose that is proven to be safe without toxicity.

questions.solution:
The patient should discontinue this dose prior to attempting a pregnancy as this dose could lead to an increased risk of spontaneous abortions and congenital malformations, including craniofacial abnormalities and valvular heart disease.

Other options:

  • High doses of carotenoids were given in a chemo-preventive trial to smokers, and those who were given the carotenoids were found to have a higher incidence of lung cancer. However, vitamin A has not been demonstrated to cause lung cancer in non-smokers.
  • Carotenemia is a condition that is associated with yellowing of the skin but not the sclerae and occurs with ingestion of >30mg of beta-carotene on a daily basis on a prolonged time. Beta-carotene (precursor of Vitamin A) is an organic compound found in plants and fruits and not in supplements. Therefore, the individual is not at risk of carotenemia form her excessive use of Vitamin A.
  • The highest daily recommended dose of vitamin A is 10,000 IU  daily. Chronic ingestion of doses higher than the recommended daily doses leads to symptoms of chronic intoxication. Acute toxicity manifests as increased intracranial pressure, diplopia, vertigo, seizures, and exfoliative dermatitis.

Related Pearl: Hypervitaminosis A

Hypervitaminosis A:

  • Vitamin A excess can present as two forms: vitamin A toxicity and carotenaemia.
  •  Hypervitaminosis A results from overconsumption of non‐prescription nutritional supplements, prescription medications containing vitamin A derivatives and foods high in vitamin A.
  • Carotenaemia is a benign disorder caused by excessive β‐carotene intake.
  • In carotenaemia, carotenes are excreted from sebaceous glands and sweat glands, and ultimately deposit in the stratum corneum. This results in carotenoderma.
  • Acute vitamin A toxicity manifests with headaches, vision changes, fatigue, anorexia, nausea, vomiting, myalgias and arthralgias. Weight loss can be observed with chronic intoxication.
  • Individuals with chronic hypervitaminosis A have dry and scaly skin, desquamation, cheilitis, alopecia, follicular hyperkeratosis and hyperpigmentation, associated pseudotumor cerebri and skeletal changes (premature closure of the epiphyses and pathological bone fractures).
  • Prognosis:
    • Vitamin A toxicity: discontinuation of vitamin A leads to resolution of almost all symptoms of vitamin A toxicity, with the exception of cirrhosis and sequelae related to pseudotumour cerebri.
    • Carotenaemia: Excellent prognosis with no clear long‐term adverse effects. Pigmentary changes resolve within weeks to months of decreasing β‐carotene intake.
